0001	一	一	one	1		floor, ceiling		yī		one; 1; single; a(n)			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4@"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">一的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A440"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">一的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E4%B8%80"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">一在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">一在RTK：one</span></a>	RTH
0002	二	二	two	2				èr		two; 2			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4G"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">二的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A447"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">二的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E4%BA%8C"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">二在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=2"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">二在RTK：two</span></a>	RTH

0011	口	口	Mouth	3		mouth		kǒu		mouth; entrance, gate			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4f"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">口的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A466"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">口的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%8F%A3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">口在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=11"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">口在RTK：mouth</span></a>	RTH

0013	月	月	Month	4		moon, flesh, part of body		yuè		moon; month			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4%EB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">月的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A4EB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">月的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%9C%88"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">月在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=13"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">月在RTK：month</span></a>	RTH
0014	田	田	Rice Field	5		rice field, brains		tián		field; farm; rice paddy			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A5%D0"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">田的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A5D0"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">田的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%94%B0"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">田在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=14"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">田在RTK：rice field</span></a>	RTH
0015	目	 目	Eye	5		eye, eyeball; 罒net		mù		eye; to look, see			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A5%D8"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">目的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A5D8"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">目的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/ %E7%9B%AE"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;"> 目在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/ %E7%9B%AE"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=15"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">目在RTK：eye</span></a>	RTH
0016	古	古	ancient	5				gǔ		ancient, old; paleo—			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A5j"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">古的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A56A"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">古的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%8F%A4"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">古在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=16"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">古在RTK：old</span></a>	RTH
0017	胡	胡	recklessly	9	Everyone knows what a new <i>moon</i> is: the first phase when the <i>moon</i> is illuminated 0%. So, presumably, an <i>ancient</i> <i>moon</i>, like the one in this character, is lit up at 100% wattage. And we all know what that means: people tend to get a little &quot;loony&quot; and start acting <b>recklessly</b>. [9]			hú		recklessly, foolishly, wildly; ALSO: whiskers, moustache			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%ADJ"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">胡的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AD4A"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">胡的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%83%A1"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">胡在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=2470"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">胡在RTK：uncivilized</span></a>	RTH
0018	吾	吾	I&nbsp;&nbsp;[literary]	7	There are a number of characters for the word <b>I</b>, but this one is restricted to literary use in Chinese. We need a sufficiently stuffy connotation for the key word, for which the sense of a &quot;perceiving subject&quot; should do just fine. Now the one place in our bodies that all <i>five</i> senses are concentrated in is the head, which has no less than <i>five</i> <i>mouths</i>: 2 nostrils, 2 ears, and 1 mouth. Hence, <i>five mouths</i> = <b>I</b>. [7]			wú		I; my; our (ie: royal &quot;we&quot;)			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A7^"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">吾的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A75E"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">吾的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%90%BE"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">吾在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=17"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">吾在RTK：i</span></a>	RTH
0019	朋	朋	Companion	8	The first <b>companion</b> that God made, as the Bible story goes, was Eve. Upon seeing her, Adam is said to have exclaimed, "<i>Flesh</i> of my <i>flesh</i>" And that is precisely what this character says in so many strokes. [8]			péng		friend, pal, acquaintance			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AAB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">朋的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AA42"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">朋的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%9C%8B"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">朋在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=19"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">朋在RTK：companion</span></a>	RTH
0020	明	明	bright	8	Among nature's <b>bright</b> lights, there are two that the biblical story of creation has God set in the sky: the <i>sun</i> to rule over the day and the <i>moon</i> to rule the night. Each of them has come to represent one of the common connotations of this key word: the sun, the <b>bright</b> insight of the clear thinker, and the moon, the <b>bright</b> intuition of the poet and the seer. [8]			míng		bright, clear; to understand (明白; míngbái); ALSO: the Ming dynasty			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A9%FA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">明的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A9FA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">明的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%98%8E"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">明在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=20"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">明在RTK：bright</span></a>	RTH
0021	唱	唱	to sing	11	This one is easy! You have one <i>mouth</i> making no noise (the choirmaster) and two <i>mouths with wagging tongues</i> (the minimum for a chorus). So when you hear the key word <b>sing</b>, think of the Vienna Boys' Choir or the Mormon Tabernacle Choir and the character is yours forever (see frame 12). [11]			chàng		to sing; to chant			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B0%DB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">唱的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B0DB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">唱的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%94%B1"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">唱在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=21"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">唱在RTK：chant</span></a>	RTH
0022	晶	晶	sparkling	12	What else can the word <b>sparkling</b> suggest if not a diamond? And if you've ever held a diamond up to the light, you will have noticed how every facet of it becomes like a miniature <i>sun</i>. This character is a picture of a tiny <i>sun</i> in three places (that is, "everywhere"), to give the sense of something <b>sparkling</b> all over the place. Just like a diamond. In writing the primitive elements three times, note again how the rule for writing given in frame 4 holds true not only for the strokes in each individual element but also for the disposition of the elements in the character as a whole. [12]			jīng		crystal, sparkling, bright, radiant			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B4%B9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">晶的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B4B9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">晶的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%99%B6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">晶在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=22"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">晶在RTK：sparkle</span></a>	RTH
0023	品	品	Goods	9	As in the character for <i>sparkling</i>, the triplication of a single element in this character indicates "everywhere" or "heaps of." When we think of <b>goods</b> in modern industrial society, we think of what has been mass-produced―that is to say, produced for the "masses" of open <i>mouths</i> waiting like fledglings in a nest to "consume" whatever comes their way. [9]			pǐn		article, product, commodity			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AB~"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">品的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AB7E"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">品的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%93%81"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">品在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=23"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">品在RTK：goods</span></a>	RTH
0024	昌	昌	prosperous	8	What we mentioned in the previous two frames about three of something meaning &quot;everywhere&quot; or &quot;heaps of&quot; was not meant to be taken lightly. In this character we see two <i>suns</i>, one atop the other, which, if we are not careful, is easily confused in memory with the three <i>suns</i> of <i>sparkling</i>. Focus on the number this way: since we speak of <b>prosperous</b> times as <i>sunny</i>, what could be more prosperous than a sky with two <i>suns</i> in it? Just be sure to actually see them there. [8]			chāng		prosperous; flourishing			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A9%F7"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">昌的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A9F7"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">昌的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%98%8C"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">昌在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=25"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">昌在RTK：prosperous</span></a>	RTH
0025	早	早	early	6	This character is actually a picture of the first flower of the day, which we shall, in defiance of botanical science, call the <i>sun</i>-flower, since it begins with the element for <i>sun</i> and is held up on a stem with leaves (the pictographic representation of the final two strokes). This time, however, we shall ignore the pictograph and imagine <i>sun</i>flowers with <i>needles</i> for stems, which can be plucked and used to darn your socks. The sense of <b>early</b> is easily remembered if one thinks of the <i>sun</i>flower as the <b>early</b> riser in the garden, because the <i>sun</i>, showing favoritism towards its namesake, shines on it before all the others (see frame 10). [6]	As a primitive element, this character takes the meaning of <i>sunflower</i>, which was used to make the abstract key word <i>early</i> more graphic.		zǎo		early; morning; for a long time, as early as ...			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A6%AD"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">早的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A6AD"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">早的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%97%A9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">早在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=26"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">早在RTK：early</span></a>	RTH
0026	旭	旭	Rising Sun	6	The key word here immediately suggests the islands located to the east of China, which would make it, from China's point of view, the Land of the <b>Rising Sun</b>, a name easily associated with Japan's national flag. If you can picture two seams running down that great red <i>sun</i>, and then imagine it sitting on a <i>baseball</i> bat for a flagpole, you have a slightly irreverent―but not altogether inaccurate―picture of how the sport has caught on in the Land of the <b>Rising Sun</b>. [6]			xù		dawn; the rising sun			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A6%B0"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">旭的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A6B0"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">旭的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%97%AD"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">旭在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=27"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">旭在RTK：rising sun</span></a>	RTH
0027	世	世	Generation	5	We generally consider one <b>generation</b> as a period of thirty (or <i>ten</i> plus <i>ten</i> plus <i>ten</i>) years. If you look at this character in its completed form―not in its stroke order―you will see three <i>tens</i>. When writing it, think of the lower horizontal lines as "addition" lines written under numbers to add them up. Thus: <i>ten</i> "plus" <i>ten</i> "plus" <i>ten</i> = thirty. Actually, it's a lot easier doing it with a pencil than reading it in a book. [5]			shì		generation, age, era; lifetime			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A5@"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">世的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A540"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">世的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E4%B8%96"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">世在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=28"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">世在RTK：generation</span></a>	RTH
0028	胃	胃	Stomach	9	You will need to refer back to frames 13 and 14 here for the special meaning of the two primitive elements that make up this character: <i>brain</i> and <i>flesh (part of the body)</i>. What the character says, if you look at it, is that the <i>part of the body</i> that keeps the <i>brain</i> in working order is the <b>stomach</b>. To keep the elements in proper order, when you write this character think of the <i>brain</i> as being "held up" by the <i>flesh</i>. [9]			wèi		stomach, belly, paunch			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%ADG"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">胃的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AD47"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">胃的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%83%83"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">胃在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=29"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">胃在RTK：stomach</span></a>	RTH
0029	旦	旦	Daybreak	5	The obvious sign of <b>daybreak</b> is the <i>sun</i> peeking out over the horizon, which is pretty much what this character depicts. If you can imagine the <i>sun</i> poking its head out through a hole in your <i>floor</i>, however, you will have an easier time remembering this character. [5]			dàn		dawn, morning, day-break			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A5%B9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">旦的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A5B9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">旦的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%97%A6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">旦在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=30"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">旦在RTK：nightbreak</span></a>	RTH
0030	凹	凹	concave	5	You couldn't have asked for a better key word for this character! Just have a look at it: a perfect image of a concave lens (remembering, of course, that the characters square off rounded things), complete with its own little &quot;cave.&quot; Now all you have to do is learn how to write it. [5]			āo		concave, indented or depressed, sunken			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A5W"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">凹的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A557"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">凹的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%87%B9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">凹在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=33"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">凹在RTK：concave</span></a>	RTH
0031	凸	凸	convex	5	Maybe this helps you see how the Chinese have no trouble keeping <b>convex</b> distinct from <i>concave</i>. Note the odd feeling of the fourth stroke. If it doesn't feel all that strange now, by the time you are done with this book, it will. There are very few times you will have to write it. [5]			tū [普], tú [國]		convex, protruding; bulge out			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A5Y"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">凸的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A559"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">凸的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%87%B8"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">凸在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=34"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">凸在RTK：convex</span></a>	RTH
0032	自	自	oneself	6	You can think of this character as a stylized pictograph of the nose, that little <i>drop</i> that Mother Nature set between your <i>eyes</i>. The Chinese often refer to themselves by pointing a finger at their nose―giving us an easy way to remember the character for <b>oneself</b>. [6]	The same meaning of <i>oneself</i> can be kept when this character is used as a primitive element, but you will generally find it better to give it the meaning of <i>nose</i> or <i>nostrils</i>, both because it accords with the story above and because it is the first part of the character for <i>nose</i> (frame 575).		zì		oneself, self; personal			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A6%DB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">自的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A6DB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">自的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%87%AA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">自在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=36"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">自在RTK：oneself</span></a>	RTH
0033	白	白	white	5	The color <b>white</b> is a mixture of all the primary colors, both for pigments and for light, as we see when a prism breaks up the rays of the <i>sun</i>. Hence, a single <i>drop</i> of <i>sun</i> spells <b>white</b>. [5]	As a primitive, this character can either retain its meaning of <i>white</i> or take the more graphic meaning of a <i>white bird</i> or <i>dove</i>. This stems from the fact that it appears at the top of the character for <i>bird</i>, which we shall get to later (frame 1396).		bái		white, pure, unblemished; clear, plain			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A5%D5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">白的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A5D5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">白的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%99%BD"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">白在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=37"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">白在RTK：white</span></a>	RTH
0034	百	百	hundred	6	When the Japanese borrowed the Chinese characters, they often played with their shapes to find interesting connections. For example, they came to refer to a person's 99th birthday as the start of the "<i>white</i> year" because <i>white</i> is the character you are left with if you subtract <i>one</i> from a <b>hundred</b>. [6]			bǎi		hundred; numerous			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A6%CA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">百的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A6CA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">百的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%99%BE"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">百在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=38"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">百在RTK：hundred</span></a>	RTH
0035	皂	皂	Soap	7	Whatever the color of the <b>soap</b> that this character refers to, it does the same trick of <i>cutting</i> the grease and grime to make things <i>white</i>. That's a bit too abstract and reasonable, though, so you may want to imagine looking at the soap under a microscope and seeing little whirling blades <i>dicing</i> the blotches of dirt one by one until everything turns <i>white</i>. [7]			zào		soap; black			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A8m"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">皂的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A86D"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">皂的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%9A%82"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">皂在n词酷</span></a>・	RTH
0036	中	中	Middle	4	The elements in this character are a <i>walking stick</i> and a <i>mouth</i>. The connotation we will associate with the key word <b>middle</b> is that period of life known as <b>middle</b> age, so called because it is the time in your life when you have trouble with your expanding "<b>middle</b>." More often than not, the expansion has to do with eating more and moving around less. This character has the<br />grotesque image of a person with a <i>walking stick</i> jammed into his <i>mouth</i>, the more easily to shovel food in without the interference of the tedious exercise of opening and closing it. [4]<br />Note the indicator that the character for <b>middle</b> can be used as either a noun or an adjective. Where no part of speech is indicated, assume the most common. In the case of the former frame, for example, <i>soap</i> might be taken as a verb, but one's first thought goes to the noun, which is a good place to start for that character. Be aware, though, that even where one part of speech is indicated for a character, other possibilities may exist.			zhōng		center, middle; central; in the midst of; ALSO: China			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4%A4"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">中的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A4A4"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">中的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E4%B8%AD"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">中在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=39"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">中在RTK：in</span></a>	RTH
0037	千	千	thousand	3	This character is almost too simple to pull apart, but for the sake of practice, have a look at the <i>eyedropper</i> above and the <i>ten</i> below. Now put the elements together by thinking of squeezing two more zeros out of an eyedropper alongside the number <i>ten</i> to make it a <b>thousand</b>. [3]			qiān		thousand; a multitude			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4d"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">千的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A464"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">千的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%8D%83"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">千在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=40"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">千在RTK：thousand</span></a>	RTH
0038	舌	舌	Tongue	6	The characters for <i>mouth</i> and <i>thousand</i> naturally form the idea of <b>tongue</b> if one thinks of a <i>thousand</i> <i>mouths</i> able to speak the same language, or as we say, "sharing a common <b>tongue</b>." It is easy to see the connection between the idiom and the character if you take its image literally: a single <b>tongue</b> being passed around from <i>mouth</i> to <i>mouth</i>. [6]			shé		tongue			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A6%DE"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">舌的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A6DE"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">舌的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%88%8C"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">舌在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=41"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">舌在RTK：tongue</span></a>	RTH
0039	升	升	Liter	4	Think of a one-<b>liter</b> carafe (the kind you might serve drinks in) filled not with milk or wine but with a <i>thousand</i> sharp <i>needles</i>. You may well wonder what they are doing there, but the answer is simple: it's a kind of sports drink for a robot. [4]			shēng		metric liter MW (also written 公升; gōngshēng)			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4%C9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">升的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A4C9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">升的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%8D%87"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">升在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=42"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">升在RTK：measuring box</span></a>	RTH
0040	昇	升	to rise up	8	Keeping the image from the last frame, we have here a <i>liter</i> carafe with a <i>sun</i> above it. Conveniently, the connotation of the key word <b>rise up</b> is what the <i>sun</i> does in the morning, just before breakfast. Can you actually SEE it <b>rising up</b> out of the <i>liter</i> carafe of freshly squeezed <i>Sun</i>kist orange juice on your breakfast table? [8]			shēng		to raise, hoist; promote; ascend			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AA@"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">昇的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AA40"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">昇的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%8D%87"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">升在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%8D%87"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=43"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">昇在RTK：rise up</span></a>	RTH
0041	丸	丸	Pill	3	One of the scourges of sports like modern baseball has been the use of performance-enhancing drugs, those tiny little pills that have helped turn honest competition into cut-throat business. Now look at the character and picture it as a bottle of pills hanging on the thigh of a baseball player like a pez dispenser, ready for the popping as the need arises. [3]	As a primitive, this element takes the meaning of a <i>bottle of pills</i>.		wán		pill, pellet, small round object; ball			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4Y"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">丸的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A459"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">丸的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E4%B8%B8"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">丸在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=44"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">丸在RTK：round</span></a>	RTH
0042	卜	卜	Divination	2		When using this character as a primitive, we will stick with the meaning of a <i>divining rod</i> or a <i>magic wand</i>.		bǔ		fortune telling; prophesy; to divine; foretell			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4R"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">卜的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A452"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">卜的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%8D%9C"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">卜在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=2103"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">卜在RTK：augury</span></a>	RTH
0043	占	占	to tell fortunes	5	This is one of those characters that is a real joy of simplicity: a <i>divining rod</i> with a <i>mouth</i> ― which are the two ingredients needed to <b>tell fortunes</b>. Note how the movement from top to bottom (the movement in which the characters are written) is also the order of the elements which make up our story and of the key word itself: first <i>divining rod</i>, then <i>mouth</i>. This will not always be possible, but where it is, memory has almost no work at all to do. [5]			zhān		to divine; practice divination			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A5e"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">占的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A565"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">占的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%8D%A0"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">占在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=48"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">占在RTK：fortune-telling</span></a>	RTH
0044	上	上	above	3	The two directions, <b>above</b> and <i>below</i>, are usually pointed at with the finger. But the characters do not follow that custom, so we have to choose something else, easily remembered. The primitives show a <i>magic wand</i> standing <b>above</b> a <i>floor</i> ― "magically," you might say. Anyway, go right on to the next frame, since the two belong together and are best remembered as a unit, just as the words <b>above</b> and <i>below</i> suggest each other. [3]			shàng		top, superior, above, highest; to go up, forge ahead			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4W"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">上的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A457"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">上的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E4%B8%8A"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">上在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=49"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">上在RTK：above</span></a>	RTH
0045	下	下	below	3	Here we see our famous <i>magic wand</i> hanging, all on its own, <b>below</b> the <i>ceiling</i>, as you probably already guessed would happen. In addition to giving us two new characters, the two shapes in this and the preceding frame also serve to illustrate the difference between the primitive meanings for <i>ceiling</i> and <i>floor</i>: it all depends on whether the single horizontal line stands above or <b>below</b> the primitive element to which it is related. [3]			xìa		under, underneath, below, down; inferior; to bring down			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4U"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">下的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A455"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">下的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E4%B8%8B"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">下在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=50"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">下在RTK：below</span></a>	RTH
0046	卡	卡	Card	5	The key word <b>card</b> can stand for all sorts of things, but let's settle on a credit <b>card</b> for our image. Perhaps the first thing that comes to mind is the picture of a shopkeeper sliding your credit <b>card</b> up and down (from <i>above</i> to <i>below</i> and back again) in the reading machine to record your transaction. Now imagine her doing it fast and furiously, again and again, with increasing impatience until your poor <b>card</b> is whittled away to a small strip of plastic. [5]		(credit card)	kǎ		card, punch card			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A5d"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">卡的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A564"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">卡的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%8D%A1"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">卡在n词酷</span></a>・	RTH
0047	卓	卓	eminent	8	The word <b>eminent</b> suggests a famous or well-known person. So all you need to do―given the primitives of a <i>magic wand</i> and a <i>sunflower</i> ― is to think of the world's most <b>eminent</b> magician as one who uses a <i>sunflower</i> for a <i>magic wand</i> (like a flower-child who goes around turning the world into peace and love). [8]			zhuó		profound, eminent, lofty			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A8%F4"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">卓的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A8F4"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">卓的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%8D%93"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">卓在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=51"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">卓在RTK：eminent</span></a>	RTH
0048	朝	朝	Dynasty	12	It is easy to imagine one of the great <b>dynasties</b> of China in all its glory. Now all we have to figure out is what the elements <i>moon</i> and <i>mist</i> have to do with it. Picture a great palace with a powerful emperor seated on a throne in its innermost court. To keep the Wizard-of-Oz illusion that this power is beyond question and beyond the understanding of the masses, the whole complex is kept permanently shrouded in <i>mist</i>. How do they do it, you ask. On one side of the throne is a servant pulling on a cord to wave a gigantic fan back and forth. On the other, a servant with a long cord hooked on a corner of the quarter <i>moon</i>. When he pulls on it, the <i>moon</i> tilts over and spills out a month's supply of <i>mist</i> that keeps the myth of the dynasty alive. [12]			cháo		dynasty, imperial court; ALSO: Korea<br>towards<br>to face<br>facing<br>direct<br>a dynasty<br>the imperial court<br>open to			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B4%C2"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">朝的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B4C2"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">朝的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%9C%9D"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">朝在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=52"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">朝在RTK：morning</span></a>	RTH
0049	嘲	嘲	to ridicule	15	If you read off the elements in the character, you have something like "<i>mouthing</i> off at the <i>dynasty</i>!" When we think of what we commonly <b>ridicule</b> in civilized society, one of the oldest and most universal targets is the ruling elite. Who better to deride than one's leaders? Again, the explanation is too rational, so turn it into a story that has you <b>ridiculing</b> a particular <i>dynasty</i>'s court with particular buffoonery. [15]			cháo		to ridicule, mock, deride, scorn			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%BCJ"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">嘲的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=BC4A"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">嘲的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%98%B2"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">嘲在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=2155"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">嘲在RTK：derision</span></a>	RTH
0050	只	只	only	5	When we run across abstract key words like this one, the best<br>way to get an image is to recall some common but suggestive<br>phrase in which the word appears. For instance, we can think<br>of the expression "it's the only one of its kind." Then we imagine<br>a barker at a side-show advertising some strange pac-man like<br>creature he has inside his tent, with only a gigantic mouth and<br>two wee animal legs. [5]			zhǐ		only, merely, just, but			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A5u"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">只的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A575"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">只的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%8F%AA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">只在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=53"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">只在RTK：only</span></a>	RTH
0051	貝	贝	Shellfish	7	To remember the primitive elements that make up this charac-<br />ter, an <i>eye</i> and <i>animal legs</i>, you might be tempted to think of it<br />as a pictograph of a <b>shellfish</b> with its ridged shell at the top and<br />two little <i>legs</i> sticking out of the bottom. But that might not help<br />you recall later just how many ridges to put on the shell. Better<br />to imagine a freakish <b>shellfish</b> with a single, gigantic <i>eye</i> roam-<br />ing the beaches on its slender little <i>legs</i>, scaring the wits out of<br />the sunbathers. [7]	When this character is used as a primitive, in addition to <i>shellfish</i>, the meanings <i>shells</i>, <i>oysters</i>, and <i>clams</i> will often come in handy.		bèi	note: never right side	shellfish; sea shell; money			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A8%A9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">貝的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A8A9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">貝的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%B4%9D"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">贝在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%B4%9D"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=54"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">貝在RTK：shellfish</span></a>	RTH
0052	貼	贴	to paste	12	Think here of brushing on an adhesive, as when you paste<br />something on a billboard. Here we have an oyster pasting a<br />poster on his back to advertise his services in the dubious occu-<br />pation of one who tells fortunes. Try to imagine the problem<br />he would have reaching his back with the brush to paste, and<br />then see him strutting around and calling out, &quot;Fortunes to tell!<br />Fortunes to tell!&quot; [12]			tiē		to paste to, stick on, glue; attached to			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B6K"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">貼的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B64B"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">貼的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%B4%B4"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">贴在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%B4%B4"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=2736"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">貼在RTK：affix</span></a>	RTH
0053	貞	贞	chaste	9	You have heard of Diogenes running around with his lamp<br />looking for an honest man. Here we have an image of the<br />famous shellfish, Oysterogenes, running around with his divin-<br />ing rod looking for a chaste man. We leave it to you to decide<br />which one has the better luck in his quest. [9]			zhēn	//clamshell around penis//	virtuous, chaste, pure; loyal			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%ADs"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">貞的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AD73"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">貞的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%B4%9E"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">贞在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%B4%9E"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=55"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">貞在RTK：upright</span></a>	RTH
0054	員	员	Employee	10	How do we get a mouth over a shellfish to mean an employee?<br />Simple. Just remember the advice new employees get about<br />keeping their mouths shut and doing their jobs, and then make<br />that more graphic by picturing an office building full of white-<br />collar workers scurrying around with clams pinched to their<br />mouths. [10]			yuán		employee, assistant; personnel, staff member			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AD%FB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">員的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=ADFB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">員的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%91%98"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">员在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%91%98"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=56"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">員在RTK：employee</span></a>	RTH
0055	見	见	to see	7	The elements that compose the character for see are the eye<br />firmly fixed to a pair of human legs. Surely, somewhere in your<br />experience, there is a vivid image just waiting to be dragged up<br />to help you remember this character.... [7]			jiàn		see, observe, behold; percieve			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A8%A3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">見的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A8A3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">見的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%A7%81"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">见在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%A7%81"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=57"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">見在RTK：see</span></a>	RTH
0056	元	元	Beginning	4	"In the beginning..." starts that marvelous shelf of books we<br />call the Bible. It talks about how all things were made, and tells<br />us that when it came to humanity the Creator made two of<br />them, man and woman. While we presume two were made of<br />every other creature as well, we are not told as much. Hence we<br />need only two and a pair of human legs to come to the character<br />that means beginning. [4]		(<u>not</u> <i>to begin</i>)	yuán		origin; first, primary; dollar; ALSO: Yuan dynasty			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4%B8"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">元的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A4B8"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">元的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%85%83"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">元在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=59"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">元在RTK：beginning</span></a>	RTH
0057	頁	页	Page	9	What we have to do here is turn a shellfish into a page of a book.<br>The one at the top tells us that we only get a rather short book,<br>in fact a book of only one page. Imagine a title printed on the<br>shell of an oyster, let us say "Pearl of Wisdom," and then open<br>the quaint book to its one and only page, on which you find a<br>single, radiant drop of wisdom, one of the masterpiece poems of<br>nature. [9]	As a primitive, this character often takes the unrelated meaning of a <i>head </i>(preferably one detached from its body), derived from the character for <i>head </i>(frame 1067).		yè		page; leaf			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AD%B6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">頁的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=ADB6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">頁的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E9%A1%B5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">页在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E9%A1%B5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=60"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">頁在RTK：page</span></a>	RTH
0058	頑	顽	stubborn	13	This character refers to a blockhead, a persistently stubborn<br />person who sticks to an idea or a plan just the way it was at the<br />beginning, without letting anything that comes up along the way<br />alter things in the least. The explanation makes &quot;sense,&quot; but is<br />hard to remember because the word &quot;beginning&quot; is too abstract.<br />Back up to the image we used two frames ago―Adam and Eve<br />in their Eden―and try again: The root of all this goes back to<br />the beginning, with two brothers each defending his own way<br />of life and asking their God to bless it favorably. Abel stuck to<br />agriculture, Cain to animal-raising. Picture these two seeking<br />the favors of heaven, one of them with an unusually stubborn<br />grimace on his face. No wonder something unfortunate hap-<br />pened! [13]			wán		obstinate, stubborn; recalcitrant			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B9x"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">頑的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B978"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">頑的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E9%A1%BD"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">顽在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E9%A1%BD"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=61"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">頑在RTK：stubborn</span></a>	RTH
0059	凡	凡	ordinary	3	While we refer to something insignificant as a "drop in the<br />bucket," the character for ordinary shows us a "drop in the<br />wind" To make the image stick as clearly as water dropping into<br />a bucket, stop and think of something really ordinary and then<br />say, "It's just a drop in the wind"―and imagine what that might<br />actually look like. [3]			fán		ordinary, common, mundane			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4Z"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">凡的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A45A"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">凡的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%87%A1"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">凡在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=62"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">凡在RTK：mediocre</span></a>	RTH
0060	肌	肌	Muscle	6	One of the more common ways of testing the strength of one's<br />muscles is to lock hands with a local hulk on a small table top<br />and arm wrestle. This is the image here, depicted by the ele-<br />ments for part of the body and small table. The muscle is, there-<br />fore, the part of the body you test by literally bringing it to the<br />small table. [6]		(full character)	jī		flesh; muscle			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A6%D9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">肌的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A6D9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">肌的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%82%8C"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">肌在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=66"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">肌在RTK：texture</span></a>	RTH
0061	負	负	defeated	9	Above we have the condensed form of bound up, and below, the<br>familiar shellfish. Now imagine two oysters engaged in shell-to-<br>shell combat, the one who is defeated being bound and gagged<br>with seaweed, the victor towering triumphantly over it. The<br>bound shellfish thus becomes the symbol for anyone or any-<br>thing that has been defeated. [9]			fù		to lose; to be burdened; negative (math)			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%ADt"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">負的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AD74"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">負的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%B4%9F"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">负在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%B4%9F"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=63"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">負在RTK：defeat</span></a>	RTH
0062	勻	匀	uniform	4	The two primitives bound up and two (clearer in the hand-<br />drawn form) combine to give the meaning of uniform. One<br />of the real challenges for primary school teachers is to keep<br />students from scattering every which direction. If you think<br />of the final touch to a school outfit, the shoes, and then recall<br />the childhood jingle, &quot;One, two, buckle my shoe,&quot; the solution<br />is near at hand. Instead of having children buckle their shoes,<br />they can be taught to tie their shoelaces together by changing<br />the lyrics to read &quot;One, two, bind up my shoes.&quot; This keeps them<br />from straying very far from the group and helps teachers pro-<br />vide a uniform education. [4]			yún		equal; evenly (divided); uniform			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4%C3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">勻的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A4C3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">勻的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%8C%80"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">匀在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%8C%80"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・	RTH
0063	句	句	Sentence	5	By combining the two primitives bound up and mouth, it is easy<br>to see how this character can have the meaning of a sentence.<br>The mouth suggests it is a spoken sentence. To be more precise,<br>it is a cluster of words bound up tightly and neatly so that they<br>will fit in your mouth. [5]			jù		sentence, phrase, clause; MW for verse			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A5y"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">句的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A579"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">句的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%8F%A5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">句在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=65"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">句在RTK：phrase</span></a>	RTH
0064	旬	旬	Decameron	6	There simply is not a good phrase in English for the block of ten<br />days which this character represents. So we resurrect the classi-<br />cal term decameron, whose connotations the tales of Boccaccio<br />have done much to enrich. Actually, it refers to a journey of<br />ten days taken by a band of people―that is, a group of people<br />bound together for the days of the decameron. [6]			xún		a ten-day period			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A6%AF"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">旬的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A6AF"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">旬的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%97%AC"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">旬在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=67"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">旬在RTK：decameron</span></a>	RTH
0065	勺	勺	Ladle	3		If you want to bind up drops of anything―water, soup, lemon-<br>ade―you use something to scoop these drops up, which is what<br>we call a ladle. See the last drop left inside the ladle? [3]		sháo		spoon, ladle; (unit of volume = 10 ml)			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4c"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">勺的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A463"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">勺的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%8B%BA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">勺在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=68"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">勺在RTK：ladle</span></a>	RTH
0066	的	的	Bull’s Eye	8	The elements white bird and ladle easily suggest the image of<br>a bull's eye if you imagine a rusty old ladle with a bull's eye<br>painted on it in the form of a tiny white bird, who lets out a little<br>"peep" every time you hit the target.<br>This is the most frequently used character in Chinese, serv-<br>ing a number of common grammatical functions. But―it also<br>means bull's eye. [8]			de		[possessive marker]; as (dì) = "aim"			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AA%BA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">的的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AABA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">的的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%9A%84"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">的在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=69"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">的在RTK：bull's eye</span></a>	RTH
0067	首	首	Heads	9	Reading this character from the top down, we have: horns ...<br>nose. Together they bring to mind the picture of a moose-head<br>hanging on the den wall, with its great horns and long nose. The<br>plural form is used to stress the frequent metaphorical use of<br>the term to refer to various kinds of heads, including heads of<br>state. It might help to see a number of the latter lined up on the<br>den wall alongside the moose, each fitted out with antlers and a<br>whopper of a nose.<br>Here we get a good look at what we mentioned when we first<br>introduced the element for horns: that they can never be left<br>floating free and require an extra horizontal stroke to prevent<br>that from happening, as is the case here. [9]			shǒu		head, chief, leader; first (occasion or thing); MW for poems			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AD%BA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">首的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=ADBA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">首的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E9%A6%96"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">首在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=70"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">首在RTK：neck</span></a>	RTH
0068	直	直	straight	8	Think of the first two elements, ten eyes, as referring to a group<br>of five scientists working together on a top-secret, million-<br>dollar project to draw a straight line on the floor without the<br>aid of special equipment. In the end, all ten eyes verify that it<br>is straight, leaving no doubt that the use of government funds<br>was fully justified. Time to apply for another grant.<br>Note how the first two strokes of the element for eye are made<br>a little longer so that they can touch the final stroke. The same<br>thing will happen in the following three characters, and later on<br>as well, so pay particular attention to the stroke order below. [8]			zhí		straight, vertical, upright, erect; frank, candid			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AA%BD"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">直的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AABD"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">直的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%9B%B4"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">直在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=73"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">直在RTK：straightaway</span></a>	RTH
0069	置	置	to set up	13	Think of having to set up the net for a badminton or volleyball<br>game. One of the main problems is how to keep the net in a<br>straight line so that it doesn't sag in the middle. Which is just<br>what this character shows us. [13]			zhì		place, arrange, lay out; set aside			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B8m"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">置的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B86D"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">置的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%BD%AE"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">置在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=832"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">置在RTK：placement</span></a>	RTH
0070	具	具	Tool	8	Here is the full character on which the primitive of the last<br />frame is based. If you can think of a table full of carpenter's<br />tools of all sorts, each equipped with its own eye so that it can<br />keep a watch over what you are doing with it, you won't have<br />trouble later keeping the primitive and the character apart. [8]			jù		tool, instrument, device; equipment			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A8%E3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">具的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A8E3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">具的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%85%B7"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">具在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=74"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">具在RTK：tool</span></a>	RTH
0071	真	真	true	10	Here is an example of how there can be different ways of identi-<br />fying the primitive elements that make up a character. The most<br />obvious is straight and animal legs, but the character could as<br />well be analyzed into ten and tool. Let's choose the latter.<br />How do you know if something is true or not? What if there<br />were a kit of ten tools you could count on to run a test? Well, at<br />least when it comes to asking whether people are really true to<br />themselves, the ten commandments are a good start. [10]<br />			zhēn		real, true, actual, genuine			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AFu"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">真的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AF75"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">真的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%9C%9F"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">真在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=75"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">真在RTK：true</span></a>	RTH
0072	工	工	the Work	3	The pictograph of an I-beam, like the kind that is used in heavy<br>construction work on buildings and bridges, gives us the char-<br>acter for work. [3]	Since the key word can be too abstract when used as a primitive element, we will often revert to the clearer image of an <i>I-beam</i>.		gōng		work, labor, worker; working class; skill, (cp: 唱工; chànggōng; the art of singing)			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4u"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">工的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A475"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">工的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%B7%A5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">工在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=76"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">工在RTK：craft</span></a>	RTH
0073	左	左	Left	5	By combining the last two frames and reading the results, we<br>get: by ones side... work. Conveniently, the left has traditionally<br>been considered the "sinister" side, where dark and occult works<br>are cultivated and carried out. [5]			zuǒ		left, lefthand; unorthodox, improper; leftwing			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A5%AA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">左的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A5AA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">左的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%B7%A6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">左在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=77"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">左在RTK：left</span></a>	RTH
0074	右	右	Right	5	When thinking of the key word right, in order to avoid con-<br>fusion with the previous frame, take advantage of the double<br>meaning here. Imagine a little mouth hanging down by one's<br>side―one's right side, of course―like a little voice of conscience<br>telling one the "right" thing to do. [5]			yòu		right, righthand; rightwing			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A5k"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">右的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A56B"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">右的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%8F%B3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">右在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=78"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">右在RTK：right</span></a>	RTH
0075	有	有	to possess	6	The picture here is a slab of flesh dangling by one's side, perhaps<br>from a belt or rope tied around the waist. While we normally<br>think of things that we have and possess, we also know that<br>there are things that can have and possess us. Such cases might<br>be likened to an evil spirit possessing one's soul. This character<br>suggests a way to exorcize it: hang a slab of fresh flesh by one's<br>side until it begins to putrefy and stink so bad that the demon<br>departs. Take careful note of the stroke order. [6]			yǒu		have, own, possess; exist			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A6%B3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">有的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A6B3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">有的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%9C%89"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">有在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=79"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">有在RTK：possess</span></a>	RTH
0076	賄	贿	bribe	13	To the left we have the primitive for a shellfish, and to the right,<br />the character we just learned for possess. Keep the connotation<br />of the last frame for the word possess, and now expand your<br />image of shells to include the ancient value they had as money<br />(a usage that will come in very helpful later on). Now people<br />who are possessed by shells are likely to abandon any higher<br />principles to acquire more and more wealth. These are the easi-<br />est ones to persuade with a bribe of a few extra shells. [13]<br />			huì		bribe; to offer a bribe			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B8%EC"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">賄的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B8EC"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">賄的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%B4%BF"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">贿在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%B4%BF"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=80"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">賄在RTK：bribe</span></a>	leech RTH
0077	貢	贡	Tribute	10	A tribute has a kind of double meaning in English: honor paid<br />freely and money (shells) collected by coercion. Simply because<br />a ruler bestows a noble name on a deed is hardly any consola-<br />tion to the masses who must part with their hard-earned shells.<br />Little wonder that this ancient work of gathering money by call-<br />ing it a tribute has given way to a name closer to how it feels to<br />those who pay it: a tax. [10]<br />			gòng		tribute, gifts			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B0^"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">貢的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B05E"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">貢的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%B4%A1"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">贡在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%B4%A1"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=81"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">貢在RTK：tribute</span></a>	RTH
0078	項	项	Item	12	To the right we see a page and to the left an element for I-beam.<br />The item referred to here is not some specific object but an<br />entry on an "itemized" list. Each item in the list you have to<br />imagine here is preceded by a little I-beam―not a drawing, but<br />an actual iron I-beam. Imagine lugging a list like that around<br />the grocery store! [12]<br />			xiàng		item, thing; sum (of money)			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B6%B5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">項的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B6B5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">項的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E9%A1%B9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">项在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E9%A1%B9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=82"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">項在RTK：paragraph</span></a>	RTH
0079	刀	刀	Sword	2	Although this character no longer looks very much like a sword,<br />it does have some resemblance to the handle of the sword. As<br />it turns out, this is to our advantage, in that it helps us make a<br />distinction between two primitive elements based on this char-<br />acter. [2]<br />	In the form of the character, this primitive means a <i>dagger</i>. When it appears to the right of another element, it is commonly stretched out like this 刂, and like this 'J when to the left of another element. In these cases, it will take the sense of a great and flashing <i>saber</i>, a meaning it gets from a character to be introduced in Book 2.		dāo		knife, dagger			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4M"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">刀的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A44D"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">刀的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%88%80"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">刀在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=83"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">刀在RTK：sword</span></a>	RTH
0080	刃	刃	Blade	3	Think of using a dagger as a razor blade, and it shouldn't be<br>hard to imagine cutting yourself. See the little drop of blood<br>dripping off the blade? [3]			rèn		blade; edge of blade			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4b"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">刃的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A462"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">刃的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%88%83"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">刃在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=84"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">刃在RTK：blade</span></a>	RTH
0081	切	切	to cut	4	To the right we see the dagger and next to it the number seven,<br />whose primitive meaning we decided would be diced (frame<br />7). It is hard to cut meat or vegetables with a knife without<br />imagining one of those skillful Japanese chefs. Only let us say<br />that he has had too much sake to drink at a party, grabs a dag-<br />ger lying on the mantelpiece and starts dicing up everything in<br />sight, starting with the hors d'oeuvres and going on to cut up<br />the furniture and carpets.... [4]			qiē		to cut, slice, chop			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4%C1"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">切的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A4C1"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">切的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%88%87"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">切在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=85"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">切在RTK：cut</span></a>	RTH
0082	召	召	to summon	5	A sword or dagger poised over a mouth is how the character<br />used to summon a person is written. Note the immediate―how<br />shall we put it politely?―Freudian implications of the charac-<br />ter. (Observe, too, if you will, that it is not at all clear whether<br />the long slender object is summoning the small round one or<br />vice versa.) [5]	The primitive meaning remains the same. Just be sure to associate it with a very concrete image, such as a prosecutor at your door with a document that summons you to appear in court.		zhào		to call together, summon, convene			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A5l"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">召的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A56C"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">召的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%8F%AC"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">召在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=86"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">召在RTK：seduce</span></a>	RTH
0083	昭	昭	evident	9	Nothing quite works to make something evident like "evidence"<br />that backs it up. Here we see a lawyer who summons the sun<br />down from the noonday sky to stand as a witness and make the<br />facts as evident as can be. [9]			zhāo		manifest, clear, obvious, evident			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%ACL"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">昭的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AC4C"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">昭的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%98%AD"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">昭在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=87"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">昭在RTK：shining</span></a>	RTH
0084	則	则	Rule	9	The character depicts a clam alongside a great and flashing<br />saber. Think of digging for clams in an area where there are<br />gaming rules governing how large a find has to be before you<br />can keep it. So you take your trusty saber, which you have care-<br />fully notched like a yardstick, crack open a clam and then mea-<br />sure the poor little beastie to see if it is as long as the rules say it<br />has to be. [9]			zé		rule, law, regulation; general principle			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%ABh"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">則的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AB68"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">則的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%88%99"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">则在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%88%99"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=88"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">則在RTK：rule</span></a>	RTH
0085	副	副	vice—	11	The key word vice- has the sense of someone second-in-com-<br />mand. The great and flashing saber to the right (its usual loca-<br />tion, so you need not worry about where to put it from now<br />on) and the wealth on the left combine to create an image of<br />dividing one's property to give a share to one's vice-wealth-<br />holder. [11]			fù		secondary, auxiliary; deputy, assistant, vice-			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B0%C6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">副的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B0C6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">副的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%89%AF"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">副在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=89"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">副在RTK：vice-</span></a>	RTH
0086	丁	丁	fourth	2	This character is fourth in a system of enumeration from first to<br />tenth based on an ancient lunar calendar and referred to as &quot;the<br />celestial stems.&quot; What it shows us is someone waiting fourth in<br />line, using a giant metal spike as a makeshift chair. [2]	When used as a primitive, the character changes its meaning to <i>nail</i> or <i>spike</i>.		dīng		4th Heavenly Stem; [nail]; 4th (in order); man, cube			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4B"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">丁的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A442"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">丁的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E4%B8%81"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">丁在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=91"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">丁在RTK：street</span></a>	RTH
0087	叮	叮	to sting	5	You know how a bee stings, right? It drives the little barbed<br />spike in its bottom into your skin and then pulls away. Of course,<br />as we noted way back in frame 11, the primitive element for<br />mouth can refer to any kind of orifice, but imagine the damage<br />a bee could inflict if it could sting with its mouth at the same<br />time―a kind of bi-polar attack.
