[5]		(mosquito bite)	dīng		sting (mosquito bite); to stick to a point; ask repeatedly			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A5m"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">叮的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A56D"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">叮的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%8F%AE"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">叮在n词酷</span></a>・	RTH
0088	可	可	can	5	To begin with, you will notice that this character is composed of<br>the very same elements as that of the former frame. Only their<br>arrangement is different.<br>Remember the story about the "Little Engine that Could"<br>when you hear this key word, and the rest is simple. See the<br>determined little locomotive huffing and puffing up the moun-<br>tain―"I think I can, I think I can..."―spitting railroad spikes<br>out of its mouth as it chews up the line to the top. [5]			kě		can; may; able to			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A5i"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">可的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A569"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">可的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%8F%AF"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">可在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=93"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">可在RTK：can</span></a>	RTH
0089	哥	哥	Older Brother	10	The older brother is depicted here as a duplication of the char-<br>acter for can. It shouldn't take too much work to imagine him,<br>for whatever reason, as a can-can brother. [10]			gē		elder brother			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AD%F4"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">哥的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=ADF4"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">哥的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%93%A5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">哥在n词酷</span></a>・	RTH
0090	頂	顶	crest	11	The key word can refer to the summit or crest of a mountain,<br />but the crest of the head works better here. The immediate<br />image this conjures up is the head of a rooster with its comb<br />or a cockatoo with its crest feathers. And from there it is but a<br />short step to think of the punk hairstyles that imitate this look<br />by shaping the hair into a row of brightly colored spikes. So a<br />spike-head becomes a crest. [11]		(of hill)	dǐng	(гребень)	top, summit, peak; to carry on the head			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B3%BB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">頂的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B3BB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">頂的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E9%A1%B6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">顶在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E9%A1%B6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=94"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">頂在RTK：place on the head</span></a>	RTH
0091	乙	 乙	second	1	This character belongs to the same series of &quot;celestial stems&quot; as<br />that in frame 86 of the last lesson. The second person in line is<br />seated in what looks like a rocking chair (much better situated<br />than the fourth seat). [1]	Since this is also a pictograph of a <i>hook</i> or <i>fishhook</i>, let us take these as primitive meanings. Its shape will rarely be quite the same as that of the character. When it appears at the bottom of another primitive, it is straightened out, almost as if the weight of the upper element had bent it out of shape:𠃊&nbsp;&nbsp;<br />When it appears to the right of another element, the short horizontal line that gets the shape started is omitted, and the whole character is stretched out and narrowed ― all for reasons of space and aesthetics: 乚&nbsp;&nbsp;		yǐ		2nd Heavenly Stem; [fishguts]; 2nd (in order), second class, ethanol			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4A"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">乙的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A441"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">乙的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/ %E4%B9%99"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;"> 乙在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/ %E4%B9%99"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=71"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">乙在RTK：fish guts</span></a>	RTH
0092	子	子	child	3	This character is a pictograph of a child wrapped up in one of<br />those handy cocoons that Indian squaws fix to their backs to<br />carry around young children who cannot get around by them-<br />selves. (Incidentally, this is why English has taken over the<br />word &quot;papoose&quot; from the Algonquin language to refer to the<br />device itself.) The first stroke is like a wee head popping out for<br />air; the second shows the body and legs all wrapped up; and the<br />final stroke shows the arms sticking out to cling to the mother's<br />neck. [3]	As a primitive, this character retains the meaning of <i>child</i>, though you might imagine a little older <i>child</i>, able to run around and get into more mischief.		zǐ		1st Earthly Branch; RAT; [11:00pm - 1:00am]; child; offspring, seed			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4l"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">子的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A46C"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">子的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%AD%90"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">子在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=95"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">子在RTK：child</span></a>	RTH
0093	孔	孔	cavity	4	A cavity is really just a small hole, but the first thing we think<br />of when we hear the word is that little pothole that shows up in<br />a diseased tooth. The Chinese may not use the character in this<br />sense, but what's to stop us?.<br />Probably the one thing most children fear more than anything<br />else is the dentist's chair. Can you remember the first time as a<br />child you saw your dentist hold an x-ray up to the light and pro-<br />nounce the ominous word &quot;cavity&quot;? Even though you were not<br />likely to know that the word meant that you have an extra hole<br />in your head until you were much older, it did not take long<br />before the sound got associated with the drill and that row of<br />shiny hooks the dentist uses to torture people who are too small<br />to fight back. [4]			kǒng		opening, hole, vent, aperture			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4%D5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">孔的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A4D5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">孔的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%AD%94"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">孔在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=96"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">孔在RTK：cavity</span></a>	RTH
0094	吼	吼	to roar	7	A mouth and a cavity combine to create the character for roar.<br>It shouldn't tax your memory banks too much to think back<br>to how you howled and roared the first time you had a cavity<br>drilled by a doctor poking around inside your mouth with his<br>weapons of dental destruction. [7]			hǒu		roar (of a lion), to howl			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A7q"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">吼的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A771"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">吼的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%90%BC"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">吼在n词酷</span></a>・	RTH
0095	了	了	—ed	2	This character is most frequently used as a grammatical par-<br>ticle. Since it can indicate completion of an action, it is here<br>assigned the key word -ed. Learn this character by returning<br>to frame 92 and the image given there. The only difference is<br>that the "arms" have been left off (actually, only tuck-ed inside).<br>Thus a child with its arms wrapp-ed up into the backsack is the<br>picture of a job successfully complet-ed.<br>Incidentally, you should be aware that this grammatical par-<br>ticle has generated a great deal of debate among specialists. [2]			le		[completed action marker]			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4F"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">了的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A446"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">了的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E4%BA%86"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">了在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=97"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">了在RTK：complete</span></a>	RTH
0096	女	女	Woman	3	You have probably seen somewhere the form of a squatting<br>woman drawn behind this character, with two legs at the bot-<br>tom, two arms (the horizontal line) and the head poking out<br>the top. A little farfetched, until you draw the character<br>and feel the grace and flow of the three simple strokes.<br>Remembering the character is easy; being able to write it<br>beautifully is another thing. [3]	The primitive meaning is the same: <i>woman</i>. It will help if you have a particular person in mind.		nǚ		female; woman			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4k"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">女的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A46B"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">女的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%A5%B3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">女在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=98"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">女在RTK：woman</span></a>	RTH
0097	好	好	good	6	The sense of good carried by this character is very broad in<br>range. And what better image for this than a woman holding<br>her child. [6]			hǎo		good, well, fine			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A6n"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">好的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A66E"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">好的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%A5%BD"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">好在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=99"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">好在RTK：fond</span></a>	RTH
0098	如	如	to be like	6	Pardon us if we revert to the venerable old Dr. Freud again,<br />but his eye for symbolism is often helpful to appreciate things<br />that more earthy imaginations once accepted more freely but<br />that we have learned to cover over with a veneer of etiquette.<br />For instance, from ancient times things like the mouth of a<br />cave have served as natural ritual substitutes for the opening<br />through which a woman gives birth. This is just one example of<br />the way in which one thing can be like another in a metaphori-<br />cal sense and can therefore help unlock the hidden meanings of<br />ritual and symbolism. [6]			rú		to be like, be as good as; to comply with; if, as			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A6p"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">如的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A670"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">如的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%A6%82"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">如在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=100"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">如在RTK：likeness</span></a>	RTH
0099	母	 母	Mother	5	Look closely at this character and you will find the outline of<br />the character for woman in it, the second stroke of which has<br />been expanded to make space for the two breasts that help a<br />mother be a mother. [5]	As a primitive, this character will take on the added meaning of <i>breasts</i> in accord with the explanation given above. Take careful note of the fact that the form is altered slightly when this character serves as a primitive, the two dots joining together to form a longer stroke: 毌. An example follows in the next frame.		mǔ		mother			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A5%C0"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">母的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A5C0"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">母的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/ %E6%AF%8D"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;"> 母在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/ %E6%AF%8D"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=101"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">母在RTK：mama</span></a>	RTH
0100	貫	贯	to pierce	11	If one is asked to think of associations for the word pierce,<br />among the first to come to mind is that of piercing one's ears<br />to hold earrings, a quite primitive form of self-mutilation that<br />has survived into the twenty-first century. The character here<br />is read, top to bottom: mother . . . oyster. All you need to do is<br />imagine piercing an ear so that it can hold a mother-of-pearl<br />you have just wrested from an oyster. [11]			guàn		to pierce, pass through; to string together			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B3e"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">貫的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B365"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">貫的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%B4%AF"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">贯在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%B4%AF"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=102"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">貫在RTK：pierce</span></a>	RTH
0101	兄	兄	Elder Brother	5	The difference between &quot;older brother&quot; (frame 89) and elder<br />brother is ever so slight in English, the latter sounding just a bit<br />less colloquial. The same is the case in Chinese.<br />By now characters like this one should &quot;look like&quot; something<br />to you even though it is more of an &quot;ideogram&quot; than a &quot;picto-<br />graph.&quot; The large mouth on top and the human legs below almost<br />jump off the page as a caricature of elder brother, the one with<br />the big mouth (or if you prefer a kinder image, the one who &quot;has<br />the say&quot; among all the children). [5]	As a primitive this character will take the meaning of <i>teenager</i>, in accord with the familiar image of the big <i>mouth</i> and the gangling, clumsy <i>legs</i>.		xiōng		elder brother			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A5S"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">兄的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A553"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">兄的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%85%84"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">兄在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=103"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">兄在RTK：elder brother</span></a>	RTH
0102	克	克	to overcome	7	In this frame we get a chance to use the character we just learned<br>in its primitive meaning of teenager. The needle on top indicates<br>one of the major problems confronting the teenager growing<br>up in today's world: drugs. Many of them will fall under the<br>shadow of the needle at some time during those tender years.<br>Only when a whole generation rises up and declares, "We Shall<br>Overcome," will the needle cease to hang over their heads as it<br>does in this character. [7]			kè		to subdue; to restrain, overcome			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A7J"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">克的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A74A"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">克的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%85%8B"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">克在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=104"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">克在RTK：overcome</span></a>	RTH
0103	小	小	small	3		The primitive meaning remains the same, <i>small</i>. Written above a horizontal line, its form is slightly altered, the last two strokes turning inwards like this: ⺌.		xiǎo		small, tiny; insignificant			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4p"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">小的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A470"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">小的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%B0%8F"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">小在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=105"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">小在RTK：little</span></a>	RTH
0104	少	少	few	4				shǎo		few, less; inadequate			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4%D6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">少的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A4D6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">少的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%B0%91"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">少在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=106"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">少在RTK：few</span></a>	RTH
0105	吵	吵	noisy	7	You might think that noisy should be associated with many peo-<br />ple talking at once, but the idea in this character is much more<br />philosophical than that: What happens when things get noisy<br />is that peopled vocabulary shrinks to a more neolithic level the<br />higher the volume is turned up. And so it is that noisy becomes<br />associated with the very few things a mouth can say when it<br />is talking loudly. Try to picture people quoting Shakespeare to<br />each other in a shouting match, and you will see how right this<br />character is. [7]			chǎo		noisy; to make a racket, disturb; to squabble			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A7n"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">吵的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A76E"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">吵的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%90%B5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">吵在n词酷</span></a>・	RTH
0106	大	大	large	3	Here we have a simple pictograph of a person taking up the<br />space of an entire character and giving it the sense of large. It<br />should not be too hard to locate the two legs and outstretched<br />arms. [3]	When used as a primitive, this character needs a different meaning, since the element representing the human person will come up later. Therefore, this shape will become a <i>large dog</i> or, if you prefer, a <i>St. Bernard dog</i>. In frame 225 we will explain why this choice was made.		dà		big, great, large, vast			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4j"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">大的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A46A"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">大的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%A4%A7"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">大在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=107"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">大在RTK：large</span></a>	RTH
0107	尖	尖	tip	6	The tip this character refers to is the tapered point of something<br />like a pen or a pagoda. The composition of the elements, small<br />and large, is perfectly suited to the image of a small tip at the<br />end of something larger. [6]		, point	jiān		point, pinnacle; pointed, sharp; shrewd			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A6y"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">尖的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A679"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">尖的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%B0%96"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">尖在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=2903"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">尖在RTK：sharp point</span></a>	RTH
0108	夕	夕	Evening	3	Just as the word evening adds a touch of formality or roman-<br />ticism to the ordinary word "night" so the character for eve-<br />ning takes the ordinary looking moon in the night sky and has<br />a cloud pass over it—partially hiding it and hence eliminating<br />the final stroke.			xī [普], xì [國]		evening, sunset; (dusk =&nbsp;&nbsp;xì )			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4i"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">夕的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A469"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">夕的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%A4%95"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">夕在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=109"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">夕在RTK：evening</span></a>	RTH
0109	多	多	many	6	"Many moons ago," begins much of Amerindian folklore—a<br>colorful way of saying "Once upon a time" and a great deal of<br>help for remembering this character. Here we have two moons.<br>(three of them would take us back to the beginning of time,<br>which is further than we want to go.) [6]			duō		many, much, a lot of, numerous, multi-			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A6h"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">多的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A668"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">多的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%A4%9A"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">多在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=108"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">多在RTK：many</span></a>	RTH
0110	夠	够	enough	11	"Enough is enough." Who has not been scolded with these<br>words in their youth by a parent or teacher who has run out of<br>patience! Now if you can conjure up the memory of a particular<br>time you yourself blasted those words out at someone who wal<br>trying your patience, imagine that short sentence becoming an<br>uncontrollable obsession, as you walk off into the sunset mut-<br>tering it many times&nbsp;&nbsp;-- over and over and over again. [11]			gòu		to reach, be enough; adequate, sufficient			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B0%F7"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">夠的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B0F7"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">夠的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%A4%9F"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">够在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%A4%9F"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・	RTH
0111	外	外	Outside	5	On the left, the primitive for evening, and on the right,-<br>for the magic wand. Now, as every magician worth his abraca-<br>dabra knows, bringing your magic wand out into the evening<br>air makes your magic much more powerful than if you were to<br>stay indoors. Hence, evening and magic wand takes you natu-<br>rally outside. [5]			wài		outside, external; foreign; unofficial			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A5~"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">外的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A57E"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">外的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%A4%96"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">外在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=111"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">外在RTK：outside</span></a>	RTH
0112	名	名	a Name	6	Perhaps you have heard of the custom, still preserved in certain<br />African tribes, of a father creeping into the tent or hut of his<br />newborn child on the night of the child's birth, to whisper into<br />its ear the name he has chosen for it, before making his choice<br />public. It is an impressive "naming" custom and fits in tidily<br />with the way this character is constructed: evening • • • mouth. At<br />evening time, a mouth pronounces the name that will accom-<br />pany one throughout life. [6]			míng		name; title, rank			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A6W"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">名的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A657"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">名的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%90%8D"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">名在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=112"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">名在RTK：name</span></a>	RTH
0113	厚	厚	thick	9	When we refer to someone as thick-skinned or thickheaded,<br>we are often quick to add -- even if only under our breath --<br>something about their upbringing. Perhaps it is because deep<br>down we cherish the belief that by nature people are basically<br>tender and sensitive.<br>Be that as it may, the Chinese character for thick depicts a<br>child abandoned out on the wild cliffs, exposed to the heat of the<br>sun and thus doomed to develop a head and skin as thick as the<br>parent who left it there. [9]			hòu		thick (for flat things); substantial, generous			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%ABp"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">厚的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AB70"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">厚的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%8E%9A"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">厚在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=125"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">厚在RTK：thick</span></a>	RTH
0114	石	石	stone	5	With a mouth under cliff, what else could we have here but the entrance to a secret cavern, before which a great stone has been rolled so that none may enter? Perhaps it is the hiding place where Ali Baba and his band of thieves have stored their treasures, in which case that magic word known to every school child who ever delighted in the tales of the Arabian Nights should be enough to push the stone aside. But take care—the cliff is steep, and one slip will send you tumbling down into the ravine below.<br />This is the first of two occasions (for the other, see frame 902) on which the second stroke in cliff will reach over slightly to the right beneath the horizontal stroke. If you think of the edge jutting outwards (in keeping with the story above), the problem should be taken care of. [5]	The <i>stone</i> is a quite common primitive element, which is not restricted to great boulders but is used for <i>pebbles</i> or <i>rocks</i> of any size or shape.		shí		rock; stone; mineral			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A5%DB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">石的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A5DB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">石的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%9F%B3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">石在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=113"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">石在RTK：stone</span></a>	RTH
0115	砂	砂	Gravel	9	In this character a few stones take on the meaning of gravel. Imagine ordering a wheelbarrow of stones from your local quarry and having them dump an entire truckload on your garden path. Imagine how annoyed you would be: "I said a few stones, a little gravel for my walkway—not a blooming moun­tainside!"			shā		pebbles, gravel, sand; gritty			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AC%E2"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">砂的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=ACE2"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">砂的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%A0%82"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">砂在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=117"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">砂在RTK：sand</span></a>	RTH
0116	妙	妙	wonderful	7	primitive for woman is on the left (there and at the bottom of another primitive is where you will always find her), and to the right the element for few. When we refer to a woman as wonderful, we mean to praise her as the sort of person we meet but few of and far between. [7]			miào		wonderful, excellent; clever			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A7%AE"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">妙的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A7AE"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">妙的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%A6%99"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">妙在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=123"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">妙在RTK：exquisite</span></a>	RTH
0117	肖	肖	to resemble	7	The word resemble should suggest, among other things, a son who resembles his father. A "chip off the old block" is the way we often put it, but the character is more simple. It speaks of a small bit of flesh. [7]	When this character is used as a primitive, its meaning changes to <i>sparks</i> or <i>candle</i>.		xiào		to resemble, be like; resembling			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A8v"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">肖的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A876"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">肖的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%82%96"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">肖在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=114"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">肖在RTK：resemblance</span></a>	leech RTH
0118	削	削	to peel	9	For want of a kitchen knife, you decide to peel an apple with a saber. You strike a warrior's pose, toss the apple into the air, and with a guttural shout, brandish your trusty saber in the air with lightning speed. Can you see the sparks flying and the peelings falling to the ground? [9]			xiāo&nbsp;&nbsp;(also: xuē [普], xuè [國])		to peel, pare, whittle; to scrape			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%ABd"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">削的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AB64"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">削的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%89%8A"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">削在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=118"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">削在RTK：plane</span></a>	RTH
0119	光	光	Ray	6	The fourth stroke that separates them is added for reasons of aesthetics. (If that doesn't make sense, try writing the character without it and see how ugly the results look, even to your begin­ner's eye.)<br />Now if you have wondered what those little particles of &quot;dust&quot; are that dance around in the light rays that come through the window and fall on your desk, try imagining them as small and disembodied human legs, and you should have no trouble with this character. [6]			guāng		light; ray; brightness, lustre; glory			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A5%FA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">光的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A5FA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">光的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%85%89"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">光在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=119"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">光在RTK：ray</span></a>	RTH
0120	太	太	overly	4	All right, you are wondering, overly "what"? Given the legend­ary temperament of the St Bernard dog, we may suppose that it is being overly affectionate. Hence the large drop of slobber— yuck. [4]			tài		too; extremly; highest; senior			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4%D3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">太的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A4D3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">太的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%A4%AA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">太在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=120"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">太在RTK：plump</span></a>	RTH
0121	省	省	to economize	9	When we decide it's time to economize, we take it for granted that we will need to trim back our appetites a bit. If one's eyes can be too big for one's stomach, they can also be too big for ones pocketbook. Or, as this character suggests, too many. Imagine yourself with eyes all over your head, so that in order to economize you will have to pluck most of them out until only a few remain. [9]			shěng		to save, economize, use sparingly; province			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AC%D9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">省的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=ACD9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">省的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%9C%81"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">省在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=124"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">省在RTK：focus</span></a>	RTH
0122	奇	奇	strange	8	The elements we are given to work with here are St. Bernard dog&nbsp;&nbsp;and can. Lots of phrases pop to mind to attach these words to the keyword but they end up being too abstract because of the word can.<br>It is helpful in such cases (and there will be a number of them as we go along) to stick closely to the more basic elements, in this case, mouth and nails. Now all we need do is create a fictitious "Strange but true" Column in the Sunday funnies, featuring a St.Bernard's dog whose mouth has been sealed shut with a <br>row of nails because he was hitting the brandy keg around his neck too hard. [8]			qí		strange, odd, weird; unexpected			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A9_"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">奇的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A95F"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">奇的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%A5%87"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">奇在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=126"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">奇在RTK：strange</span></a>	RTH
0123	川	川	Stream	3	in this frame. The reason there are no wavy lines is simply that the Chinese characters no longer use them. [3]	As a primitive, this character will denote a <i>stream</i> or a <i>flood</i>. Note, however, that there are certain small changes in the writing of the element, depending on where it appears rela­tive to other elements:<br />on the left, it is written)&nbsp;&nbsp;on the top, it is written on the bottom, it is written		chuān		stream, river; Sichuan (abbrev.)			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4t"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">川的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A474"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">川的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%B7%9D"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">川在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=127"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">川在RTK：stream</span></a>	RTH
0124	州	州	a state	6	Here we see drops of land (little islets) rising up out of a stream^ creating a kind of sandbar or breakwater. Ever wonder how the state line is drawn between states separated by a river? If there were little drops of land as in the character, there'd be nothing to it. [6]		(in the US)	zhōu		state, province			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A6{"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">州的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A67B"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">州的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%B7%9E"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">州在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=128"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">州在RTK：state</span></a>	RTH
0125	順	顺	to obey	12	In the language of the primitives, this character would read stream • • • head. This turns out to be convenient for remember­ing its meaning of obey. Either one obeys the person who is head of an organization or else obeys by following the stream of opinion ("current" practice, we call it). Both these senses come together in this character. [12]			shùn		to obey, submit to, follow			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B6%B6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">順的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B6B6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">順的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E9%A1%BA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">顺在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E9%A1%BA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=129"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">順在RTK：obey</span></a>	RTH
0126	水	水	Water	4	This character, which looks a bit like a snowflake, is actually a pictograph of water―not any particular body of water or movement of water, but simply the generic name for water. Should you have any difficulty remembering it, simply think of a walking stick being dropped vertically into the water, sending droplets out in all four directions. Then all you need to learn is how to write it in proper order. [4]	As a primitive, this character can keep its form, or it can be written with three drops to the left of another primitive, like this:氵 This latter, as we will see, is far more common. It can also be written stiffly, in five strokes, as 氺 in which case we will take it to mean a <i>snowflake</i>. An example will fol­low shortly. Finally, as we will see later in frame 380, in the printed form, the <i>snowflake</i> element can be straightened out to give&nbsp;&nbsp;•		shuǐ		water; liquid			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4%F4"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">水的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A4F4"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">水的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%B0%B4"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">水在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=130"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">水在RTK：water</span></a>	RTH
0127	永	永	Eternity	5	This character also uses the full form of water, though its meaning seems to have nothing at all to do with it. Remember what William Blake said about seeing &quot;infinity in a grain of sand and eternity in an hour&quot;? Well, reading this character from top to bottom, we see &quot;eternity in a drop of water?<br />Note how the introduction of the drop requires that the first stroke of water begin with a short horizontal &quot;starter line.&quot; Try leaving it out and you will see how reasonable this is. [5]			yǒng		forever, always; perpetual(ly)			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A5%C3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">永的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A5C3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">永的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%B0%B8"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">永在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=132"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">永在RTK：eternity</span></a>	RTH
0128	求	求	to request	7	Let the key word suggest a formal invitation that begins, "Mr.<br>and Mrs. Snow request the honor of your presence at the wed-<br>ding of their beloved daughter Snowflake to Dripdropy the son<br>of Mr. and Mrs. Leak. • ••" The only stroke remaining to account<br>for is the one that runs between and "unites" the happy couple<br>together until death (or sunlight) do them part. [7]			qiú		to request, beseech, demand			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A8D"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">求的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A844"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">求的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%B1%82"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">求在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=934"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">求在RTK：request</span></a>	RTH
0129	泉	泉	a Spring&nbsp;&nbsp;[ie: Well]	9	Call to mind the image of a fresh, bubbling spring of watery<br />and you will probably notice how the top of the spring you are<br />thinking of, the part where the &quot;bubbling&quot; goes on, is all white.<br />Happily, the white is just where it should be, at the top, and the<br />water is at the bottom. [9]	We will keep this image of a <i>spring</i> when using this character as a primitive, but not without first drawing attention to a slight change that distinguishes the primitive from the character. The final four strokes (the element for <i>water</i>) are abbreviated to the three small <i>drops</i> that we learned earlier as the character for <i>small</i>, giving us:		quán		fountain, spring			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%ACu"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">泉的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AC75"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">泉的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%B3%89"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">泉在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=133"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">泉在RTK：spring</span></a>	RTH
0130	原	原	flatlands	10	&quot;The flatlands are alive, with the sound of muuusic... •&quot; Well,<br />tìiey are in this case anyway, though the setting is a rather grisly<br />one. Watch Schwester Maria as she skips along merrily, dodging<br />in and out of the springs that pop up like landmines until she<br />comes to the edge of a cliff and loses her balance. Listen to her<br />words echoing as she falls and this character should be yours<br />forever. [10]			yuán		prairie, plain, grassland; primary, original			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AD%EC"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">原的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=ADEC"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">原的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%8E%9F"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">原在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=134"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">原在RTK：meadow</span></a>	RTH
0131	願	愿	a Wish	19	Flatlands and a head are all we are given to work with in the character for wish. Since the key word already suggests some­thing like a formal request made of some higher power, let us imagine a gigantic Wizard-of-Oz head located in the middle of the üowery flatlands we saw in the last frame. Then just picture people kneeling before it, each with a wish they hope to have fulfilled. (The scarecrow wanted brains, the lion courage, and the tin man a heart. What about you?) [19]			yuàn		to desire, want; hope; wish			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%C4@"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">願的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=C440"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">願的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%84%BF"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">愿在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%84%BF"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=135"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">願在RTK：petition</span></a>	RTH
0132	沖	冲	to wash away	7	Imagine a few innocent looking drops of water creeping up on you to wash you away out into the middle of the ocean. Impossible, you say? Not if drops of water have drifted in from the Bermuda Triangle where they have had a lot of practice at washing away everything from yachts to ocean liners. In any case, this character gives a completely new meaning to the dan­ger of "drowning in a teaspoonful of water? [7]			chōng	??a foreigner frantically trying to wash away china	to rinse, steep, wash away; to clash, collide			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A8R"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">沖的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A852"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">沖的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%86%B2"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">冲在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%86%B2"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=138"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">沖在RTK：open sea</span></a>	RTH
0133	泳	泳	to swim	8	On the left we see again the primitive for drops of water. To the right, we see the character for eternity. Knowing how much children like to swim, what could be a better image of an eter-nity of bliss than an endless expanse of water to swim in with­out a care in the world? 0134	洲	洲	Continent	9	If states are separated by smaller bodies of waterf continents are separated by great oceans. The drops of water to the left of state fill this function. 0135	沼	沼	Marsh	8	Unlike the flatlands with their cliffs, the marshlands are low and near a source of water that feeds them until they get soggy through and through. Why certain land becomes marsh is probably due to the fact that it feels thirsty, and so tries its best to summon the water over to its side. But, like so many tempta­tions, the last state of the victim is worse than the first. Hence the slushy marsh. [8]			zhǎo		pool, pond; swamp			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AAh"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">沼的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AA68"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">沼的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%B2%BC"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">沼在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=137"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">沼在RTK：marsh</span></a>	RTH
0136	沙	沙	Sand	7	Learn this character in connection with that for gravel from frame 115. The difference between sand and gravel is one your feet know very well from walking along the beach. The sand is finer and the gravel cuts into the skin. Hence the element for stone figures prominently in gravel, whereas that for water (which, after all has done the work of grinding away at the stone for centuries) shows up here in sand. [7]			shā		sand; powder; granulated; hoarse			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A8F"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">沙的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A846"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">沙的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%B2%99"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">沙在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=2296"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">沙在RTK：grains of sand</span></a>	RTH
0137	江	江	Yangtze	6	China's equivalent to the Mighty Mississippi is the Yangtze. In fact, the character in this frame, although genetically meaning river, can be used as an abbreviation for the Yangtze, much the same as the "River" of "Ole Man River" is for those who live on water and an I-beam. Actually, the heavy metal I-beam is being launched as a raft by some mentally challenged Huck Finn hop			jiāng		the Yangtze; large river			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A6%BF"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">江的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A6BF"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">江的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%B1%9F"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">江在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=139"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">江在RTK：creek</span></a>	RTH
0138	汁	汁	Juice	5	st any ordinary juice, but a brew of water and nee-dies. Its distinctively sharp taste cuts your thirst by distracting it with excruciating pain as the juice passes down your throat. 0139	潮	潮	Tide	15	To get the meaning of the key word tide, just think of the ebb and flow of a dynasty's fortunes―literally. Watch as all the wealth of the empire flows into the emperor's court at high tide, and note how everything there empties out back into the popu­lace when it is at low tide.			cháo		tide, flow, current, movement			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%BC%E9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">潮的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=BCE9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">潮的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%BD%AE"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">潮在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=141"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">潮在RTK：tide</span></a>	RTH
0140	源	源	source	13	With the advice of the last frame in mind, it is easy to see water гпа flatlands in this character for source. Both in its etymology (it has a common parent with the word &quot;surge&quot;) and in popular usage, source suggests the place water comes from. In this char­acter, it is under the flatlands, where we earlier saw it breaking the surface in those bubbly little springs. 0141	活	活	lively	9	When we speak of a lively personality or a lively party, we immediately think of a lot of chatter. This character depicts the idea of lively by having tongues babble and splash around like flowing water. 0142	消	消	to extinguish	10	Among the many things water can do is help extinguish fires, and that is just what we have here. First of all, take the water at the left as the drops of water that are used to depict water in general. In the best of all possible worlds, the most efficient way to extinguish a fire would be to see that each drop of water hits one spark of the conflagration. An unthinkable bit of Utopian fire fighting, you say to yourself, but helpful for assigning this key word its primitives. [10]			xiāo		vanish, disappear, melt away			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AE%F8"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">消的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AEF8"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">消的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%B6%88"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">消在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=144"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">消在RTK：extinguish</span></a>	leech RTH
0143	況	况	Situation	8	What we have here is "an awkward situation." The teenager of the family has used up all the water for his bath, and there is nothing left to make tea. What the hey, its all in the fimüly, you say, and rather than throw out the bathwater, you decide to keep the situation secret and make the tea anyway. Little do the guests know, as they sip their tea daintily, that the tea is not the only thing in the hot water. [8]			kuàng		situation, condition; furthermore			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AAp"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">況的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AA70"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">況的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%86%B5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">况在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%86%B5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=145"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">況在RTK：but of course</span></a>	RTH

0145	湖	湖	Lake	12	Rather than use the character for recklessly from frame 17 as a primitive element, let us take the elements one by one: water ...ancient.. .flesh. You have heard of legends of people being abandoned in the mountains when they had become too ancient to work. Well, here is a legend about people being set adrift in the waters of a stormy lake because their flesh had gotten too ancient to bear the burdens of life. [12]			hú		lake			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B4%F2"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">湖的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B4F2"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">湖的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%B9%96"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">湖在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=148"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">湖在RTK：lake</span></a>	RTH
0146	測	测	to fathom	12	Connoting the measurement of the depth of water, the keyword fathom begins with the water primitive. To its right, we see the character for rule (frame 84) which we learned in the sense of "gaming rules." Now when we measure the depth of water, we have to follow a different set of rules than those we use to measure the fish we pull out of it. We fathom it; that is, we mea­sure it in units of six feet. Picture yourself fathoming a body of water several hundred feet deep according to official тиЩ which stipulate that you must use a government-approved tape measure and avoid the use of electronic equipment. [12]		(fathom: a unit of length...)	cè		to conjecture, ponder; to estimate, predict, measure			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B4%FA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">測的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B4FA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">測的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%B5%8B"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">测在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%B5%8B"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=149"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">測在RTK：fathom</span></a>	RTH
0147	土	土	Soil	3	We don't like it any more than you do, but this character is not the pictograph it is trumped up to be: a mound of soil piled on the ground. All we can recommend is that you memorize it as it is. Anyway, it will be occurring with such frequency that you have almost no chance of forgetting it, even if you try. [3]	When this character is used as a primitive, the sense of <i>soil</i> is extended to that of <i>ground</i> because of its connection with the character for the same (frame 478). From there it also takes the added meanings of <i>dirt</i> and <i>land</i>.		tǔ		earth, dirt, soil; land			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4g"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">土的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A467"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">土的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%9C%9F"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">土在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=150"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">土在RTK：soil</span></a>	RTH
0148	均	均	to equal	7	The idea of making things equal is pictured here at its most basic: land reform. It provides soil in uniform portions to every­one. To help with the association, we may recall the famous line of Napoleon the Pig in George OrwelFs 1984: &quot;All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others.&quot; Picture one of those suspicious land reforms going on in the barnyard and led by one group of animals (the pigs) who apportion the largest parcels to themselves and ration out among everyone else uniform slivers of land too small to live on. [7]			jūn		equal, even, fair, uniform; equally			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A7%A1"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">均的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A7A1"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">均的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%9D%87"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">均在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=160"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">均在RTK：level</span></a>	RTH

0150	填	填	to fill in	13	When you fill in a form, it is expected that the information be ше said, most people are less concerned with foil and true disclosure than with protecting their privacy, whereas those who make the forms are often more interested in getting the dirt on them. If you can imagine filling in some of the blanks with shovelfuls of actual dirt to give them what they want, you wm keep the metaphor more concrete. 0151	吐	吐	to spit	6	We have here a rather small mouth (it is always compressed when set on the left) next to a much larger piece of dirt It is not hard to imagine what you might do if you got a mouth full of dirt As least we know what we would do: spit it out as fast and far as we could! 0152	哇	哇	Waaah!	9	The shrill cries of a bawling infant can be more piercing than any noise an adult makes, which is why they are so hard to ignore. In this character, we see the sounds of that cry, Waah!, likened to a mouth spitting out bricks to shatter the silence of our sleep. [9]			wā		[sound of child's crying]			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%ABz"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">哇的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AB7A"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">哇的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%93%87"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">哇在n词酷</span></a>・	RTH
0153	寸	寸	Chinese Inch	3	This character stands for a small measurement used prior to the metric system, a little less than 1V3 English inches in length and one-tenth of a Chinese foot (which we will meet later, in Book 2). The character, appropriately, represents one drop of a ten (with a hook!). [3]			cùn		the width of a person's thumb			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4o"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">寸的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A46F"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">寸的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%AF%B8"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">寸在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=45"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">寸在RTK：measurement</span></a>	RTH
0154	封	封	to seal	9	Think of the key word seal in connection with a letter you have written and are preparing to close. Instead of using the tradi­tional hot wax to seal the document, you glue a brick on the outside一a love letter swab (sealed with a brick). A romantic thought, but the postage will bankrupt you. [9]			fēng		to seal; envelope			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AB%CA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">封的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=ABCA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">封的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%B0%81"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">封在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=156"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">封在RTK：seal</span></a>	RTH
0155	寺	寺	Buddhist Temple	6	You have heard of people "attaching" themsdves to a particular sect? Here is your chance to take that metaphor literally and imagine some fellow walking into a Buddhist temple with a fervent resolve to attach himsdf to the place. Since there is plenty of unused land around the precincts, he simply picks out a suitable patch, brushes the soles of his feet with glue, steps down firmly, and so joins the Buddhist temple as a "permanent member." [6]			sì		Tibetan Buddhist temple			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A6x"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">寺的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A678"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">寺的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%AF%BA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">寺在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=158"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">寺在RTK：buddhist temple</span></a>	RTH
0156	時	时	Time	10	"What is time?” asked St. Augustin in his memoirs, “Ask me not, and I know. Ask me, and I cannot tell you." Here we have a curious answer to that perennial riddle. Time is a sun riling over a Buddhist temple. It sounds almost like a Zen kōan whose repetition might yield some deep secret to the initiated. At any rate, imagining a monk seated in meditation pondering it might help us remember the character. [10]			shí		time, hour, o'clock; when; tense [grammar]			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AE%C9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">時的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AEC9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">時的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%97%B6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">时在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%97%B6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=159"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">時在RTK：time</span></a>	RTH
0157	火	火	Fire	4	Just as sitting before a fire enlivens the imagination and lets you see almost anything you want to in the flames, this character is so simple it lets you see almost any sort of fire you want to see. It no longer makes a good pictograph, but we invite you to take a pencil and paper and play with the form一first writing it as shown below and then adding lines here and there一to see what you can come up with. Everything from matchbooks to ciga­rette lighters to volcanic eruptions to the destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah have been found here. No doubt you, too, will find something interesting to bend your memory around these four simple strokes. [4]	Although the generic meaning of <i>fire</i> can be carried over as a primitive meaning, it is usually best to keep to the mean­ing of <i>flames</i> or <i>fireplace</i>. Another primitive element for fire, based on this one, is written 灬 and will mean <i>cooking fire</i>.		huǒ		fire, flame; rage			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4%F5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">火的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A4F5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">火的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%81%AB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">火在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=161"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">火在RTK：fire</span></a>	RTH
0158	灰	灰	ashes	6	The character for ashes naturally includes the primitive for fire, or more specifically, a fireplace. Now what do you do with that bucket of ashes you have just cleaned out of the fireplace? You strap it to your belt and walk around with it by your side until the wind scatters them, with distributive justice, over everyone else's property. [6]			huī		ash, dust			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A6%C7"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">灰的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A6C7"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">灰的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%81%B0"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">灰在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=168"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">灰在RTK：ashes</span></a>	RTH
0159	煩	烦	vexed	13	When people are vexed about something, they often refer to themselves as "really burned" about it. In this character, the per­son head is on fire) raising the metaphor to new heights. [13]			fán		troubled, vexed, annoyed, fed up			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B7%D0"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">煩的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B7D0"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">煩的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%83%A6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">烦在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%83%A6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=163"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">煩在RTK：anxiety</span></a>	RTH
0160	炎	炎	Inflammation	8	A fire belongs in the fireplace, not over it. When the fire spreads to the rest of the house, we have an inflammation of the house. As with any inflammation—including those that attack our bodies一the danger is always that it might spread if not checked. This is the sense behind the reduplication of the element for fire, one atop the other. [8]			yán		flame; inflammation; -itis			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AA%A2"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">炎的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AAA2"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">炎的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%82%8E"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">炎在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=162"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">炎在RTK：inflammation</span></a>	RTH
0161	淡	淡	thin	11	You may not think there is such a thing as thin water or thin fire, but when you mix fire and water, the one does make the other thin. When you see this key word, think not of "slender" but of thin in the sense of pale, diluted, or weak. Paint thinner makes paint thin in this way (though we do not recommend mixing it vnthfire9 unless you want a real inflammation). [11]		(pale, diluted, weak)	dàn		weak, thin, watery; bland, insipid			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B2H"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">淡的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B248"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">淡的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%B7%A1"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">淡在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=164"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">淡在RTK：thin</span></a>	RTH
0162	災	灾	Disaster	7	Of all of nature's disasters, this character picks out two of the worst floods dLTìdfires. To recall the disposition of the elements, think of nature's solution to nature's own problem: a great flood pouring down over a great forest fire. [7]			zāi		disaster, calamity, catastrophe			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A8a"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">災的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A861"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">災的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%81%BE"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">灾在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%81%BE"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=167"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">災在RTK：disaster</span></a>	RTH
0163	照	照	to illuminate	13	Although the range of possible meanings that the character for illuminate can have is about as rich as the connotations of the English word, we need to focus on just one of them: to make something obscure evident. If you glaze a pot and put it into the oven to &quot;ère&quot; it, you in fact illuminate it. Hence the character for illuminate makes a connection between the character for evident and the primitive element for cooking fire. [13]			zhào		light up, illuminate, shine, reflect; photograph			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B7%D3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">照的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B7D3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">照的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%85%A7"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">照在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=170"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">照在RTK：illuminate</span></a>	RTH
0164	魚	鱼	a Fish	11	Breaking down this character give us three elements, which we list in the order of their writing: hound up... rice field... cooking fire. Not much to work with at first sight. But we can join them together by thinking of a three-part story: first a fish is caught and bound up on a line with its unfortunate schoolmates; when the fisherman gets home, he cuts off the head and tosses it, with the entrails, out into the rice field for fertilizer; and the rest he sets in a skillet over a cookingfire for his supper. [11]			yú		fish			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B3%BD"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">魚的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B3BD"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">魚的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E9%B1%BC"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">鱼在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E9%B1%BC"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=171"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">魚在RTK：fish</span></a>	RTH
0165	漁	渔	Fishing	14	To the story we have just made about fish, this character for the profession of fishing adds yet another element before the others: namely the water, where the fish was happily at home before being caught, disemboweled, and eaten. Be sure to get a clear image of the water when you put it all together to create a picture of fìshing. [14]		(activity)	yú		to fish; fishing; to seize, filch			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%BA%AE"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">漁的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=BAAE"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">漁的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%B8%94"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">渔在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%B8%94"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=172"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">漁在RTK：fishing</span></a>	RTH
0166	堯	尧	Yao	12	This character, used as a family name, is best associated with the legendary sage king Yao, who lived around 2300 все and became a model for rulers in ancient China. One fact about this king, which can help us remember the writing of the charac­ter, is that he is said to have invented the board game of Go as a way to sharpen the brain of his dim-witted son. Here we see the son as simply a pair of human legs (no brain attached), playing Go on the floor with little clumps of dirt (instead of the customary stones). [12]	Used as a primitive, this character will be associated with the image of that unforgettable character in the Charlie Brown cartoon strips, <i>Pigpen</i>. Or, if you prefer, some par­ticularly memorable slob from your high-school days. The association should be obvious: <i>dirt</i>, <i>dirt</i> everywhere and a <i>pair of human legs</i>.		Yáo		Emperor Yao (2358 - 2258 BCE), an ancient sage			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B3%F3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">堯的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B3F3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">堯的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%B0%A7"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">尧在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%B0%A7"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=2095"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">堯在RTK：lofty（尭）</span></a>	RTH
0167	燒	烧	Fever	16	Picture little Pigpen as "running a fever." Can you see the fire chasing after him as he runs away, kicking up even more dust thaji he usually does? [16]			shāo		to burn; to bake, cook, roast; fever			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%BFN"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">燒的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=BF4E"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">燒的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%83%A7"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">烧在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%83%A7"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1200"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">燒在RTK：bake（焼）</span></a>	RTH
0168	曉	晓	Dawn	16	When you think of the dawn, imagine the sun rising up over the horizon, drenching the landscape in a golden color. Imagine little Pigpen sitting in the middle of a field, getting scrubbed			xiǎo	{From 日 (rì) 'sun' and 尧(堯) yáo phonetic.<br />2767 堯(S尧) [Yáo] (surname); a legendary emperor (2200 B.C.)<br />堯[尧] ¹Yáo n. 〈hist.〉 legendary founding emperor, a model of wisdom and virtue}<br />	dawn, daybreak; to know, tell			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%BE%E5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">曉的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=BEE5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">曉的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%99%93"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">晓在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%99%93"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1201"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">曉在RTK：daybreak（暁）</span></a>	leech RTH
