0169	里	里	a Li&nbsp;&nbsp;[measurement]	7	That's right—a li. Don't bother looking it up in your English dictionary; it's a Chinese unit of distance. One li is about a half kilometer. The character depicts how the measure came to be used. Atop we see the rice field, and below the element for land. Think of those four sections you see in the rice field (and which we made mention of when first we introduced the character in frame 14) as blocks of land. Thus, a land division based on the size of a rice field would be a li. [7]	To get a more concrete primitive meaning for this character, we shall refer to it as a <i>computer</i>, a meaning deriving from the character for <i>logic</i>, which we will meet in Lesson 12. To remember the meaning, it might help to think of the alter­native meaning of the primitive at the top: <i>brains</i>.		lǐ		unit of length (0.5 km); in, inside			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A8%BD"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">里的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A8BD"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">里的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E9%87%8C"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">里在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=173"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">里在RTK：ri</span></a>	RTH
0170	量	量	quantity	12	Think of quantity as having to do with measuring time and dis­tance, and the rest is simple: you have a quantity of time in the new day that begins with daybreak, and a quantity of distance in the rural li. [12]			liàng		quantity, capacity, amount			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B6q"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">量的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B671"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">量的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E9%87%8F"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">量在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=177"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">量在RTK：quantity</span></a>	RTH
0171	埋	埋	to bury	10	When we bury something (or someone, for that matter), we usually mean putting it under ground. Only here, we are bury­ing our beloved computer that has served us so well these past years. Behind us a choir chants the "Dies irae, dies ilia" and there is much wailing and grief among the bystanders as they pass by to shovel a little dirt into what will be its final resting place, r.i.p. [10]			mái		to bury, hide (away)			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AEI"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">埋的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AE49"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">埋的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%9F%8B"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">埋在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=179"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">埋在RTK：bury</span></a>	RTH
0172	黑	黑	black	12	Three frames ago we noted that it might help to think of the top part of the primitive for computer as brains. In this character you will see why. Note how the third stroke, ordinarily written as a single horizontal line, is here broken up into a pair of ani­mal horns right in the middle of the element. Think of this as a brain impaled (literally) on the horns of a dilemma.<br />That done, there is no problem with this character. Like most things electrical, a computer, too, can overheat, and often this happens because its brain is caught on the horns of a dilemma. Now look closely with your imaginative eye and you can see the horns sprouting out of the cpu and flames pouring out of the computer to char the keyboard, the monitor, and your desk a sooty black color. [12]			hēi		black; dark, evil; Heilongjiang Prv. (abbrev.)			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B6%C2"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">黑的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B6C2"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">黑的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E9%BB%91"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">黑在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=174"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">黑在RTK：black（黒）</span></a>	RTH
0173	點	点	Spot	16	When Madam Cheng tells fortunes, she not only tells you about the bright and beautiful things that await you but also about the dark, black misfortunes that menace your future like spots on a white background. Look into the crystal ball and you can see these black spots peppered here and there. And if you zoom in, you will see that each spot is a particular place that bodes ill for you. These are, literally, the black spots in your future. [16]			diǎn		dot, speck, spot; point; o'clock			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%C2I"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">點的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=C249"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">點的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%82%B9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">点在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%82%B9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=169"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">點在RTK：spot（点）</span></a>	RTH
0174	墨	墨	Black Ink	15	Besides meaning black ink, this character also appears in the word for an inked string that is pulled taut and snapped to mark a surface, much the same as a carpenter doing repair work in your home might use a chalked string. Here it is used to mark the dirt on a baseball diamond with a long, hpavy piece of string soaked in black ink. [15]			mò		ink; dark; Mexico (abbrev.)			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%BE%A5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">墨的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=BEA5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">墨的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%A2%A8"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">墨在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=175"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">墨在RTK：black ink</span></a>	RTH
0175	冒	冒	to risk	9	In order not to risk being identified, burglars often wear a mask or something else draped over their face. If you look closely at the character and "read off" the primitive elements, you will end up with a hood with two slits for the eyes. It would almost be worth trying one on if becoming a burglar didn't risk a lot more than just being recognized.<br />Even if you followed the explanation above, it bears repeating that the top four strokes are not the same as the primitive for sun or day or tongue wagging in the mouth. The difference is subtle but not to be ignored. [9]			mào		to risk, dare, attempt; to give off, emit			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AB_"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">冒的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AB5F"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">冒的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%86%92"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">冒在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=18"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">冒在RTK：risk</span></a>	RTH
0176	同	同	same	6	he primitives in this character show us one and mouth under a hood. Let us take the key word to connote the sense in which monks living in community share the same life, routine, food, and ideals. We might say they all have the same habits, includ­ing the &quot;habit&quot; they wear on their backs. Here we see the monk's cowl, drawn down over the eyes so that all you can see when you look at him is a mouth. But since monks also speak their prayers in common, it is but a short step to think of one mouth under a hood as the character for everything that is the same about monastic life. [6]	When this character is used as a primitive, it will mean <i>monks</i> dressed in a common habit.		tóng		same, similar, alike; in common, together with			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A6P"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">同的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A650"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">同的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%90%8C"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">同在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=180"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">同在RTK：same</span></a>	RTH
0177	洞	洞	cave	9	Early hermit-monks often lived in caves where they prayed and fasted for years on end. The one thing they could not do with­out was water. To fix this image, imagine a monk who has filled up his cave with water neck high, which makes it difficult to sleep but at least protects him from dehydration. [9]		(full character)	dòng		cave, hole			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AC}"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">洞的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AC7D"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">洞的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%B4%9E"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">洞在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=181"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">洞在RTK：den</span></a>	RTH
0178	向	向	orientation	6	This character begins with a mysterious drop off in the distance. Then we find a sort of transparent helmet with no eyes or nose, but only a prominent mouth under it—obviously an extrater­restrial. And what is it jabbering on about with its mouth open like that? It has strayed far from its spaceship (the drop off in the distance) whose fuel tanks are bone dry. Seeing that the poor creature is completely "disoriented," you offer a first orien­tation to life on earth by handing him a few bucks and pointing the way to the nearest gas station. [6]			xiàng		direction, to face; to, toward			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A6V"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">向的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A656"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">向的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%90%91"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">向在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=183"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">向在RTK：yonder</span></a>	RTH
0179	尚	尚	to esteem	8	Above we see the primitive for small attached to one of those glass covers you might use to display a family heirloom. Its being small is important, because what is in fact on display is the shrunken, stuffed, and mounted mouth of an ancestor we particularly esteem. We may be used to esteeming the words our forebears leave behind, but here we also esteem the very mouth that spoke them. We leave it to you to imagine a suitable place in your room for displaying such an unusual conversation piece.[8]			shàng		to esteem, value, put stock in; yet, still			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A9|"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">尚的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A97C"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">尚的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%B0%9A"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">尚在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=184"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">尚在RTK：esteem</span></a>	RTH
0180	字	字	character	6	Here is the character for character itself. Not just Chinese char­acters but any written character from hieroglyphs to Sanskrit to our own Roman alphabet. It shows us simply a child in a house. But let us take advantage of the double meaning of the key word to note that just as a child born to a Chinese house is given characters for its name, so it is also stamped with the "character" of those who raise it from infancy on. [6]<br />			zì		letter; character; pronunciation			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A6r"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">字的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A672"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">字的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%AD%97"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">字在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=185"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">字在RTK：character</span></a>	RTH
0181	守	守	to guard	6	If you want to guard, the best way is to post a watchman, like the royal soldiers in front of Buckingham Palace or the Pope's Swiss Guard. The whole idea of hiring people to guard is that they should stick like glue to your house to protect it from unwanted prowlers. So go ahead and find a watchman who is really stuck on his job and glue him to your house to guard it. [6]			shǒu		to guard, observe, watch; to defend			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A6u"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">守的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A675"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">守的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%AE%88"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">守在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=186"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">守在RTK：guard</span></a>	RTH
0182	完	完	to finish	7	To start a house we lay the foundations; to finish it, a roof. This character shows the "finished" product, from the beginnings in the foundation at the bottom, to the roof with its chimney at the top. Come to think of it, the same holds true of anything we start and finish. [7]			wán		to finish, be over; run out; done, complete			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A7%B9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">完的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A7B9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">完的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%AE%8C"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">完在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=187"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">完在RTK：perfect</span></a>	RTH
0183	實	实	reality	14	This apparently complex character is really simplicity itself. It has only two elements: house and pierce. The problem is the key word, which, despite its claims to reality, is about as abstract as they come. But if you think of a house that is really old-fash­ioned and out of touch with reality, then perhaps all it needs is a professional to pierce the chimney, or put a couple of studs on the front door. Who knows, maybe there's a career out there somewhere for a uhouse piercer" who goes around the suburbs blaring out over a microphone,"Hey, houses, get real!" [14]			shí	?reality is what pierces through the roof of your mental house?	solid; real, true; reality			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B9%EA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">實的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B9EA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">實的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%AE%9E"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">实在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%AE%9E"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1572"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">實在RTK：reality（実）</span></a>	RTH
0184	宣	宣	to proclaim	9	Think of the key word in its religious sense of a missionary preaching: "proclaiming the good news to all nations" and "shouting it from the housetops' all day, day in and day out. The element for daybreak that follows below has an additional stroke at the top. Remembering what we said about the sun creeping up over the horizon (the floor) at daybreak (frame 29), the extra stroke can represent the other horizon towards which the sun journeys, giving us "sunrise, sunset? That should be enough to help you remember this simple character, used in fact both for traditional missionary work as well as for one of its contemporary replacements: propaganda. [9]			xuān		to declare, announce, proclaim			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AB%C5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">宣的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=ABC5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">宣的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%AE%A3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">宣在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=188"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">宣在RTK：proclaim</span></a>	RTH
0185	宵	宵	Nighttime	10	Unlike the &quot;evening&quot; (frame 108), nighttime suggests time spent at night, as in pulling an all-nighter to prepare for an exam when everyone else is fast asleep in bed. The character expresses this by picturing a house with a candle in it. The rea­son is obvious: whoever is living there is passing the nighttime &quot;burning the candle at both ends.&quot; [10]		(not <i>night</i>)	xiāo		night, nighttime; dark			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AEd"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">宵的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AE64"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">宵的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%AE%B5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">宵在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=189"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">宵在RTK：wee hours</span></a>	RTH
0186	安	安	peaceful	6	To be told that the place of the woman is in the house may not sit well with modern thought, but like all cultural habits the Chinese characters bear the birthmarks of their age. So indulge yourself in a Norman Rockwell image of a peaceful moment: a weary woman of the house slouched asleep in the living room chair, her hair in curlers and a duster lying in her lap. [6]			ān		peace, calm, quiet; peaceful, tranquil; to pacify			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A6w"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">安的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A677"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">安的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%AE%89"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">安在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=190"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">安在RTK：relax</span></a>	RTH
0187	宴	宴	Banquet	10	To carry on from the last frame, we note the entire day of work that comes between a woman and her house in preparing for a dinner banquet, pictorially "interrupting" her peaceful relax­ation. [10]			yàn		feast, banquet, party; to host a dinner			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AEb"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">宴的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AE62"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">宴的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%AE%B4"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">宴在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=191"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">宴在RTK：banquet</span></a>	RTH
0188	寄	寄	to mail	11	Now there is nothing particularly strange about your normal mailbox, but the one depicted here is a strange house that you actually have to enter to drop off your letters. Think of the haunted House of Usher that Edgar Allen Poe immortalized, or the enchanted Gingerbread House that Hansel and Gretel are heading towards with an armful of letters to mail. [11]		(not 郵)	jì		to mail, sen, transmit; to rely or depend on			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B1H"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">寄的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B148"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">寄的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%AF%84"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">寄在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=192"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">寄在RTK：draw near</span></a>	leech RTH
0189	富	富	wealthy	12	Here we have the original character on which the primitive ele­ment for wealth is based. In keeping with the story introduced back then, note how many wealthy people get that way through simple inheritance, being born into the wealth of their parents' house. [12]		(full character, <u>not</u> <i>wealth</i>)	fù		rich, wealthy, abundant; to enrich			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B4I"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">富的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B449"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">富的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%AF%8C"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">富在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=193"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">富在RTK：wealth</span></a>	RTH
0190	貯	贮	to store up	12	This character shows a family that literally stores up its clams by hanging them on a large, six-foot nail driven into a space under the roof of their house. [12]			zhù		to store, save up, stockpile, hoard			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B6J"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">貯的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B64A"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">貯的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%B4%AE"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">贮在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%B4%AE"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=194"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">貯在RTK：savings</span></a>	RTH
0191	木	木	Tree	4	This is a pictograph of a tree, the main trunk shown in the long vertical stroke and the boughs in the long horizontal stroke and the final two strokes sweeping down in both directions. Although it may look similar at first sight to the character for water (frame 126), the order in which it is written is completely different and this affects its final appearance. [4]	As a primitive, this character can mean <i>tree</i> or <i>wood</i>. When the last two strokes are detached from the trunk (7k), we shall change its meaning to <i>pole</i> or <i>wooden pole</i>.		mù		tree; lumber, wood, wooden			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4%EC"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">木的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A4EC"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">木的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%9C%A8"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">木在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=195"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">木在RTK：tree</span></a>	RTH
0192	林	林	Woods	8	Learn this frame in connection with the next one. A woods is a small cluster of trees. Hence the simple reduplication of the character for tree gives us a woods. [8]			lín		woods, forest; grove			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AAL"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">林的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AA4C"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">林的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%9E%97"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">林在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=196"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">林在RTK：grove</span></a>	RTH
0193	森	森	Forest	12	A forest is a large expanse of trees, or "trees, trees everywhere," to adopt the expression we used in frames 22,23, and 166. [12]			sēn		forest; wooded; gloomy			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B4%CB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">森的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B4CB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">森的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%A3%AE"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">森在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=197"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">森在RTK：forest</span></a>	RTH
0194	植	植	to plant	12	You have no doubt seen how people practicing the Japanese art of bonsai take those helpless little saplings and twist them into crippled dwarves before they have a chance to grow up as they should. The more proper way to plant a young tree and give it a fair shake in life is to set it into the earth in such a way that it can grow up straight. [12]			zhí		to plant, grow; to establish			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B4%D3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">植的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B4D3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">植的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%A4%8D"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">植在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=205"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">植在RTK：plant</span></a>	RTH
0195	杏	杏	Apricot	7	Since apricots can be eaten just as they fall from the trees, pic­ture this mouth agape at the bottom of a tree (just as the ele­ments have it), waiting for apricots to fall into it. [7]			xìng		apricot			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A7%F6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">杏的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A7F6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">杏的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%9D%8F"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">杏在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=203"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">杏在RTK：apricot</span></a>	RTH
0196	呆	呆	dim-witted	7	The dim-witted thimblehead in this character is seated in the topmost branches of a tree with his mouth agape, waiting for the fruit to fall into it, but the only thing that happens is that nothing happens. [7]			dāi		foolish; stupid, simple			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A7b"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">呆的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A762"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">呆的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%91%86"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">呆在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=2181"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">呆在RTK：dumbfounded</span></a>	RTH
0197	枯	枯	withered	9	When a tree is withered and about to die, it is probably due to a kind of arteriosclerosis that keeps its sap from flowing freely. This character shows us an ancient and wrinkled tree with poor circulation, withered up and whiling away its remaining days in a retirement center. [9]			kū		dried up, decayed, withered desiccated, emaciated			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AC\"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">枯的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AC5C"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">枯的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%9E%AF"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">枯在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=206"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">枯在RTK：wither</span></a>	RTH
0198	村	村	Village	7	The character for village shows a circle of trees glued together to measure off the confines of a village. [7]			cūn		village; rustic, vulgar			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A7%F8"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">村的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A7F8"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">村的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%9D%91"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">村在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=208"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">村在RTK：town</span></a>	RTH
0199	相	相	one another	9	The key word one another stirs up associations of people inter­acting. When we read off the elements, tree... eye, we are given an idea of how to keep this interaction amicable by calling to mind the scriptural proverb about first taking the tree trunk out of your own eye before helping your neighbors remove the splinters from theirs. [9]			xiāng		mutual, reciprocal, each other			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AC%DB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">相的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=ACDB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">相的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%9B%B8"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">相在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=209"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">相在RTK：inter-</span></a>	RTH
0200	本	本	notebook	5	Recalling that notebooks are made of paper, and paper made of trees, one might think of a notebook as a slice of a tree. Can you see the "cross-cut" in the trunk of the tree7. Picture a chainsaw cutting you out a few notebooks to take to school. [5]			běn		book, notebook; root, basis, origin, source			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A5%BB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">本的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A5BB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">本的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%9C%AC"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">本在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=211"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">本在RTK：book</span></a>	RTH
0201	案	案	legal case	10	The case that this key word refers to is the legal kind and the image contrasts the attitudes of the parties involved. While you are in a frazzle, the lawyer answers all your phone calls with/Tm working on your case,&quot; when actually she is swaying, relaxed and peaceful, in a hammock strung up between the trees in her backyard. Imagine that—people actually get paid to take it easy while you do all the worrying. [10]			àn		case, record, file			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AE%D7"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">案的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AED7"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">案的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%A1%88"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">案在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=214"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">案在RTK：plan</span></a>	RTH
0202	未	未	not yet	5	As the key word suggests, this character has to do with some­thing not quite over and done with. More concretely, it shows us a tree that is not yet fully grown. The extra short stroke in the upper branches shows new branches spreading out, leaving one with the feeling that the tree has a ways to go yet before it reaches maturity. In other words, the character conveys its meaning pictographically, playing on the earlier pictograph of the tree. [5]			wèi		8th Earthly Branch; SHEEP; [1:00pm - 3:00pm]; not yet, still not			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A5%BC"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">未的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A5BC"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">未的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%9C%AA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">未在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=216"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">未在RTK：not yet</span></a>	RTH
0203	末	末	Last	5	This character is best learned in connection with that of the previous frame. The first stroke shows a branch that is longer than the main branch, indicating that the tree has reached the last of its growth, so that its top branches stop spreading and start drooping downwards. Be sure to keep this imagery in mind, to avoid confusing this key word with synonyms that will appear later. [5]			mò		end, final, last			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A5%BD"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">末的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A5BD"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">末的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%9C%AB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">末在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=217"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">末在RTK：extremity</span></a>	RTH
0204	沫	沫	Foam	8	The foam this character refers to is the last stage of water after it has dashed and splashed against the rocks, spraying in all direc­tions. The foam is thus a wave that has run its full course and reached its last on the rocky seashore. If you picture it in your minds eye, this somewhat rare (but oh-so-easy-to-learn) char­acter is yours for good. [8]			mò		foam, froth, suds, lather			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AAj"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">沫的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AA6A"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">沫的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%B2%AB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">沫在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=218"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">沫在RTK：splash</span></a>	RTH
0205	味	味	Flavor	8	When a tree has not yet finished growing, it produces fruit with a full flavor. When the official taster (the professional mouth to the left) determines that full flavor has been reached, the tree is pruned back so that it remains permanently not yet grown. A neat little agricultural trick and an easy way to see the sense of flavor hidden in this character. [8]			wèi		flavor, taste, smell, scent			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A8%FD"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">味的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A8FD"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">味的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%91%B3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">味在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=219"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">味在RTK：flavor</span></a>	RTH
0206	妹	妹	younger sister	8	The younger sister in the family is the woman in the family who, like the newest branch in a tree, is not yet old enough or mature enough to do everything the older sister can do (see frame 1298). [8]			mèi		younger sister			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A9f"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">妹的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A966"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">妹的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%A6%B9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">妹在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=220"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">妹在RTK：younger sister</span></a>	RTH
0207	查	查	to investigate	9	To investigate is to get to the bottom of something or track something down, which often has you working all through the night, right to daybreak In the case of this character, it is Sir Isaac Newton, who is investigating the laws of physics when the appearance of the sun at daybreak prompts the tree to stretch and welcome a new day. At that, an apple drops from its branches square on Sir Isaac s head, inspiring him to discover the law of universal gravitation. [9]			chá		to inspect, check, investigate			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%ACd"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">查的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AC64"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">查的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%9F%A5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">查在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1781"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">查在RTK：investigate（査）</span></a>	RTH
0208	渣	渣	sediment	12	This character has you in your scuba-diving gear investigating at the bottom of a reservoir to see what has made the water go bad. See yourself mucking around the sediment and finding remnants of all sorts of garbage and chemical waste. Hopefully, someone will find the "dregs" of society that put it there and bring them to justice. [12]			zhā		sediement, residue, dregs			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B4%ED"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">渣的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B4ED"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">渣的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%B8%A3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">渣在n词酷</span></a>・	RTH
0209	染	染	to dye	9	Take a handful of ash tree seeds, plant them in your backyard, and sprinkle them with water mixed with your mothers hair dye. If you are patient enough to nurture this little orchard of ash trees to full size, you could carve yourself out the first-ever- in-history brunette or platinum-streaked baseball bat. [9] 			rǎn	{From 氵(水 shuǐ) 'water', 九 (jiǔ) 'nine', and 木 (mù) 'tree'.<br />        &quot;To dye; imbue with, infect -- the commentator says: 九 nine dippings into a 水 decoction of a special kind of 木 tree&quot; --Karlgren.<br />        Probably no historical relation to 氿 guǐ.<br />==== 氿 [guǐ] 氿泉 guǐquán spring coming out of hillside}	to dye; to contract (an illness), acquire (a bad habit)			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%ACV"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">染的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AC56"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">染的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%9F%93"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">染在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=509"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">染在RTK：dye</span></a>	RTH
0210	李	李	Plum	7	Little Jack Horner has left his corner and his Christmas pie to try out his fortunes with a tree in the garden. He sticks in his thumb and out drops a plum, which says, "What a weird child you are!" [7]			lǐ		plum			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A7%F5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">李的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A7F5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">李的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%9D%8E"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">李在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=2511"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">李在RTK：damson</span></a>	RTH
0211	桌	桌	Table	10	You have to think here of a group of magicians seated around a magical table, which is made out of the stump of a tree, and has the image of a large sun carved into its surface. The magicians pass the magic wand around from hand to hand to see if any of them can make the sun shine. At last, one of them succeeds, and the sun begins to glow (burning a hole in the table in the process). [10]			zhuō		table; MW for table, desk			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AE%E0"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">桌的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AEE0"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">桌的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%A1%8C"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">桌在n词酷</span></a>・	RTH
0212	若	若	as if	9	Here we see a flower held in the right hand, calling to mind the famous story of the Buddha who held up a. flower with his right hand to a small gathering of his disciples. Most of them were perplexed, but Kasyapa smiled and the Buddha handed him the flower, as if he had understood something that everyone else had missed. To this day it remains a mystery what it was that the Buddha communicated to Kasyapa, but everyone treats the story as if it is of pivotal importance. [9]			ruò		to seem, be like; similar; as, if			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%ADY"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">若的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AD59"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">若的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%8B%A5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">若在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=223"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">若在RTK：young</span></a>	RTH
0213	草	草	grass	10	Perhaps you know the custom of seeding grass randomly or in some particular pattern with the flower called the crocus, which blooms for a few days each year in early spring. As the grass begins to turn green again after winter has passed, these tiny flowers dot up here and there. Now just look out your window at a patch of grass somewhere and think what a nice idea it would be to have your name spelled out in flowers once as a sort of early harbinger of spring. [10]			cǎo		grass, straw; rough draft			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AF%F3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">草的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AFF3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">草的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%8D%89"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">草在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=224"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">草在RTK：grass</span></a>	RTH
0214	苦	苦	Suffering	9	The picture of suffering we are given here is that of a flower that has grown ancient. When a flower ages, it pales and dries up, and probably even endures a kind of botanical suffering. If<br />you think that plants are incapable of such feelings, then ask yourself why so many people believe that talking to their flow­ers helps them bloom better. [9]			kǔ		to suffer from; suffering, hardship; painstakingly; bitter			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%ADW"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">苦的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AD57"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">苦的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%8B%A6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">苦在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=225"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">苦在RTK：suffering</span></a>	RTH
0215	寬	宽	wide	15	The key word wide will suggest a wide-angle lens, since that is one of the first expressions likely to pop into mind at the sound of the word. What we are trying to see in a single view is an immense greenhouse filled with one each of all the flow­ers of the world. Picture yourself trying to see the whole thing through the viewer of your wide-angle lens, and then focusing on a single drop of dew on the tiniest petal of the tiniest blos­som. To see everything in all its detail may be asking a little much of a single lens, but nothing short of such a vision could ever satisfy the curiosity that comes with the gift of sight. [15]			kuān		wide, broad, vast, spacious; tolerant			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%BCe"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">寬的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=BC65"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">寬的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%AE%BD"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">宽在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%AE%BD"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=226"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">寬在RTK：tolerant（寛）</span></a>	RTH
0216	葉	叶	Leaf	13	Two elements we have to work with here are flower and family tree. Now all of us know what it is to have some rotten fruit on the family tree, but let us never forget that it is always possible for even the worst of us to turn over a new leaf and burst into flower if given the chance. [13]			yè		leaf, petal; page; historic period			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B8%AD"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">葉的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B8AD"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">葉的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%8F%B6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">叶在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%8F%B6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=228"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">葉在RTK：leaf</span></a>	RTH
0217	莫	莫	nobody	11	A rickety old sign with the warning written on it "Nobody, but Nobody Leaves Here" dangles from a shingle over the entrance to a graveyard. But, contrary to what you expect, this is a thor­oughly modern graveyard. Gone are the cobwebs and gnarled trees, the tilted headstones and dark, moonless nights that used to scare the wits out of our childhood imaginations. Instead, we see brightly colored flowers placed before the tombstones, the sun shining gloriously overhead, and a cuddly St Bernard dog sitting at the gate, making sure that nobody tries to leave. [11]	When this character is used as a primitive element, we will replace the abstract key word with the more concrete <i>graveyard</i>.		mò	A dead man with a ripped-of leg lies rotting in the open-air graveyard, with only the sun and some flowers for comfort.	nobody; not; don't, isn't			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B2%F6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">莫的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B2F6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">莫的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%8E%AB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">莫在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=2105"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">莫在RTK：shalt</span></a>	RTH
0218	模	模	to imitate	15	Ah, but haven't they made a parody of the modern graveyard in trying to imitate its classic ancestors! The flowers are plastic, the writing on the stones is unimaginative and cold, and the whole thing looks more like a marble orchard than a right and proper graveyard. This character continues with the modern­ization trend by picturing artificial trees in the graveyard. But of course, how convenient! They don t need pruning or fertilizing, their leaves don t fall, and they remain the same color all year long. But far from imitating the real thing, they end up a cheap "imitation." [15]			mó	A dead <b>imitating mime</b> with a ripped of leg (the only good mime) lies in the fake stone-is-too-expensive <b>wooden</b> <b>graveyard</b>.	to imitate; model, pattern, template			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%BC%D2"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">模的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=BCD2"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">模的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%A8%A1"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">模在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=229"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">模在RTK：imitation</span></a>	leech RTH
0219	漠	漠	Desert	14	Let this key word suggest to you a mirage in a desert. The haze rising up from the desert sands creates the illusion of a body of water in the distance. In fact, the mirage only recedes as you crawl your way across the surface of what will soon be your graveyard. To fix the image, imagine yourself reaching the mirage and finding out that it is in fact a graveyard, in which there is a headstone with your name on it. [14]		(<u>not</u> <i>Drought</i>)	mò		desert; cold, detachedl; indifferently			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%BAz"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">漠的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=BA7A"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">漠的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%BC%A0"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">漠在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=230"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">漠在RTK：vague</span></a>	RTH
0220	墓	墓	a Grave	14	The mounds of soil with crude wooden crosses set at their head suggests those Boot Hill graves near Tombstone, Arizona, that many of you will remember from cowboy lore. The only odd thing about this character is that the soil comes under the graveyard, rather than to its left, where we might expect it. Just think of how it looks as you walk toward Boot Hill, with the cross and mound of soil in the foreground.<br />By the way, this is not the first time, nor will it be the last, that we learn a character whose key word is the same, or almost the same, as a primitive element based on it, but whose shape dif­fers somewhat. There is no cause to worry. By using the primi­tive in a variety of other characters, as we have done here, the confusion will be averted as a matter of course. In most cases, as here, the primitive element is simply one part of the fuller original character. [14]		(full character)	mù		grave, tomb			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B9%D3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">墓的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B9D3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">墓的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%A2%93"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">墓在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=231"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">墓在RTK：grave</span></a>	RTH
0221	苗	苗	Seedling	9	To avoid confusion with the image of rice seedlings to appear later, we shall take these seedlings out of their agricultural set­ting in the rice fields and into the frame of Brave New World surgery, where "ideas" or "values" are being implanted into brains like seedlings to insure a harmonious society. Then you need only imagine them taking root and breaking out into flower right through the tops of the skulls of people walking around on the streets. [9]	When this character is used as a primitive element, we will adjust its meaning to <i>tomato seedling</i>.		miáo		seedling; sprout			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AD]"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">苗的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AD5D"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">苗的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%8B%97"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">苗在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=234"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">苗在RTK：seedling</span></a>	RTH
0222	瞄	瞄	to aim	14	In order to aim at something through the sights of a rifle, you fix your eyes on the thin crosshairs. In this case, however, the usual crosshairs have been replaced with the completely useless serrated leaves of a tomato seedling. And not only that, they are poking out of where the lens should be and keep tickling your eyeball, keeping you from aiming properly. Obviously the sabo­tage of peacemakers working in a rifle factory. [14]			miáo		to aim, fix one’s eyes on			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%BA%CB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">瞄的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=BACB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">瞄的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%9E%84"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">瞄在n词酷</span></a>・	RTH
0223	兆	兆	Portent	6	Here we have a pictograph of the back of a turtle, the two slop­ing vertical strokes representing the central ridge and the four short strokes the pattern. Think of reading turtle shells as a way to foretell the future, and in particular, to suggest a portent of coming evils. [6]			zhào		omen, sign; to foretell; million, mega			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A5%FC"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">兆的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A5FC"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">兆的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%85%86"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">兆在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=235"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">兆在RTK：portent</span></a>	RTH
0224	桃	桃	peach	10	To associate the peach with the primitive for a portent, recall the famous Japanese legend of Momotaro, the Peach Boy. It begins once upon a time with a fisherman and his wife who wanted badly to have a child, but none was born to them. Then one day the old man caught a giant peach, out of which jumped a healthy young lad whom they named Peach Boy. Though the boy was destined to perform heroic deeds, his birth foreshad­owed great misfortune (how else could he become a hero?). Thus the peach tree is seen as a portent of coming evil. [10]			táo		peach			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AE%E7"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">桃的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AEE7"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">桃的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%A1%83"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">桃在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=236"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">桃在RTK：peach tree</span></a>	RTH
0225	犬	犬	Pooch	4	We have already learned that the character for large takes on the meaning of the St. Bernard dog when used as a primitive. In this frame we finally see why. The drop added as a fourth and final stroke means that we have to do with a much smaller dog, a pooch, which compared to the St. Bernard dog is no more than a drop in the kennel. [4]			quǎn		dog			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4%FC"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">犬的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A4FC"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">犬的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%8A%AC"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">犬在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=238"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">犬在RTK：dog</span></a>	RTH
0226	尤	尤	remarkable	4	We learn this next character here simply because it is the easiest place to learn it. Later it will figure as an element of other, more complex characters.<br>The only thing that distinguishes this character from the pooch is its remarkable human leg. As the story goes, the poor creature lost its leg in a car accident and hobbled around pitifully, until one day a mad scientist caught sight of it, dragged it into his castle, and fastened on it the severed leg of a local chorus girl (whose leg had mysteriously flown off her chassis in the middle of a performance, striking a French tourist on the head). So there you have it, the altogether remarkable Frankenpooch. [4]	As a primitive, this character will keep its meaning of the <span style="font-weight:600; font-style:italic;">Frankenpooch</span>.		yóu		outstanding; especially, particularly			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4%D7"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">尤的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A4D7"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">尤的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%B0%A4"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">尤在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=2087"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">尤在RTK：understandably</span></a>	RTH
0227	默	默	silence	16	"But my words, like silent raindrops fell...." The famous ode to "silence" from which these words were taken begins with an enigmatic phrase that this character will clear up once and for all: "Hello, Darkness, my old friend...." It has long been assumed that Darkness referred to nighttime, but actually it was the name of a silent black chihuahua that hung around the set without ever once barking, eventually inspiring the song. [16]			mò		silent, still, quiet; to write from memory			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%C0q"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">默的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=C071"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">默的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E9%BB%98"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">默在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=240"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">默在RTK：silence（黙）</span></a>	RTH
0228	然	然	sort of thing	12	The character in this frame is used as a suffix for certain adverbs and adjectives, and for too many other purposes to capture in a single key word. Rather arbitrarily, we have settled on "sort of thing." Reverting to the time when dog was more widely eaten than it is today (see frame 230), we see the flesh of a chihuahua roasting over a cooking fire—a "hot-diggity, dog-diggity" sort of thing. [12]			rán		thus, so, certainly, like this, in this manner; -ly			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B5M"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">然的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B54D"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">然的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%84%B6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">然在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=241"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">然在RTK：sort of thing</span></a>	RTH
0229	哭	哭	to cry	10	Here we have a chatterbox of a chihuahua. Listen to it gabbing away in its high, shrill voice and you have a pretty good idea of what you sound like when you cry. [10]			kū		to cry, weep; to wail			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AD%FA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">哭的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=ADFA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">哭的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%93%AD"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">哭在n词酷</span></a>・	RTH
0230	器	器	Utensil	16	The picture in this character is not a pleasant one. It shows a tiny little chihuahua lying on a platter all stuffed and stewed and garnished with vegetables, its paws in the air and a cherry in its mouth. At each corner of the table sits an empty but eager mouth, waiting for the utensils to arrive so the feast can begin. [16]			qì		device, tool, utensil, instrument			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%BE%B9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">器的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=BEB9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">器的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%99%A8"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">器在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=121"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">器在RTK：utensil</span></a>	RTH
0231	臭	臭	stinking	10	This character is a bit friendlier to the animal world than the last one. Our friend the chihuahua is alive and well, its nose in the air sniffing suspiciously after something stinking some­where or other. [10]			chòu		stinking, smelly; to emit afoul odor			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AF%E4"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">臭的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AFE4"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">臭的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%87%AD"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">臭在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=122"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">臭在RTK：stinking</span></a>	RTH
0232	狗	狗	Dog	8	This is the generic character for dog, indicated by the elements for pack of wild dogs and sentence. Think of the twenty-six let­ters of the alphabet as a pack of wild dogs that run things down in order to work them into sentences. Here they are chasing after your fleet-footed pet terrier. When they catch up with the poor little creature, they circle around it and form themselves into the famous sentence that contains all the letters of the alphabet: "The quick brown dog jumped over the lazy fox." [8]			gǒu		dog; [nb: 狗东西, gǒudōngxi, "That son of a bitch!"]			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AA%AF"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">狗的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AAAF"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">狗的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%8B%97"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">狗在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=2341"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">狗在RTK：pup</span></a>	RTH
0233	厭	厌	to detest	14	Let the key word suggest someone who has come to detest everything and everything, for whom all the things of life have become meaningless. We are reminded of a vivid image of despair in Nietzsche's Thus Spoke Zarathustra that makes the character simple to remember.<br />Walking the dark cliffs at midnight, Zarathustra hears a dog (the pooch) howling. He approaches, and under the pale light of the moon he sees a shepherd lad lying on the ground with a thick, black snake hanging out of his mouth (like a long, wag­ging tongue). The snake had crawled in while the lad was asleep, grabbed on to his throat, and held fast. Zarathustra tells the shepherd to bite off the head of the snake and become free of the despair that holds him in tortured captivity, and cease to detest the things of life. [14]			yàn		to loathe, dislike, detest			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B9%BD"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">厭的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B9BD"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">厭的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%8E%8C"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">厌在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%8E%8C"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=2149"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">厭在RTK：despondent</span></a>	RTH
0234	壓	压	pressure	17	Too much pressure in the classroom not only affects students' ability to learn, but it also has the dangerous effect of leading young children to detest time &quot;wasted&quot; on the playground. If you try to picture the pressure in a literal, not just a psychological sense, the image will be easier to remember. [17]			yā	(jap. simpl.: 圧)	to crush, press; to oppress			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%C0%A3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">壓的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=C0A3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">壓的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%8E%8B"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">压在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%8E%8B"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=152"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">壓在RTK：pressure（圧）</span></a>	RTH
0235	牛	牛	Cow	4	Can you see the "doodle" of a cow that has just been run over by a steamroller? The small dot in the first stroke shows its head turned to one side, and the next two strokes, the four legs. [4]	When this character is used as a primitive, the same sense of <span style="font-weight:600; font-style:italic;">cow</span> is kept. Note only that when it is placed over another element, its tail is cut off, giving us In this case, and when the element appears on the left (^), the order of the final two strokes is changed.		niú		ox, cow, bull			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4%FB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">牛的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A4FB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">牛的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%89%9B"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">牛在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=245"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">牛在RTK：cow</span></a>	RTH
0236	特	特	special	10	Let the key word of this frame refer to something in a special class all its own—like the sacred cows of India that wander freely without fear of being butchered and ground into ham­burger. Even though the practice is originally a Hindu one, and in any case no longer followed among the majority of Mahayana Buddhist monks, the Buddha's refusal to take the life of any sen­tient being makes it only fitting that cows, special as they are, should be placed on the sacred grounds of a Buddhist temple in this character. [10]			tè		special (-ly); unusual, unique, extraordinary			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AFS"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">特的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AF53"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">特的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%89%B9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">特在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=246"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">特在RTK：special</span></a>	RTH
0237	告	告	to declare	7	Folklore throughout the world tells us of talking animals who show a wisdom superior to that of human beings, and that same tradition has found its way into television shows and cartoons right in our own century. This character depicts a cow with a large mouth that utters, with oracular wisdom, answers to ques­tions posed to her. She begins each reply by opening her mouth wide enough to swallow you whole and stating (in a thick southern drawl),"Aah do declare...T<br />Observe that the stroke order of the cow element changes in the abbreviated form it takes here. [7]			gào		to tell, say, announce, inform			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A7i"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">告的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A769"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">告的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%91%8A"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">告在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=247"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">告在RTK：revelation</span></a>	RTH
0238	浩	浩	vast	10	The word vast almost inevitably suggests an endless body of water. Only in the case of this character, it is not located in any of the known bodies of water but inside the large mouth of the oracular cow. Take a peek inside and see if you can see the waves splashing against her palate. [10]		[expand]	hào		extensive, grand; vast (water)			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AFE"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">浩的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AF45"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">浩的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%B5%A9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">浩在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=2311"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">浩在RTK：abounding</span></a>	RTH
0239	先	先	before	6	Take this key word in its physical, not its temporal, sense (even though it refers to both). If you have a cow with human legs, as the elements show us here, it can only be because you have two people in a cow suit. Who would not prefer to be the one standing before, rather than the one that holds up the rear and becomes the "butt" of everyone's laughter! [6]		(not "in front of")	xiān		early; prior; former; in advance; first			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A5%FD"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">先的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A5FD"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">先的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%85%88"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">先在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=248"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">先在RTK：before</span></a>	RTH
0240	洗	洗	to wash	9	This character is so logical that one is tempted to let the ele­ments speak for themselves: water... before. Let's see what we can do to make it more memorable.<br>We all know the parental insistence inflicted on children, "Wash your hands before you come to the table." At some point, your mom gets so fed up with repeating it that she calls in a plumber to fix a small water spigot to the edge of the table in front of each chair. Mom dutifully washes her own hands to drop the hint, and everyone does the same in turn. Of course, we would end up with wet laps and water all over the floor, but at least everyone's hands would be clean. [9]			xǐ		to wash, cleanse, purify; to bathe			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AC~"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">洗的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AC7E"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">洗的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%B4%97"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">洗在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=249"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">洗在RTK：wash</span></a>	RTH
0241	介	介	to introduce	4	The right way to enter a new situation is to have someone politely introduce you, so that you don t feel that you are intrud­ing. This character shows a walking stick being introduced into an umbrella frame by someone shoving it into an already occu­pied slot in the umbrella stand at the door. First notice the ver­tical strokes: on the left is the curved umbrella handle, and on the right the straight walking stick. Now try to imagine the two parties tugging at their respective properties like two kids on a wishbone, creating a scene at the entrance of an elegant restau­rant. So much for polite "introductions." [4]			jiè		to introduce; to lie between; between			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4%B6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">介的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A4B6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">介的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E4%BB%8B"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">介在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=250"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">介在RTK：jammed in</span></a>	RTH
0242	界	界	World	9	Whoever it is that decides to introduce the construction of more and more buildings in our cities as "development proj­ects' should be held accountable someday for what a mess we are making of the natural world, not to mention the living and working conditions of those who populate them. From a bird's-eye view, this glass-and-cement jungle begins to look more and more like a gigantic checkerboard (replacing the neatly partitioned rice fields). If you look closely at the character, you should be able to see a kind of movement taking place as still more buildings are being introduced into already cramped spaces. [9]			jiè		boundary, scope, extent			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AC%C9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">界的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=ACC9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">界的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%95%8C"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">界在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=251"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">界在RTK：world</span></a>	RTH
0243	茶	茶	Tea	10	As everyone knows, tea is made from tea leaves. But the tea plant itself has its own flowers, which can be quite beautiful and add a special flavor to the tea, as the Chinese found out over 4,600 years ago. With the image of a terrace of flowering tea bushes in mind, picture a number of brightly painted and very 1-o-n-g wooden poles (frame 191) placed here and there in their midst, with an umbrella at the top of each of them to shade the delicate-tasting tea flowers. [10]			chá		tea; tea plant			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AF%F9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">茶的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AFF9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">茶的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%8C%B6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">茶在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=252"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">茶在RTK：tea</span></a>	RTH
0244	會	会	Meeting	13	Here is the full character for the primitive element introduced in the previous frame. The two added elements below, the brains impaled on the horns of a dilemma (see frame 172) and tongues wagging in the mouths create a memorable, and accu­rate, description of a lot of meetings. [13]			huì		to meet, assemble, gather; group; association; ALSO: can, be able			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B7|"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">會的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B77C"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">會的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E4%BC%9A"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">会在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E4%BC%9A"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=752"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">會在RTK：meeting（会）</span></a>	RTH
0245	合	合	to fit	6	The character for fit reads literally, top to bottom, as a meeting of mouths—which is a rather descriptive way of speaking of a romantic kiss. We ail know what happens when there is no meeting of minds and when peoples ideas don't fit with one another.
