But this character invites us to imagine what hap­pened to the romance of a certain unfortunate couple whose mouths didn't fit. [6]			hé		to fit, suit; to join, combine; to close, shut (eg: book)			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A6X"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">合的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A658"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">合的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%90%88"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">合在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=253"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">合在RTK：fit</span></a>	RTH
0246	哈	哈	Ha!	9	This is a "sound character* for the sound of laughter. Write it twice and it is read—what else!—ha-ha. Now nothing fits the human mouth better than a good laugh, one of the few things that separate us scientifically from other primates. Can it be accidental that the sound of laughter is universal across lan­guages? Another reason to say that it fits the mouth perfectly. [9]			hā		[ the sound of laughter]			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AB%A2"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">哈的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=ABA2"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">哈的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%93%88"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">哈在n词酷</span></a>・	RTH
0247	塔	塔	Pagoda	13	On the left we see a mound of dirt and on the right, flowers made to fit together. The two combine to create a great pagoda made of dirt, with flowers by the tens of thousands made to fit together for the roofing of each of the layers. Be sure to put yourself in the scene and fit a few of the flowers in place yourself so that the image works its way into memory with full force. [13]			tǎ		pagoda; tower			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B6%F0"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">塔的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B6F0"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">塔的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%A1%94"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">塔在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=254"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">塔在RTK：pagoda</span></a>	RTH
0248	王	王	King	4	See what you can do to come up with a pictograph of a king's scepter here that suits your own idea of what it should look like. You might even begin with the basic element for I-beam and then try to fit the remaining third stroke in. [4]	As a primitive, this character can mean either <i>king</i> or <i>scep­ter</i>, but it will usually be taken to mean <i>jewel</i> or <i>ball</i> (from the characters introduced in the following two frames.).		wáng		king, monarch			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4%FD"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">王的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A4FD"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">王的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%8E%8B"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">王在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=255"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">王在RTK：king</span></a>	RTH
0249	玉	玉	Jade	5	Note the drop here in the king's scepter, which is exactly what you would expect it to be: a gold staff with a large jade jewel on the handle, a symbol of his wealth and power. [5]	When this character is used as a primitive and retains its original shape, it will keep the original meaning of <i>jade</i>. When it appears on the left, however, it will be lacking the final stroke, making it the same as the character in the pre­vious frame, I. In such cases, its meaning will be <i>jewel</i> or <i>ball</i>		yù		jade			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A5%C9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">玉的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A5C9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">玉的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%8E%89"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">玉在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=256"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">玉在RTK：jewel</span></a>	RTH
0250	球	球	Balls	11	Immediately we introduce the primitive element for ball and we meet the full character for ball on which it is based. As an aid to remembering it, think of a catcher signaling the pitcher his request not for a strike but for a ball. As if he was going to throw his glove or his hat. What else can the pitcher throw? Heaven only knows what Alexander Cartwright was smoking when he gave it that name. [11]			qiú		ball; sphere			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B2y"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">球的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B279"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">球的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%90%83"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">球在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=935"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">球在RTK：ball</span></a>	RTH
0251	現	现	present	11	Do not think of a "gift" here, but of the present time, as distinct from the future and the past. The character gives us a ball in which we see the present moment—obviously a crystal ball that enables us to see things going on at the present time in faraway places. [11]		(time)	xiàn		present; now; existing; current			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B2{"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">現的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B27B"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">現的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%8E%B0"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">现在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%8E%B0"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=259"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">現在RTK：present</span></a>	RTH
0252	玩	玩	to play	8	The very first game people played dates back to the beginning of creation, in the Garden of Paradise. For those who see it as a story of original sin, it went something like the game children play called "hot potato." You take a ball and pass it around as quickly as possible until someone drops the ball&gt; thereby los­ing. In the case of Adam and Eve, it was a piece of fruit from the forbidden tree. "Its not mine, its his ""No it's not, she had it first...." In any case, if you see an original sin in all of this, then both of them clearly dropped the ball for the rest of us. [8]		(<u>not</u> <i>to play with</i>)	wán [普], wàn [國]		to play, amuse oneself; to play jokes			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AA%B1"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">玩的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AAB1"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">玩的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%8E%A9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">玩在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=2567"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">玩在RTK：toy</span></a>	RTH
0253	狂	狂	crazy	7	We sometimes refer to people or ideas that are crazy as being "looney," which literally means driven mad by the light of the moon. The most famous of the "looneys" are the legendary lycanthropes or "wolfmen." Sometimes the transformation is only a temporary phenomenon; sometimes it is permanent. In the latter case, the poor chap takes off on all fours to live with the beasts. To remember this character, imagine one of these lycanthropes going crazy and setting himself up as king of a pack of wild dogs that roams about and terrorizes innocent sub­urban communities. [7]			kuáng		crazy, insane, mad; conceited, arrogant			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A8g"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">狂的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A867"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">狂的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%8B%82"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">狂在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=260"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">狂在RTK：lunatic</span></a>	RTH
0254	皇	皇	Emperor	9	An emperor, as we all know, is a ruler—something like a king but higher in status. The white bird perched above the king, ele­vating him to "imperial" heights, is the messenger the emperor sends back and forth to the gods to request advice and special favors, something that white birds have long done in folklore throughout the world. [9]			huáng		emperor; royal, imperial			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AC%D3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">皇的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=ACD3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">皇的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%9A%87"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">皇在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=261"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">皇在RTK：emperor</span></a>	RTH
0255	煌	煌	resplendent	13	In this character we see a. fire-emperor, resplendent in his glory. He is not an emperor who rules over fire, but one made of fire. His speeches, his temper, his eyes—everything about him is "fiery" [13] 			huáng		brilliant, bright, shining, luminous			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B7%D7"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">煌的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B7D7"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">煌的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%85%8C"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">煌在n词酷</span></a>・	RTH
0256	呈	呈	to submit	7	The trick to remembering this character lies in associating the key word submit with the line from the nursery rhyme about four and twenty blackbirds baked in a pie: "Wasn't this a dainty dish to set before the king?" If we think of submit as "setting before" or "presenting to," then all we have to do to complete the picture is imagine a king with his head thrown back and his mouth wide open as twenty-four blackbirds fly in one after the other. Dainty? [7]	❖ Note that when this character is used as a primitive, in some fonts the first stroke of king is drawn from right to left and slanting downwards, replacing the usual horizontal stroke shown here, drawn left to right.		chéng		to submit, present (eg: a report); to petition			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A7e"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">呈的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A765"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">呈的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%91%88"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">呈在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=262"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">呈在RTK：display</span></a>	RTH
0257	全	全	whole	6	Being whole suggests physical and spiritual health,"having ones act together." This character compares being whole to "being king under ones own umbrella" that is, giving order to ones own life. Granted it sounds terribly abstract, but what could be more abstract than the word whole? [6]			quán		all, whole, entire, complete			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A5%FE"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">全的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A5FE"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">全的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%85%A8"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">全在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=263"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">全在RTK：whole</span></a>	RTH
0258	理	理	Logic	11	We first referred to this character back in frame 169 to which you might want to return to have a peek. The image of logic we are given is something like a central jewel in a computer, like the jewels in old clocks that keep them running smoothly. Try to picture yourself making your way through all the rams and roms and approaching this shining jewely a chorus of voices and a blast of trumpets in the background heralding the great seat of all-knowing logic. [11]			lǐ		reason; logic; science; inner principle			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B2z"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">理的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B27A"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">理的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%90%86"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">理在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=265"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">理在RTK：logic</span></a>	RTH
0259	主	主	Lord	5	"A mans home is his castle," goes the proverb from an age where it was the male who was lord of the household. Fundamentally, it means only that every one of us is a bit (or drop) of a king in our own environment. As for the positioning of the elements, if you take care to "read off" the primitives in this way, you wont end up putting the drop down below, where it turns the charac­ter into jade. [5]	When using this character as a primitive element, we set the key word aside entirely and take it as a pictograph of a solid brass <span style="font-weight:600; font-style:italic;">candlestick</span> (with the drop representing the flame at the top).		zhǔ		master; lord; host			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A5D"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">主的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A544"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">主的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E4%B8%BB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">主在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=266"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">主在RTK：lord</span></a>	RTH
0260	注	注	to pour	8	Picture yourself trying to hold your hand steady as you pour water from a lighted candlestick. What could be more ridicu­lous, or simpler, as a way to recall this character? [8]			zhù		to inject; to pour into			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AA`"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">注的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AA60"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">注的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%B3%A8"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">注在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=267"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">注在RTK：pour</span></a>	RTH
0261	金	金	the Gold	8	If this were not one of the most common characters you will ever have to write, we would apologize for having to give the explanation that follows. Anyway, we want to depict bars of gold bullion with an umbrella overhead to shade them from the heat (and perhaps to hide them as well). The bullion is made by melting down all the scepters of the kingdom, drop by drop, and shaping them into bars. [8]	When this character is used as a primitive, it means not only <span style="font-weight:600; font-style:italic;">gold</span> but any <span style="font-weight:600; font-style:italic;">metal</span> at all.		jīn		metal; money; gold			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AA%F7"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">金的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AAF7"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">金的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E9%87%91"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">金在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=269"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">金在RTK：gold</span></a>	RTH
0262	銅	铜	Copper	14	Picture an order of monks serving as chaplains for the police force. Their special habit, made of protective metal, is distin­guished by a row of copper buttons just like the "cops" they . serve. [14]			tóng		copper			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%BB%C9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">銅的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=BBC9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">銅的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E9%93%9C"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">铜在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E9%93%9C"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=272"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">銅在RTK：copper</span></a>	RTH
0263	釣	钓	to go fishin’	11	The character we learned for fishing (frame 165) refers to the professional, net-casting industry, while the key word in this frame, go fishirf, is related to the pastime or sport. The odd thing is that your' go-fishin " rod is a golden ladle which you are using to scoop goldfish out of a river. 0266	銘	铭	Inscription	14	Take inscription in the sense of the name you ask the jeweler to carve on a gold bracelet or inside a gold ring to identify its owner or communicate some sentimental message. 0267	鎮	镇	at ease	18	The first lie-detector machines of the twentieth century worked by wiring pieces of metal to the body to measure the amount of sweat produced when questions were asked. It was discov­ered that nervousness produced more sweat, indicating subcon­scious reactions when the true facts of the matter were getting too close for comfort. The only way to beat the apparatus is to have complete control over yourself and remain perfectly at ease. Picture yourself trying to do it while the examiners ask questions guaranteed to extract buckets of sweat from you. [18]			zhèn		calm, cool, composed; to ease or relieve pain			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%C2%ED"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">鎮的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=C2ED"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">鎮的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E9%95%87"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">镇在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E9%95%87"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=276"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">鎮在RTK：tranquillize</span></a>	RTH
0268	道	道	Way	12	The key word carries both the sense of a road or way for transit and a way or method of doing something. The primitives here read: heads and road. YouVe probably heard about companies cleaning house and threatening that &quot;heads are going to roll.&quot; Well, here is the road they are rolling on. If you want, think of it as the Way of the Bottom Line. [12]			dào		way, path, road; method, principle; truth, Tao			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B9D"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">道的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B944"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">道的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E9%81%93"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">道在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=277"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">道在RTK：road-way</span></a>	RTH

0270	迅	迅	speedy	6	This character shows a Speedy Gonzales wanna-be tearing down the highway in his '57 Chevy, only to be brought to an abrupt halt by the highway police who have scattered hooks and needles across the road to puncture his tires. 0271	造	造	to create	10	We sometimes think of create as meaning to make something out of nothing. 0276	蓮	莲	Lotus	14	Imagine yourself sitting on the edge of a lotus pond in the early morning as the pink and white lotus flowers softly pop into bloom, one after another. 0280	逾	逾	to exceed	12	The road to the slaughterhouse is a two-lane, one-way highway, crowded with animals of all sizes approaching their doomsday. 0281	各	各	each	6	"Suum cuique" goes the popular Latin proverb. A certain disease of the English language makes it almost impossible to translate the phrase without gender bias. In any event, here we see some­one walking with his/her mouth between his/her walking legs, giving us an image of "To each his/her own." [6]	❖ The sense of the proverb should help when using this char--------^nro it tn itc original ele­ments. But do not associate it in any way with the word "every," which we shall meet later in another context.		gè		each; every			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A6U"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">各的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A655"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">各的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%90%84"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">各在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=291"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">各在RTK：each</span></a>	RTH
0282	格	格	Pattern	10	To each tree its own pattern. Think of the key word as refer­ring to the patterns on an array of Hawaiian shirts that you are dressing up the trees in your garden with to give to each its own identity and keep them distinct from one another. Take a moment to admire the whole fashion show. [10]			gé		pattern, standard, form; style			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AE%E6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">格的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AEE6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">格的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%A0%BC"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">格在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=292"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">格在RTK：status</span></a>	RTH
0283	客	客	Guest	9	When you are a guest in a courteous town, each household has its own way of welcoming you, and each house becomes your home. [9]			kè		visitor, guest; customer			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AB%C8"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">客的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=ABC8"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">客的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%AE%A2"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">客在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=294"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">客在RTK：guest</span></a>	RTH
0284	額	额	Forehead	18	As Miss Manners will be the first to tell you, out of respect one does not look straight into the eyes of ones guests of honor, but focuses on the knots of their neckties. Here, however, you are told to look at the upper part of the head, to the forehead of your guest. [18]			é		forehead; tablet, plaque; fixed			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%C3B"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">額的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=C342"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">額的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E9%A2%9D"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">额在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E9%A2%9D"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=295"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">額在RTK：forehead</span></a>	RTH
0285	夏	夏	Summer	10	In the summer, fatigued by the heat, you have devised a creative and energy-saving fan: you have hired a couple of racewalking stars in training for the summer Olympics, stuck their noses to the ceiling, and asked them to practice by moving their walking legs around quickly in mid-air, giving you a fresh breeze and enhancing their chances of picking up a medal. [10]			xià		summer			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AEL"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">夏的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AE4C"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">夏的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%A4%8F"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">夏在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=296"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">夏在RTK：summer</span></a>	RTH
0286	洛	洛	L.A.	9	The key word (the well-known abbreviation of the city of Los Angeles) represents one of the important uses of this character in Chinese, namely, as the first character in the full compound for Los Angeles. How do we get from each drop of water to the city of L.A.? Think of what happens to the moisture in the air over that city. To each droplet of water is added its own particle of pollutant. Hence the gray blanket of smog that hangs over that unfortunate symbol of industrial devastation. [9]			luò		the "Luò" river in Shanxi Prv.			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AC%A5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">洛的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=ACA5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">洛的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%B4%9B"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">洛在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=2302"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">洛在RTK：old kyoto</span></a>	RTH
0287	落	落	to fall	13	One of the worst consequences of the smog in cities like L. A. is that the petals of flowers exposed to the open air fall before their time—good news for the artificial/tower industry, but bad news for those who prefer the real thing. [13]			luò		to fall, drop			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B8%A8"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">落的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B8A8"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">落的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%90%BD"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">落在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=299"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">落在RTK：fall</span></a>	RTH
0288	冗	冗	superfluous	4	A crown is supposed to be a sign of leadership, wisdom, and nobility. Without those virtues, it is a superfluous symbol, as in the case of the royal airhead depicted in this character. You can actually see the wind blowing between his ears. [4]			rǒng		extraneous			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4%BE"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">冗的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A4BE"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">冗的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%86%97"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">冗在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=300"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">冗在RTK：superfluous</span></a>	RTH
0289	沉	沉	profound	7	See the philosopher lost in profound speculation on matters metaphysical, the drops of water on his forehead showing the intensity of his concentration, and the accusation of his more pragmatic neighbors that the whole thing is profoundly super­fluous. [7]			chén		deep, profound; to lower, submerge, immerse			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A8I"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">沉的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A849"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">沉的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%B2%89"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">沉在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1888"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">沉在RTK：sink（沈）</span></a>	RTH
0290	軍	军	Army	9	The crowned vehicle depicted here is a "chariot," symbol of a Caesars army. [9]	❖ Used as a primitive this character means only chariot		jūn		army, military; soldiers, troops			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%ADx"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">軍的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AD78"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">軍的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%86%9B"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">军在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%86%9B"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=301"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">軍在RTK：army</span></a>	RTH

0292	運	运	to carry	12	A row of "sweet" chariots "swinging low" to our roads is a sure sign that, as the old southern spiritual has it, the Lord is "comin' for to carry us home." 0294	夢	梦	a Dream	14	To have a dream after going to bed is really the crown to a per­fect evening. The flower petals over the eyes (instead of the "sand" that Westerners are used to finding there when they awake in the morning) only confirm the image of a pleasant dream suggested by the rest of this rather complex character. [14]			mèng	The flower petals over the eyes: the crown to a per­fect evening. 	dream, visionary; wishful			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B9%DA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">夢的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B9DA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">夢的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%A2%A6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">梦在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%A2%A6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=305"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">夢在RTK：dream</span></a>	RTH
0295	坑	坑	Pit	7	A whirlwind begins to dig its way into the soil like a drill until it makes a deep pit. 0296	高	高	tall	10	Recalling an image from frame 178, first see the mouth under the extraterrestrial's transparent helmet, and then the mouth under the top hat of one of his mates who has tried on the top hat only to find that this strange earthlings' headgear makes him look much, much taller than everyone else. [10]	♦ As a primitive, this character keeps its sense of tall and its position at the top of other primitives, but its writing is abbreviated in one of two forms: when drawn with only the first five strokes (*), it keeps the generic meaning of tall but when the next two strokes are added (*) it will mean a tall <span style="font-weight:600; font-style:italic;">tiara</span>, since the element for <span style="font-weight:600; font-style:italic;">hood</span> is compressed into the form or a <span style="font-weight:600; font-style:italic;">crown</span>.		gāo		high; tall			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B0%AA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">高的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B0AA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">高的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E9%AB%98"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">高在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=307"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">高在RTK：tall</span></a>	RTH
0297	享	享	to enjoy	8	While the other children enjoy themselves at hopscotch and jacks, this one, a tall child—-but a really tall child, 11 feet 4 inches and only in second grade—enjoys herself at less terres­trial play: peeping into bird nests, chatting up the giraffes at the zoo, and high-jumping over the pole-vault bar. [8]			xiǎng		enjoy			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A8%C9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">享的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A8C9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">享的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E4%BA%AB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">享在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=308"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">享在RTK：receive</span></a>	RTH
0298	熟	熟	ripe	15	When fruit is ripe and in season, we can't get enough of it. The problem is, we want to enjoy the taste of ripe peaches and man­gos all year round. What we have here is a bottle of pills distilled from ripe fruit, after stewing for hours over a cooking firey into &quot;essence of peach&quot; and &quot;essence of mango.&quot; Enjoy them when­ever you want. [15]			shú		ripe; done; cooked			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%BC%F4"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">熟的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=BCF4"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">熟的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%86%9F"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">熟在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=310"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">熟在RTK：mellow</span></a>	leech RTH
0299	亭	亭	Pavilion	9	Think of all the pavilions at County Fairs or World Expos you have wandered into or seen advertised in the media, and you will no doubt see rising up among them the towering spike of a structure with a revolving restaurant at the top—often the only pavilion to survive the event. The difference here is that the res­taurant is in the shape of a high, bejeweled golden tiara. [9]			tíng		pavilion			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%ABF"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">亭的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AB46"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">亭的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E4%BA%AD"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">亭在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=311"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">亭在RTK：pavilion</span></a>	RTH
0300	亮	亮	shining	9	To restore those musty old tiaras in the museum back to their original shiny luster, it occurs to you to try an air blaster. Picture yourself with a tank of compressed air strapped to your back, protective goggles over your eyes, and nozzle in hand. As you approach the row of irreplaceable treasures, you squeeze the trigger and a hurricane-force wind sends the whole display fly­ing against the far wall and landing in a heap of junk. [9]			liàng		light; bright			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%ABG"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">亮的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AB47"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">亮的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E4%BA%AE"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">亮在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=2920"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">亮在RTK：translucent</span></a>	leech RTH
0301	京	京	Capital	8	When you think of a capital city, think of the tally domed capi­tal building with swarms of small folk gathered around its base, probably demonstrating for their governments attention. [8]	❖ As a primitive element, this character will take the meaning of a <span style="font-weight:600; font-style:italic;">capitol building</span>.		jīng		capital; Beijing (abbrev.)			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A8%CA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">京的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A8CA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">京的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E4%BA%AC"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">京在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=312"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">京在RTK：capital</span></a>	RTH
0302	涼	凉	cool	11	Here we see a capitol building getting a cool shower (the drops of water)y probably because some politician has done some­thing scandalous again. [11]			liáng		cool; cold			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B2D"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">涼的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B244"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">涼的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%87%89"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">凉在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%87%89"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=313"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">涼在RTK：refreshing</span></a>	RTH
0303	景	景	Scenery	12	Scenery is depicted as a sun rising over a capitol bwi Wing, which is as close as some city dwellers get to natural scenery for years at a time! [12]			jǐng		scenery, circumstance			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B4%BA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">景的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B4BA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">景的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%99%AF"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">景在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=314"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">景在RTK：scenery</span></a>	RTH
0304	就	就	at once	12	The key word at once suggests an order to be carried out imme­diately. In this case, it is our little Frankenpooch being sum­moned to come at once to the capitol building to testify before a subcommittee on organized crime in the canine world. [12]			jiù		at once, right away			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B4N"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">就的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B44E"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">就的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%B0%B1"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">就在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1969"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">就在RTK：concerning</span></a>	leech RTH
0305	周	周	Circumference	8	Look more closely at your lidded crock and you will see little ruler marks along its bottom edge. This is so you can use it to calculate the circumference of your motorcycle helmet: just begin at a fixed point and turn the lidded crock around and around, keeping it flush against the side of the helmet, until you come back to your starting point. If you kept track of how many turns and part-turns your lidded crock made, you now know the circumference. [8]	❖ As a primitive, this character can take the added signifi­cance of a <span style="font-weight:600; font-style:italic;">lap</span>.		zhōu		circuit, lap, cycle; encircle			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A9P"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">周的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A950"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">周的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%91%A8"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">周在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=317"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">周在RTK：circumference</span></a>	RTH
0306	週	周	Week	11	Picture a circular road with seven markers on it, one for each day of the week. When you have walked one complete lap on this road, you shall have completed one week. [11]			zhōu		week; cycle			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B6g"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">週的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B667"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">週的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%91%A8"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">周在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%91%A8"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=318"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">週在RTK：week</span></a>	RTH
0307	士	士	Soldier	3	The shape of this character, slightly differing from that for soil by virtue of its shorter final stroke, hints at a broad-shouldered, slender-waisted soldier standing at attention. [3]			shì		warrior, soldier, knight; scholar; expert			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4h"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">士的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A468"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">士的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%A3%AB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">士在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=319"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">士在RTK：gentleman</span></a>	RTH
0308	吉	吉	lucky	6	Here we see a statue of the famous Soldier of Good Fortune, G. L. (&quot;Good Luck&quot;) Joe, standing on a street with a gigantic open mouth. Every day people walk up to and stick their heads down deep inside. As the superstition goes, G. L. Joe will make this their lucky day. [6]	❖ When this character is used as a primitive, we shall take this shape to mean an <span style="font-weight:600; font-style:italic;">aerosol can</span>, from the <span style="font-weight:600; font-style:italic;">mouth</span> and the very tight-fitting <span style="font-weight:600; font-style:italic;">lid</span> (note how it differs here from the <span style="font-weight:600; font-style:italic;">lidded</span> crock).	(&quot;auspicious&quot;)	jí		lucky; Jilin Prv. (abbrev.)			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A6N"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">吉的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A64E"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">吉的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%90%89"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">吉在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=320"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">吉在RTK：good luck</span></a>	RTH
0309	買	买	to buy	12	We have waited to introduced this character here because it forms a pair with the following frame. Depicted here is a woman at a fish market to buy some quality oysters. You should be able to see her eyeball right down on one of the oysters, examining its quality at close range. [12]			mǎi		to buy, purchase			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B6R"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">買的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B652"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">買的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E4%B9%B0"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">买在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E4%B9%B0"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=831"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">買在RTK：buy</span></a>	RTH
0310	賣	卖	to sell	15	The companion character to buy is that for sell. The only dif­ference is the soldier watching the person eyeing something to buy, just to be sure that everything is properly paid for. [15]			mài		to sell			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%BD%E6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">賣的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=BDE6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">賣的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%8D%96"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">卖在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%8D%96"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=323"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">賣在RTK：sell（売）</span></a>	RTH
0311	書	书	Book	10	The sage talks rapidly with his tongue wagging in his mouth, while the brush of the scribe runs apace to write down the mas­ter s words in a book for posterity.<br />Just as the stroke order changed in the abbreviated form that cow took as a primitive (frame 235), here, too, the last two strokes of the element for brush are drawn in a sequence differ­ent from that of the frame above. [10]			shū		book, letter, document; writings			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AE%D1"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">書的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AED1"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">書的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E4%B9%A6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">书在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E4%B9%A6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=327"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">書在RTK：write</span></a>	RTH
0312	畫	画	a Drawing	12	The character for drawing begins, logically enough, with a brush But what in heaven's name, you ask, are those brains doing lying on the floor&quot;? We leave the rest of the story of you. [12]			huà	&quot;Draw boundary lines...delineate, draw, paint; drawing, painting; stroke (in writing) -- 聿 to draw 凵 or 一 lines: boundaries of a 田 field&quot; --Karlgren.<br />        An old form is 畵. In the common full form 畫, the bottom 凵 is reduced to 一.<br />        In the simple form 画 the top 聿 is left out.<br />        Compare 昼(晝) zhòu which is similiar to 画(畫) in the full form.<br />	a painting, picture, drawing; to draw			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B5e"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">畫的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B565"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">畫的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%94%BB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">画在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%94%BB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1170"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">畫在RTK：brush stroke（画）</span></a>	RTH
0313	劃	划	to scratch	14	Remember the game where one child would scratch a drawing of something on another kids back to see if she could guess what it was? Here we have a troupe of bored French Foreign Legionnaires playing the game with long, shining sabers.[14]			huá, huà		to scratch; to row or paddle a boat			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B9%BA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">劃的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B9BA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">劃的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%88%92"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">划在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%88%92"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・	RTH
0314	攻	攻	to attack	7	A foreman, the taskmaster at a large construction site, orders his workers to pick up their I-beams and attack the house of the little old grandmother who refuses to leave the home she has lived in all of her life. 0315	敗	败	to fail	11	The taskmaster lays the rod to all the clams that fail to make the grade in Marine School.[11]			bài		be defeated, decline, fail			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B1%D1"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">敗的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B1D1"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">敗的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%B4%A5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">败在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%B4%A5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=331"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">敗在RTK：failure</span></a>	leech RTH
0316	故	故	deliberately	9	To do something wrong deliberately is to risk the ire of that most ancient of taskmasters: the law. [9]			gù		ancient, old; reason, because			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%ACG"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">故的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AC47"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">故的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%95%85"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">故在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=333"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">故在RTK：happenstance</span></a>	RTH
0317	救	救	to rescue	11	Usually it is the school taskmaster who is requesting something or other of us, but here you are drowning in the swimming pool and the only one around is that most dreaded of all your cur-ricular taskmasters, your English poetry teacher. You carefully parse your words: "I respectfully request that you rescue me immediately." [11]			jiù		to save; to assist; to rescue			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B1%CF"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">救的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B1CF"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">救的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%95%91"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">救在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=936"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">救在RTK：salvation</span></a>	RTH
0318	敬	敬	to revere	13	In front of someone you revere, you get self-conscious and may try to speak in flowery sentences. The taskmaster at the right is drilling you in the practice of &quot;polite language.&quot; [13]		(<u>not</u> <i>to venerate</i>)	jìng		to respect, venerate, revere; to salute			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B7q"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">敬的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B771"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">敬的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%95%AC"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">敬在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=334"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">敬在RTK：awe</span></a>	RTH
0319	敞	敞	spacious	12	The leap from esteem and taskmaster to spacious seems huge, but if we associate the key word with the song &quot;America the Beautiful,&quot; it becomes but a small step. &quot;O beautiful for spa­cious skies...&quot; begin the well-known lyrics that esteem the natu­ral beauties with which the country has been blessed. But then, directly in the second stanza, the song enjoins the country to &quot;Confirm thy soul in self-control,&quot; reminding us of the need to be taskmasters over our selfish appetites. [12]			chǎng		spacious; uncovered			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B4%AF"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">敞的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B4AF"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">敞的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%95%9E"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">敞在n词酷</span></a>・	RTH
0320	言	言	to say	7	Of all the things we can do with our mouths, speech is the one that requires the greatest distinctness and clarity. Hence the character for say has four little sound waves, indicating the complexity of the achievement. (The hand-drawn form, unlike the printed form, begins with something like a top hat.) [7]	❖ When this character is used as a primitive, it will often be given the meaning of <span style="font-weight:600; font-style:italic;">words</span>.	(words)	yán		to speak; to say; talk; word			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A8%A5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">言的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A8A5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">言的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%A8%80"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">言在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=335"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">言在RTK：say</span></a>	RTH
0321	警	警	Police	20	For all the negative things some people have to say about the police, when they get pulled over on the highway, chances are they bite their tongues and make a special effort to revere the officers' words, hoping to get off with just a warning. [20]			jǐng		guard, watch; alert, alarm			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%C4%B5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">警的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=C4B5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">警的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%AD%A6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">警在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=336"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">警在RTK：admonish</span></a>	RTH
0322	計	计	a Plan	9	Words and a needle combine to form the character for a plan. Think of the needle on some kind of meter or gauge, depending on what kind of plan you intend for your story [9]			jì	"Prison break": <b>plans</b> are <i>words</i> tattoed (<i>needles</i>!) on his body.	plan, plot; strategem; scheme			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%ADp"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">計的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AD70"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">計的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%AE%A1"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">计在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%AE%A1"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=337"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">計在RTK：plot</span></a>	RTH
0323	獄	狱	Prison	14	Here we have a typical scene in a high-security prison for the scum of the canine world: a weak and vulnerable chihuahua (doing time for insider trading) surrounded on the prison yard by a ferocious looking pack of wild dogs (all of them long-tim­ers and hardened criminals). The only thing the chihuahua has to protect himself from the pack are his shrill and frightened words. [14]			yù		prison, jail; case; lawsuit			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%BA%BB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">獄的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=BABB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">獄的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%8B%B1"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">狱在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%8B%B1"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=338"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">獄在RTK：prison</span></a>	RTH
0324	討	讨	to condemn	10	Words spoken to condemn us stick to us like glue in a way no other words can. [10]		(<u>not</u> <i>to accuse</i>)	tǎo		to ask for, demand; to send a punitive expedition			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B0Q"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">討的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B051"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">討的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%AE%A8"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">讨在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%AE%A8"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=340"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">討在RTK：chastise</span></a>	RTH
0325	訓	训	Instruction	10	The personalism connoted by the word instruction, as opposed to "teaching" or "discipline," suits the picture here of words guid­ing ones progress like the gentle flowing of a stream. Even the etymology of the word instruction suggests the sense of "pour­ing into". [10]			xùn		instruction, example, pattern; to teach, train			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B0V"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">訓的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B056"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">訓的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%AE%AD"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">训在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%AE%AD"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=341"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">訓在RTK：instruction</span></a>	RTH
0326	話	话	the Talk	13	That the words of the tongue should form the character for talk is no surprise. Think of the phrase, "He's all talk," and a story should not be far behind. [13]			huà		spoken words, speech, talk, conversation; dialect; language			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B8%DC"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">話的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B8DC"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">話的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%AF%9D"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">话在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%AF%9D"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=344"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">話在RTK：tale</span></a>	RTH
0327	詩	诗	Poem	13	Since silence is treasured so highly at a Buddhist temple, the words spoken there must be well chosen. Perhaps this is why the records of the monks often read to us like poems. [13]			shī		poem; poetry, verse, ode			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B8%D6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">詩的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B8D6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">詩的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%AF%97"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">诗在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%AF%97"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=346"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">詩在RTK：poem</span></a>	RTH
0328	語	语	Language	14	Whereas the character for say and talk (frames 320 and 326) focused on the actual talking, the character for language stresses the fact that although it is J (remember: the literary I) who use them, the words of a language are not my own. [14]			yǔ		language, words; saying, expression			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%BBy"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">語的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=BB79"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">語的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%AF%AD"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">语在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%AF%AD"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=347"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">語在RTK：word</span></a>	RTH
0329	讀	读	to read	22	In the age of advertising, most words we read are out to sell some product or point of view. 0331	談	谈	to discuss	15	In attempts to discuss an issue, the fervor of one's convictions can come to the surface and create an inflammation of words (if you will, the "cuss" in discuss). 0332	這	这	this	10	When you are driving along, you sometimes see words written on the road before you, usually telling to stop or yield or slow down or watch out for something or other. In this case, we see only the word This written in giant white letters. Imagine the scene, and the confusion it would cause you for hours after­wards. [10]			zhè		this; these			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B3o"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">這的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B36F"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">這的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%BF%99"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">这在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%BF%99"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=2414"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">這在RTK：crawl</span></a>	RTH
0333	式	式	Style	6	Take style in its sense of some fashion design or model. Then let the element arrow and work stand for the well-known style of shirts known as &quot;Arrow shirts&quot; because of the little arrow sewn on each one. [6]			shì		type; form; pattern; style			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A6%A1"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">式的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A6A1"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">式的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%BC%8F"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">式在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=353"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">式在RTK：style</span></a>	RTH
0334	試	试	Test	13	When a manufacturer produces a new style for the market, the first thing that is done is to run a test on consumers, asking them to say frankly what they think about the product. Never mind the anachronism (the character was there well before our capitalistic market system) if it helps you remember. [13]		(not <i>take an exam</i>)	shì		to test, try; test, experiment			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B8%D5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">試的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B8D5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">試的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%AF%95"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">试在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%AF%95"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=354"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">試在RTK：test</span></a>	RTH
0335	戈	戈	Halberd	4	A halberd is a kind of lance made up of a long, arrowhead-shaped pike with two curved blades below it. If you don t have one in your closet, you might consult a dictionary. [4]	❖ When this character is used as a primitive, we will revert to a friendler meaning. Think of the third stroke as a kind of deocrative tassle fixed to the shaft of an arrow to indicate that it is no longer a weapon but a symbol of a <span style="font-weight:600; font-style:italic;">fiesta</span>.		gē		spear, lance, halberd			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4%E0"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">戈的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A4E0"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">戈的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%88%88"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">戈在n词酷</span></a>・	RTH
0336	或	或	or	8	Unless you were one of those saintly children who always did what they were told, you should have no trouble associating the key word in this frame with the stern warning of a parent or teacher to do something—"or else!" Here we see a rather grim depiction of the or else: you are lying down with your mouth on the floor (an inventive substitute to wearing a dunce-cap and sitting in the corner) while everyone else is out enjoying the fiesta.<br />Just as the phrase "or else" does not necessarily imply dire con­sequences but can be used as a simple indication of an alterna­tive, so, too, this character is a simple conjunction. Pay special attention to the stroke order. [8]			huò		or, else; perhaps, maybe			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A9%CE"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">或的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A9CE"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">或的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%88%96"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">或在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=2091"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">或在RTK：a</span></a>	RTH
0337	賊	贼	Burglar	13	From a burglar's point of view, a fiesta is an occasion to take out the old lock-picking needle and break into the unattended sale filled with the family shells (the old form of money, as we saw in frames 76 and 77). [13]			zéi		thief; traitor			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B8%E9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">賊的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B8E9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">賊的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%B4%BC"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">贼在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%B4%BC"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=357"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">賊在RTK：burglar</span></a>	RTH

0339	鐵	铁	Iron	21	You submit a bar of iron to the annual Thanksgiving contest for the thing for which the town is most thankful. At first, everyone laughs at you, but when the judges stop to think of how impor­tant it is for so many of the things we depend on, iron wins the gold medal. 0340	茂	茂	lush	9	The sense of the key word lush is that of something growing luxuriously, though not necessarily in excess-in this case a whole parade of weeds (outcast flowers). By way of exception, the flowers take their normal place over the enclosure. 0341	成	成	to turn into	6	Let the phrase "turn into" suggest some sort of a magical change. What happens here is that the parade marching down main street turns into a dogger-throwing bout between competing bands. Note how only one stroke has to be added to make the change. 0342	城	城	City	9	In this frame, we see a mound of dirt that is being turned into the walls of a city (the way you may have built a sand castle as a child playing on the beach). 0344	威	威	Might&nbsp;&nbsp;[ie: Power]	9	Here we see a march of women demonstrating on behalf of equal rights, a show of might not always welcome to the male chauvinist population.
