0345	滅	灭	to destroy	13	Picture a march of flames demonstrating against the Fire Department for their right to destroy, but being doused with water by the police riot squads. [13]			miè		extinguish; wipe out, exterminate			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B7%C0"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">滅的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B7C0"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">滅的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%81%AD"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">灭在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%81%AD"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=365"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">滅在RTK：destroy</span></a>	RTH
0346	咸	咸	everybody	9	Reading this character off literally, we have mouths on the march. Now as the song reminds us, &quot;Everybody needs some­body sometime.&quot; Here, quite literally, the marching mouths are desperately in need of some body. (For that matter, everyBODY needs a mouth.) Imagine them singing the song and you should feel a twinge of pity that will stick this character in memory. [9]			xián	everybody can wound with the mouth (bite)	all, everyone; together; united			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%ABw"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">咸的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AB77"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">咸的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%92%B8"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">咸在n词酷</span></a>・	RTH
0347	減	减	to reduce	12	A group of unquenchable mouths sets out on a march across the country, drinking water wherever they can find it, until their imbibitions reduce the water supply to a trickle, trigger­ing a national disaster. Of course, you are free to create your own image with the primitives water and everybody. [12]			jiǎn		decrease, subtract, diminish			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B4%EE"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">減的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B4EE"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">減的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%87%8F"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">减在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%87%8F"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=366"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">減在RTK：dwindle</span></a>	RTH
0348	單	单	a List	12	The chatterbox should let you know what kind of a list this key<br>word refers to: an auctioneer's list of items to be sold to the<br>highest bidder. Now all you need to do is imagine that the brain<br>of each of the bidders in the audience has a little meter in it with<br>a needle bobbing back and forth between "buy" and "pass" as the<br>bids continue to rise.<br>Be careful of the writing here. The brain shares a stroke with<br>the needle, which means that the order of writing is thrown off<br>a bit. [12]			dān		bill, list, form; single, sole, only			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B3%E6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">單的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B3E6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">單的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%8D%95"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">单在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%8D%95"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1928"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">單在RTK：simple（単）</span></a>	RTH
0349	戰	战	War	16	Victory in war is commonly celebrated as a national fiesta— until a knock comes at the door informing your family that the younger brother or son whose return you are awaiting is on the list of those who will be returning in a pine box. [16]			zhàn		war; battle; to fight			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%BE%D4"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">戰的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=BED4"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">戰的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%88%98"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">战在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%88%98"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1929"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">戰在RTK：war（戦）</span></a>	RTH
0350	錢	钱	Coin	16	Those special gold-colored tokens minted each year for the Mardi Gras and thrown into the crowds by people on the floats give us the character for coins. [16]			qián		coin, money, currency,			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%BF%FA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">錢的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=BFFA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">錢的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E9%92%B1"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">钱在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E9%92%B1"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=368"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">錢在RTK：coin（銭）</span></a>	RTH
0351	淺	浅	shallow	11	An entourage of floats going from one town to the next must always seek a shallow place to cross the water. Try to picture what happens if they don't. [11]			qiǎn		shallow, not deep; superficial			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B2L"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">淺的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B24C"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">淺的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%B5%85"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">浅在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%B5%85"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=369"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">淺在RTK：shallow（浅）</span></a>	RTH
0352	賤	贱	cheap	15	When the town tightwad agrees to enter a float in the annual parade, he first calculates how many clams it is going to set him back and then starts pinching pennies to make it as cheap as possible. [15]			jiàn		inexpensive, cheap, worthless; lowly			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%BD%E2"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">賤的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=BDE2"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">賤的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%B4%B1"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">贱在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%B4%B1"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=2735"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">賤在RTK：despicable（賎）</span></a>	RTH
0353	止	止	to stop	4	The character for stop is easiest to learn as a pictograph, though you have to take a moment to see it. Take it as a rather crude drawing of a footprint, the track that is left when your foot has stopped long enough to make an impression. The first three strokes represent the front of the foot and the last one, the heel. The big toe (the second stroke sticking out to the right) indi­cates that this is a left foot. [4]	❖ Although the meaning of stop will be retained, we will return often to the pictographic meaning of footprint. When the last two strokes are moved to look like this At, it means a whole trail of footprints, as you might find on the beach. We will not see an example of this until frame 973.		zhǐ		to stop, halt, prohibit			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4%EE"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">止的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A4EE"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">止的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%AD%A2"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">止在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=370"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">止在RTK：stop</span></a>	RTH
0354	步	步	Footstep	7	Footprints that follow one another a few at a time indicate foot­steps. Don t forget what we mentioned back in frame 104 about the abbreviation of the element for few when it appears under another element. [7]			bù		a step; stages in a process			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A8B"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">步的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A842"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">步的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%AD%A5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">步在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=371"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">步在RTK：walk（歩）</span></a>	RTH
0355	涉	涉	to ford	10	One way to ford a body of water is to wade across it on foot You need to take your footsteps one after the other, but unlike a stroll on dry land, you have to be careful to keep your balance and not end up in the water. Remember what is feels like to walk gingerly on the slippery bottom of a shallow stream, calculating your every footstep as you go. [10 ]			shè		ford stream, wade across			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AFA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">涉的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AF41"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">涉的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%B6%89"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">涉在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=372"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">涉在RTK：ford（渉）</span></a>	leech RTH
0356	頻	频	repeatedly	16	The image of something occurring repeatedly, over and over again, is of having ones head walked on, a succession of foot­steps trampling on your cranium. [16]			pín		frequently; repetitious			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%C0W"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">頻的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=C057"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">頻的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E9%A2%91"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">频在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E9%A2%91"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=373"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">頻在RTK：repeatedly</span></a>	RTH
0357	肯	肯	to agree	8	Seeing footprints on someone's flesh indicates a rather brutal way of having persuaded that person to agree. [8]			kěn		to agree; to consent; willing			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AA%D6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">肯的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AAD6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">肯的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%82%AF"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">肯在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=374"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">肯在RTK：agreement</span></a>	RTH

0359	歲	岁	Years of Age	13	The character indicating one's years of age pictures &amp; few foot­prints marching along,. No feet, just the footprints. 0360	武	武	military	8	Think of the 24-hour clock, also known as &quot;military time,&quot; as a watch face whose numbers actually go from 1 to 24, but which has only the hour hand on it (the elements for one and arrow), due to cutbacks in military expenditure. Now all you have to do is find a way to introduce the element that can mean either stop or footprint Be sure to retain a military flavor in your image. [8]			wǔ		martial; military			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AAZ"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">武的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AA5A"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">武的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%AD%A6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">武在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=377"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">武在RTK：warrior</span></a>	RTH
0361	賦	赋	Levy	15	A levy can be imposed for any number of reasons, but here it is pictured as a certain number of clams (money) collected by the powers that be to offset current military expenses—presumably so they can get back the minute hand for watches like the one in the last frame. [15]			fù		tax, taxation; bestow on, endow with			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%BD%E1"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">賦的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=BDE1"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">賦的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%B5%8B"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">赋在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%B5%8B"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=378"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">賦在RTK：levy</span></a>	RTH
0362	正	正	correct	5	"A journey of a thousand miles begins with a single step," says _1—_&amp;<br />the Chinese proverb. Here we see one footprint, complement­ing that proverb with the sound advice that if the first step is not correct, the rest of the journey will be off track. This is the ideal that teachers are supposed to have in correcting their stu­dents, and parents in correcting their children. [5]			zhèng		right, proper, correct; to correct			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A5%BF"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">正的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A5BF"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">正的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%AD%A3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">正在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=379"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">正在RTK：correct</span></a>	RTH
0363	政	政	Politics	9	To the many definitions for politics that already exist, this char­acter offers yet another: correct taskmastering. When those in politics twist this ideal and start maneuvering people to their own advantage, it is time to elect a correct taskmaster. [9]		(<u>not</u> <i>govern</i>)	zhèng		politics; government; political			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%ACF"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">政的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AC46"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">政的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%94%BF"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">政在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=381"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">政在RTK：politics</span></a>	RTH
0364	定	定	to settle on	8	To settle on, in the sense of deciding on a certain course of action, is likened here to mending ones house. [8]			dìng		to determine, decide, settle on			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A9w"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">定的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A977"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">定的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%AE%9A"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">定在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=382"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">定在RTK：determine</span></a>	RTH
0365	走	走	to walk	7	To walk, we are told here, has the effect of mending the soil. If you consider what driving an automobile over the soil does to it, taking more time off to walk might not be a bad idea.<br>Note that the final stroke of soil doubles up with the first stroke of mending. Of course, you could also use soil and trail of footprints as the primitive elements, but if you do, youre on your own. [7]			zǒu		to walk, move; to go, leave			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A8%AB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">走的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A8AB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">走的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%B5%B0"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">走在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=384"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">走在RTK：run</span></a>	RTH
0366	超	超	to transcend	12	Things that are beneath us tempt us to be satisfied with less than we are capable of. It is the things that transcend us that summon us to walk the path to a higher state.<br />Note in this and the following frame how the element for walk can embrace other elements from below, much the same way as the element for road does. In order to do this, the final stroke needs to be lengthened. [12]		&quot;super&quot;	chāo		to overtake, exceed, transcend; ultra—, super—			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B6W"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">超的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B657"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">超的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%B6%85"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">超在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=385"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">超在RTK：transcend</span></a>	RTH
0367	越	越	to surpass	12	Here we see two parades in competition, each trying to surpass the other by walking at breakneck pace from one town to the next. Note the little &quot;hook&quot; at the end of the first stroke of the element for parade. This is the only time it appears like this in the characters treated in these books. [12]		(<u>not</u> <i>to transcend/super</i>)	yuè		to exceed, surpass; to climb over			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B6V"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">越的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B656"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">越的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%B6%8A"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">越在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=387"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">越在RTK：surpass</span></a>	RTH
0368	是	是	to be	9	"To be, or not to be: that is the question" Hamlet's soliloquy is a prime example of how memorizing a little Shakespeare can mend a tongue wagging in the mouth* transforming the bro­ken speech of everyday English into a few minutes of golden eloquence. Like Hamlet, we, too, are riddled with doubt. "To Shakespeare or not to Shakespeare: that be the question" [9]			shì		is, am, are; to be; yes			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%ACO"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">是的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AC4F"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">是的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%98%AF"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">是在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=388"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">是在RTK：just so</span></a>	RTH
0369	題	题	Topic	18	The topic of your term paper appears at the top of the first page. That be what your paper's about, dude. 0370	建	建	to build	9	To build something complex, you first need to draw a set of plans (the writing brush) and then s-t-r-e-t-c-h your drawing out to scale in reality. 0371	延	延	to prolong	8	To prolong something enjoyable, like a vacation, is to stretch it out for as long as you can. If you look closely, you can see a stopper (the long drop) halting the progress of the footprints of time. [8]			yán		to prolong, extend, delay			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A9%B5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">延的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A9B5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">延的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%BB%B6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">延在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=392"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">延在RTK：prolong</span></a>	RTH
0372	誕	诞	Nativity	15	The key word, of course, calls to mind the feast of Christmas. As the famous poem at the start of St. John's gospel tells us, the nativity we celebrate at Christmas had its origins at the very start of time and governs all of human history. Celebrating the nativity prolongs the memory of the eternal Word in time and space. [15]			dàn		birth; birthday; bear children, give birth			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%BD%CF"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">誕的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=BDCF"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">誕的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%AF%9E"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">诞在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%AF%9E"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=393"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">誕在RTK：nativity</span></a>	RTH
0373	楚	楚	clear	13	If you build a zoo in the woods, the animals might feel comfort­able, but the visitors wouldn't get a clear view of anything but the trees. [13]			chǔ		distinct; clear; orderly			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B7%A1"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">楚的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B7A1"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">楚的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%A5%9A"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">楚在n词酷</span></a>・	RTH
0374	礎	础	Foundation	18	This character depicts a cornerstone, which was not—as it is today—a decorative slab of marble set in a corner of a finished building. Rather, it was the first stone laid as a clear guide for all the other stones to follow. It was, quite literally, a foundation stone. [18]			chǔ		foundation, base			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%C2%A6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">礎的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=C2A6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">礎的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%A1%80"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">础在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%A1%80"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=394"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">礎在RTK：cornerstone</span></a>	RTH
0375	衣	衣	Clothing	6	At the top we see the top hat, and at the bottom a pictographic representation of the folds of a piece of clothing. If you break the four folds into two sets of two strokes, you will find it easier to remember the character for clothing. [6]	❖ When this character is used as a primitive element, particu­lar attention has to be paid to the changes in shape that it can undergo. In fact, it is the most volatile of all the charac­ters we shall treat, and for that reason we will assign distinct meanings to each of the variant shapes.<br />When it appears to the left, it looks like this: 衤 and we shall generally take it to mean a cloak or cape. At the bot­tom, when attached to the stroke immediately above it, the first two strokes (the top hat) are omitted, giving us: A, which we shall take to mean a scarf.<br />On rare occasions, the final four strokes are drawn with the first two strokes slightly repositioned to give us JOc. We will refer to this element as a bandana. An example will not show up until frame 610.<br />Occasionally the element can be torn right across the middle, with the first two strokes appearing at the top and the last four at the bottom of another primitive or cluster of primitives: in which cases we shall speak of a top hat and scarf.<br />And finally, of course, the element can keep its original character shape, along with its original meaning of clothing in general.		yī		clothes			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A6%E7"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">衣的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A6E7"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">衣的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%A1%A3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">衣在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=396"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">衣在RTK：garment</span></a>	RTH
0376	裡	里	inside	13	All you need to do is imagine a computer sewn to the inside of your clothing, and you are equipped to begin your career as a<br />spy. [13]		(not "internal")	lǐ		inside, interior, within			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B8%CC"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">裡的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B8CC"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">裡的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E9%87%8C"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">里在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E9%87%8C"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=2973"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">裡在RTK：back [old]</span></a>	RTH

Fields might have played with relish. 0378	袁	袁	Yuan	10	It is used today as a family name, well illustrated by Yuan Shikai (1859-1916). 0379	遠	远	distant	13	The distant figure on the road is Yuan Shikai, receding into the annals of suspicious politicians.[13]			yuǎn		far, distant, remote			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%BB%B7"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">遠的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=BBB7"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">遠的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%BF%9C"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">远在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%BF%9C"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=402"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">遠在RTK：distant</span></a>	RTH
0380	壞	坏	bad	19	When we introduced the character for water back in frame 126, we noted that one of its primitive element shapes (to which we assigned the meaning snowflake) often appears one way in block print and another in handwritten or calligraphic form. Here we see an example of just that. There are a lot of elements to work with here in creating a story for bad. It begins with dirt and passes on to the top hat and scarf which sandwiches two more elements: eyeball and snowflake. Now, while some people have the capacity to find something good in everything, here we see a pessimistic aristocrat (in top hat and scarf) with his eyeball fixed on a snowflake and looking for the tiniest speck of dirt in it to satisfy his macabre view of reality. [19]			huài	<i>vis: earth+Baba Yaga</i>	bad; evil; rotten, spoiled, broken down			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%C3a"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">壞的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=C361"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">壞的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%9D%8F"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">坏在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%9D%8F"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=400"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">壞在RTK：demolition（壊）</span></a>	RTH

0389	肺	肺	Lungs	8	One is surprised, strolling through the market, to find amidst the flesh hung out for sale a slab marked: lungs. [9]	<span style="color:#ff0000;">The right side is 巿 (four strokes), not 市 shì (five strokes).</span>		fèi	From 月(肉 ròu) 'flesh' and 巿 fú phonetic.<br />        The right side is 巿 (four strokes), not 市 shì (five strokes).<br />巿 [fú] (archaic:) knee covers&nbsp;&nbsp;[pó] (archaic:) abundant vegetation<br />The shape 巿 has obscure origins. The important thing is to distinguish it from 市 shì. 巿 fú has only four strokes, whereas 市 shì has five.<br />        "Knee cover -- a 巾 piece of cloth attached by a 一 ribbon" --Karlgren(1923). (An ancient ceremonial garment.)<br />        "Picture of lianas" --Karlgren(1923). (Possibly, originally a different character from 'knee cover'. See 芾 fú).<br />        Supposedly, this component also occurs in the form 十 over 冂 in 南 nán, 索 suǒ and 孛 bó; the right-hand element of 姊 and 秭 may also derive from 巿.	lung			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AA%CD"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">肺的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AACD"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">肺的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%82%BA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">肺在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=414"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">肺在RTK：lungs</span></a>	RTH

0392	刺	刺	Thorn	8	(primitive thorn: 朿 Here we see a belt of thorns wrapping itself around a tree and choking the life out of it. [6])<br />The full character for thorn differs only by the addition of the saber to the right, presumably to indicate how the poor tree feels as it is being cut into by the heartless thorns. 0393	制	制	System	8	This character shows a unique system for leading a cow to the slaughterer's saber: tie a belt about its waist and fix that belt to an overhead cable, pulling the cow up into the air where it hangs suspended, helpless against the fate that awaits it. [8]			zhì		system; to regulate			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A8%EE"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">制的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A8EE"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">制的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%88%B6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">制在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=418"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">制在RTK：system</span></a>	RTH
0394	製	制	to manufacture	14	To manufacture clothing nowadays one needs an international system of production and distribution. The label sewn into so many articles of clothing indicating their origin from other parts of the planet shows how commonplace it has become to manufacture goods on a large scale. 0395	云	云	to utter	4	This character is meant to make visible that invisible but oh-so-famUiar rising cloud of hot air originating at the podium of some boring professor you know who utters his pet theories while looking off into the distance with an air of self-absorp­tion, completely oblivious of his audience. [4]	❖ When used as a primitive element, this character will take the meaning of a <span style="font-weight:600; font-style:italic;">rising cloud</span> of something or other.		yún		to say, speak&nbsp;&nbsp;[clasical]			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4%AA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">云的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A4AA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">云的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E4%BA%91"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">云在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=2102"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">云在RTK：quote</span></a>	RTH
0396	雨	雨	the Rain	8	This character, also a primitive, is one of the clearest instances we have of a complex pictograph. The top line is the sky, the next three strokes a pair of clouds, and the final four dots the rain collected there and waiting to fall. [8]	Used as a primitive this character can mean either <span style="font-weight:600; font-style:italic;">rain</span> or <span style="font-weight:600; font-style:italic;">weather</span> in general. To conserve space, it is usually con­tracted into a crown by shortening the second and third strokes into a crown like this: Note how the four dots are straightened out in this case.		yǔ		rain; rainy			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%ABB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">雨的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AB42"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">雨的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E9%9B%A8"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">雨在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=422"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">雨在RTK：rain</span></a>	RTH
0397	雲	云	Cloud	12	Here is the full character for cloud from which the primitive for a rising cloud derives. Clouds can begin with rising clouds of vapor that ascend from the surface of the planet and then gather to form those dark, ominous clouds that eventually dump their rain back on the earth. 0400	霜	霜	Frost	17	Think of frost as a venture in which the malevolent forces of weather cooperate with one another. 0403	天	天	Heavens	4	This character is meant to be a pictograph of a great man, said to represent the Lord of the Heavens. (You may, of course, use the elements ceiling and St. Bernard dog instead.) 0404	夭	夭	to die young	4	If you've ever wondered where the St. Bernard dog got its name, this character suggests a plausible answer. The first of these friendly Alpine canines, originally known simply as "Bernard dogs," died young in a sudden avalanche. Being blameless, she was wafted right up to her heavenly reward and fitted out with a halo one size too big for her hallowed head (the extended drop of the first stroke, written right to left). Centuries later she was "caninized" and came to be known as St. Bernardette, which later chauvinist theologians altered to Sr. Bernard. [ 4 ] 			yāo [普], yǎo [國]		to die prematurely; tender; gentle			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4%D4"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">夭的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A4D4"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">夭的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%A4%AD"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">夭在n词酷</span></a>・	RTH

0416	商	商	Salesman	11	See the peddler standing atop his motorcycle helmet as if it were a soapbox, hawking his wares to passersby. Make the legs and mouth represent the tools of the salesman's trade any way you can.<br />Note how the legs in the printed form in this frame look like human legsy while in the hand-drawn form below, they are clearly animal legs. There is no logical accounting for these vari­ations—at least not yet. Once again, we recommend you imitate the hand-drawn form. [11]			shāng		commerce, business, trade			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B0%D3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">商的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B0D3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">商的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%95%86"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">商在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=439"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">商在RTK：make a deal</span></a>	RTH

0454	竟	竟	unexpectedly	11	This character gets its meaning from the following frame. It shows a queen standing in front of a mirror and asking who is the fairest of them all. Unexpectedly the mirror sprouts a pair of human legs and begins to run around the room. A giant tongue wagging in the mouth appears on its surface, announcing that the mirror itself is fairer by far than the queen and all the maidens of the kingdom put together. [11]	❖ The primitive meaning for this character will be a mirror.		jìng		unexpectedly; actually; to go so far as to			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B3%BA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">竟的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B3BA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">竟的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%AB%9F"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">竟在n词酷</span></a>・	RTH

0465	於	于	[all-purpose preposition]	8	The all-purpose preposition, set here in parentheses to indicate its grammatical function, is the Swiss Army knife of Chinese grammar. Its meanings include at, in, on, by, to, of, for, and from. In time, your grammatical compass will help you with the usage of this character, but for now kick your feet up under a beach umbrella and pour yourself a cold one on ice. [8]			yú		in; at; to; from; by			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A9%F3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">於的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A9F3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">於的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E4%BA%8E"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">于在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E4%BA%8E"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=2900"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">於在RTK：within</span></a>	RTH
0466	旁	旁	Side	10	Think of the key word side in connection with the image of a sidekick, an assistant or companion so named because he is always alongside you. He, or she, is the one who carries the com-pass, the crown9 and the vase. All you have to do is find a way to relate these three elements to ttie kinds of adventures the two of you are used to getting into. [10]			páng		side; by side, close by, near			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AE%C7"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">旁的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AEC7"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">旁的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%97%81"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">旁在n词酷</span></a>・	RTH
0467	兌	兑	to convert	7	The key word should be understood in the sense of changing one thing into another, as when we convert currency. The char­acter shows a teenager with a devil's horns, which most parents with adolescents will have no difficulty sympathizing with, as their teenagers systematically and continually convert their parents' hard-earned wages into feed for the vultures at the shopping mall. [7]	❖ The primitive meaning for this character will be devil, in line with the explanation above.		duì		to cash, exchange			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A7I"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">兌的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A749"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">兌的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%85%91"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">兑在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%85%91"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・	RTH
0468	脫	脱	to undress	11	To undress is to expose the flesh and bring out the devil in ones onlookers. Ignore the moral if you want, but not the devil. [11]			tuō		to shed, take off; to escape, get away from			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B2%E6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">脫的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B2E6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">脫的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%84%B1"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">脱在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%84%B1"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=498"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">脱 / 脫在RTK：undress</span></a>	RTH
0469	說	说	to speak	14	"Sticks and stones may break my bones, but words will never hurt me." Yea, sure. Just think of all the ways that the words one speaks can bruise and wound and sting; they can be barbed and sharp, cruel and inflammatory. Let there be no doubt about it: there can be a devil in the words we speak. [14]			shuō		to speak, say, talk			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%BB%A1"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">說的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=BBA1"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">說的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%AF%B4"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">说在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%AF%B4"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=499"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">説 / 說在RTK：rumor</span></a>	RTH
0470	曾	曾	formerly	12	For the key word, think of individuals who formerly held office as administrators or heads of state. The character is composed of a pair of horns growing out of a brain impaled on the horns of a dilemma—With a tongue wagging in the mouth beneath. The dilemma of formerly prominent public figures is how to stay in the public eye even after retirement. The wagging tongue shows how so many of them do it, namely, by advertising their opinions on public policy. The horns growing out of the top show what a devilish nuismce they often make of themselves in the process. [12]	❖ The primitive meaning of this character, increase, comes from the next frame. Always think of something multiply­ing wildly as you watch.		céng		already; at some time in the past; before; once			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B4%BF"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">曾的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B4BF"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">曾的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%9B%BE"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">曾在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=501"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">曾在RTK：formerly（曽）</span></a>	RTH
0471	增	增	to increase	15	In this character we see the soil increase, multiplying so fkst that it literally buries everything in its path. [15]		(full character)	zēng		to increase, add, expand, augment			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%BCW"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">增的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=BC57"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">增的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%A2%9E"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">增在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=502"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">增在RTK：increase（増）</span></a>	RTH
0472	贈	赠	to make a present of	19	In today's world, there are fewer and fewer ways of making a present of something without seeing it as an investment await­ing its just return in time. And not only in today's world. How often unscrupulous colonizers in different parts of the world made a present of a handful of trinkets or clams (money) to unsuspecting locals as an investment that ended up increasing a million times over as they expropriated land, precious metals, and natural resources. Do not confuse this key word with the temporal word &quot;present&quot; (frame 251). [19]			zèng		give a present; to bestow, donate, confer			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%C3%D8"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">贈的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=C3D8"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">贈的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%B5%A0"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">赠在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%B5%A0"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=503"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">贈在RTK：presents</span></a>	RTH
0473	東	东	East	8	As a "Western" language, English identifies the east as the direc­tion from which the sun rises. In more fanciful terms, we see the sun piercing through a tree as it rises in the east. [8]			dōng		east, the east; eastern, eastward			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AAF"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">東的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=AA46"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">東的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E4%B8%9C"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">东在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E4%B8%9C"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=504"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">東在RTK：east</span></a>	RTH
0474	棟	栋	Building	12	This key word is used with a number as a classifier for counting buildings, not as a generic noun for structures. The elements suggests trees in the East一perhaps like the forests of innumer­able buildings we find in Beijing or Tokyo. 0476	也	也	also	3	This character is a pictograph of the scorpion, the first two strokes representing its head and pincers, the last stroke its barbed tail, in which you may recognize the fishhook.<br />To associate this image with the key word, think of the two terms that the word "also" links in a sentence and place a scor­pion there, its head biting on one word, its tail stinging the other. [3]	❖ The primitive meaning will remain scorpion, in line with the above explanation.		yě		also, too, in addition, as well			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4]"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">也的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A45D"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">也的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E4%B9%9F"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">也在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=2094"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">也在RTK：est</span></a>	RTH

0479	池	池	Pond	6	Water • • • scorpion. It would be easy to slip into a "lazy image" in cases like this one, picturing, let us say, a scorpion near the water. But if you picture a scorpion letting its venom out drop by drop until it has made a whole pond of the stuff, the image is more likely to remain fixed. 0485	己	己	self	3	This character carries the abstract sense of the self the deep-down inner structure of the human person that mythology&quot; often depicted as a snake—of which it is a pictograph. 0492	家	家	House	10	This is the full character whose primitive form we learned already. 0495	羊	羊	Sheep	6	This pictograph shows the animal horns at the top attached to the head (third stroke), the front and back legs (strokes four and five), and body (final stroke). [6]	❖ The primitive meaning remains sheep. As we saw with the cow, the "tail" is cut off when it is set immediately over another element: .Note the change in stroke order, as exemplified in the following frame.		yáng		sheep			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A6%CF"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">羊的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A6CF"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">羊的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%BE%8A"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">羊在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=547"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">羊在RTK：sheep</span></a>	RTH

0508	確	确	reliable	14	The stone on the left is clear enough, but take care with the unusual stroke order of the turkey on the right. 0509	午	午	Noon	4	With a bit of stretching, you might see a horse's head pointing leftward in this character. That gives the primary meaning of the Chinese zodiacal sign of the horse, which corresponds to the hour of noon. Note how this character differs from that for cow (frame 235). [4]	❖ As a primitive, this character gets the meaning of a stick horse.		wǔ		7th Earthly Branch; HORSE; [11:00am - 1:00pm]; noon			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4%C8"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">午的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A4C8"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">午的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%8D%88"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">午在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=568"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">午在RTK：noon</span></a>	RTH

0529	心	心	Heart	4	This character, a pictographic representation of the heart, is among the most widely used primitives we shall meet. [4]	❖ As a primitive, it can take three forms, to which we shall assign three distinct meanings.<br>In its character form, it appears beneath or to the right of its relative primitive and means the physical organ of the heart<br>To the left, it is abbreviated to three strokes, f, and means a wildly emotional state of mind.<br>And finally, at the very bottom, it can take the form小、,in which case we give it the meaning of a valentine. Examples will not appear until Book 2,		xīn		heart; mind			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4%DF"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">心的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A4DF"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">心的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%BF%83"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">心在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=595"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">心在RTK：heart</span></a>	RTH

0547	必	必	certainly	5	First note the stroke order of this character, which did not really evolve from the heart even though we take it that way. If one takes it as a pictograph "dividing", the heart in two, then one has arrived at a "certitude" about human anatomy: that each heart is certainly divided into two halves. [5]			bì		certainly; must; will; necessarily			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A5%B2"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">必的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A5B2"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">必的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%BF%85"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">必在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=635"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">必在RTK：invariably</span></a>	RTH

0578	才	才	Genius	3	Whatever one is particularly adept at―one's special &quot;genius&quot;— one can do very easily, &quot;with one finger&quot; as the phrase goes. This character is a pictograph of that one finger. Note how its dis­tinctive form is created by writing the final stroke of the ele­ment for fingers backwards. [3]	The primitive meaning, geniey derives from the roots of the word genius. Use the genie out of the bottle when the primi­tive appears to the right of or below another primitive; in that case it also keeps its same form. At the left, the form is altered to广,and the meaning becomes a genie in the bottle.		cái		ability, talent, gift, endowment			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4~"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">才的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A47E"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">才的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%89%8D"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">才在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=681"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">才在RTK：genius</span></a>	RTH

0584	及	及	to catch up with	3	The addition of a final stroke transforms this character from the primitive for a clenched戶into the character for catch up with. Observe how eliminating the hook in the second stroke and slanting it to the left gives the character a more elegant form.<br />Sometimes our emotions get ahead of us and it takes a little time for us to catch up with them. In this character, all it took was one "stroke" of kindness to turn afist clenched in anger into a hand reaching out in reconciliation. [3]	♦:♦ As a primitive, this will stand for outstretched hands. Only take care not to confuse it with beg (frame 434).		jí		to extend, reach, come up to			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4%CE"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">及的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A4CE"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">及的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%8F%8A"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">及在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=688"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">及在RTK：reach out</span></a>	RTH

0589	又	又	again	2	You should have no trouble remembering this short two-stroke character, since you will meet it again and again in its primitive meaning. [2]	♦:♦ Etymologically, this character is said to be a pictograph of the right hand, hence its inclusion in this lesson. You can always take right hand as its primitive meaning, as we will see in just a few frames. More commonly, however, we will try to avoid confusing it with other primitives of similar meaning by assigning it the meaning of crotch, as in the crotch of an arm or a tree. Or whatever.		yòu		(once) again; also; both... and...			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4S"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">又的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A453"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">又的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%8F%88"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">又在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=696"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">又在RTK：or again</span></a>	RTH

0595	觀	观	to observe	25	(stork: Here we have a senile, old turkey that thinks its a stork. 0610	派	派	Faction	9	Water... drag •.. bandana. [9]			pài	<i>Water ... tributary</i><br />{From 氵(水 shuǐ) 'water' and 𠂢, which is supposed to be 永 yǒng 'forever' written backwards, depicting water flowing. The original meaning is &quot;to branch off, like a river&quot;. The lower right part  under 𠂆 is coincidentally written the same as the lower right part of 旅 lǚ 'travel'.}<br />&quot;drag-bandana = drag-rag = zombie&quot; ??	clique, group, faction			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AC%A3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">派的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=ACA3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">派的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%B4%BE"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">派在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1855"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">派在RTK：faction</span></a>	RTH

0612	爪	爪	a Claw	4	This character is a pictograph of a bird's claw, and from there comes to mean animal claws in general (including human fingernails). Since the first two strokes are the same as the element for drag, you can imagine a cat dragging its claws across a blackboard to get you started. [4]<br />	❖ When this character is used as a primitive, we shall some­times give it the graphic image of a vulture, a bird known for its powerful claws. It generally appears above another primitive, in which case it gets squeezed into the form 、、'•		zhǎo ; zhuǎ		claw, talon			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4%F6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">爪的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A4F6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">爪的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%88%AA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">爪在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=727"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">爪在RTK：claw</span></a>	RTH

0636	擊	击	to beat	17	To the elements for missile and hand, try combining the ele­ments for car and mountain into a jeep or similar mountain-climbing vehicle to get to your key word beat. [17]<br><i>Juggernaut ... hand</i>.			jī [普], jí [國]	Originally 毄, from 軎 and 殳 (shū) 'beat'. The meaning was, to jostle or bump, 口 representing the end of a 車 (chē) war chariot's axle. 毄 became 𣪠 by the omission of one stroke. Then a 手 (shǒu) hand was added, forming 擊. The modern simple form is 击.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<br />        Compare 繋 xì, also a rare character 墼 jī.	to hit, strike; to break			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%C0%BB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">擊的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=C0BB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">擊的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%87%BB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">击在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%87%BB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=709"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">擊在RTK：beat（撃）</span></a>	RTH

0645	谷	谷	Valley	7	Look closely at the character in this frame and the one right above it and you will see the difference between the priEQitive element for eight and that for animal legs: the second stroke in eight bends gracefully outwards, while in animal legs it just kind of drops down.<br>But this doesn't tell you what animal legs are doing on top of an umbrella. The answer lies in the mouth of the valley, which is what you should think of when you see this kef word. In order to stop the illegal immigration of afl sorts of critters from the surrounding territories, a gigantic umbr^a, obviously made of a material tough enough to resist the trampling of the animal legs trying to creep across the border, has been laid over the mouth of the valley.【7】			gǔ		valley			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A8%A6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">谷的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A8A6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">谷的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%B0%B7"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">谷在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=788"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">谷在RTK：valley</span></a>	RTH

0661	歹	歹	malicious	4	This character is meant to be a pictograph of a bone attached to a piece of flesh (or vice versa). The key-word meaning, <b>malicious</b>, should not be far behind. The sense of the key word is not restricted to time, as the English expression suggests, but can also refer to space.[11]	Used as&nbsp;&nbsp;a primitive, this character will change its meaning to a brightly colored <i>mandala</i>.		màn		long, large; handsome			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B0%D2"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">曼的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B0D2"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">曼的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%9B%BC"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">曼在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=2100"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">曼在RTK：mandala</span></a>	RTH

0682	失	失	to lose	5	"To <b>lose</b>" here takes the sense of "misplace," not the sense of <i>defeated</i>, whose character we learned in FRAME 61. 0699	行	行	Line Of Business	6		As a primitive this character has two forms. Reduced to the left side only, 彳 it can take the meaning of a <i>queue</i>, from the above explanation. When the middle is opened up to make room for other elements, it becomes a <i>boulevard</i>.		háng		profession; professional; relating to a company			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A6%E6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">行的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A6E6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">行的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%A1%8C"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">行在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=873"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">行在RTK：going</span></a>	RTH

0733	算	算	to calculate	14	If you have ever used an abacus to <b>calculate</b>, you should have no trouble with this character. The <i>bamboo</i> sticks provide the frame, and in place of beads you have <i>eyeballs</i>. Now all you need to do is add your <i>two hands</i> to do your gruesome calculations.[14]			suàn		to calculate, compute, figure			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%BA%E2"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">算的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=BAE2"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">算的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E7%AE%97"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">算在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=946"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">算在RTK：calculate</span></a>	RTH

0776	丈	丈	100 Chinese Inches	3	We already met the <i>Chinese inch</i> (FRAME 153). To remember how to write the character for a hundred of them, draw the three strokes in the order shown below, saying as you go "10 times 10." If you think it helps, you can use the element for <i>tucked under the arm</i> that appears in the final two strokes.[3]			zhàng		ten feet			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4V"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">丈的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A456"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">丈的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E4%B8%88"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">丈在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=691"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">丈在RTK：length</span></a>	RTH

0778	久	久	long time	3	This character uses the diagonal sweep of the second stroke to double up for <i>bound up</i> and a <i>person</i>. Think of a mummy and the key word will not be far behind.[3]			jiǔ	vis: mummy	a long duration of time			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A4["><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">久的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A45B"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">久的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E4%B9%85"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">久在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1016"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">久在RTK：long time</span></a>	RTH
0779	畝	亩	Chinese Acre	10	The <b>Cinese acre</b>, whose size can differ from region to region, is written <i>top hat</i> ... <i>rice field</i> ... <i>long time</i>.[10]			mǔ	"1 亩 &lt;=&gt; 1 top hat-wearing mummy" ?? 0784	眾	众	Multitude	11	<i>Net ... person ... assembly line</i>.[11]			zhòng	眾 has a variant: 衆 (12: 血+乑)<br />{Three 人 (rén) people: a crowd. The ancient form had the three people side by side. To this was added 罒(目 mù) 'eye': all the 众 people in 目 view, producing the full from 眾. The three 人 people are sometimes distorted to 乑, and in the variant 衆, 罒 is changed into 血 (xuè 'blood'). The simple form 众 resembles the original, but with a triangular arrangement. Compare 聚 jù.}	multitude, crowd, masses			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B2%B3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">眾的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B2B3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">眾的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E4%BC%97"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">众在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E4%BC%97"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1857"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">眾在RTK：masses（衆）</span></a>	RTH

0813	游	游	to go swimming	12	<i>Water ... banner ... child</i>.[12]<br />(<i>Water ... roam</i>.)			yóu	==== 斿 [yóu] (obsolete: yóu ribbon at top of flag; old form of 游 yóu)<br />From  'waving branches' and 子 'person'.<br />        "The flowing, streaming points of a flag" --Karlgren.<br />        Not originally related to 方 fāng.<br />斿 <b>yóu; liú</b>&nbsp;&nbsp;<span style="font-weight:600; text-decoration: underline;">I</span> <b>yóu, liú</b> <i>сущ</i>.&nbsp;&nbsp;кисть; фестон&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;斿旐 знамя с фестонами&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;縿斿 полотнище знамени и фестоны по его краю <span style="font-weight:600; text-decoration: underline;">II</span> <b>yóu</b> <i>гл</i>.&nbsp;&nbsp;<i>вм</i>. 游 (давать волю, давать отдых)<br /><br />wiktionary:<br />Etymology: Ideogrammic compound (會意): 㫃 + 子<br />Han character: 斿 (radical 70 方+5, 9 strokes, cangjie input 卜尸人弓木 (YSOND), four-corner 08247)<br />&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;1. to swim<br />&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;2. to move or rove freely<br />	to swim; float, drift; wander, roam			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B4%E5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">游的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B4E5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">游的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%B8%B8"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">游在n词酷</span></a>・	RTH

0859	斬	斩	to hew	11	<i>Car ... tomahawk</i>.[11]		(to behead)	zhǎn	{From 车(車 chē) 'car' and 斤 (jīn) 'axe'.<br />        &quot;Cut asunder, cut off, decapitate -- 車 chariot with 斤 axes on it&quot; --Karlgren.<br />        &quot;It is a souvenir of the ancient chariots with scythes, says the Glose. More probably 車 the whirling of an 斤 axe brandished&quot; --Wieger.}<br /><br />{{Main Entry: hew<br />Pronunciation: \ˈhyü\<br />Function: verb<br />Inflected Form(s): hewed; hewed or hewn \ˈhyün\; hew·ing<br />Etymology: Middle English, from Old English hēawan; akin to Old High German houwan to hew, Lithuanian kauti to forge, Latin cudere to beat<br />Date: before 12th century<br /><br />transitive verb 1 : to cut with blows of a heavy cutting instrument<br />2 : to fell by blows of an ax &lt;hew a tree&gt;<br />3 : to give form or shape to with or as if with heavy cutting blows &lt;hewed their farms from the wilderness — J. T. Shotwell&gt;intransitive verb 1 : to make cutting blows<br />2 : conform, adhere &lt;hew to tradition&gt; —often used in the phrase hew to the line &lt;no pressure…on newspapers to hew to the official line — New York Times Magazine&gt;}}	to cut, chop, sever; to behead			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B1%D9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">斬的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B1D9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">斬的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%96%A9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">斩在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%96%A9"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=2092"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">斬在RTK：chop off</span></a>	RTH

0862	質	质	Quality	15	<i>Two tomahawks ... shells</i>.[15]			zhì&nbsp;&nbsp;[普], zhí&nbsp;&nbsp;[國]	{The full form 質 has 斦 (斤 jīn 'axe' doubled) on top of 貝 (bèi) 'money': a kilogram of money.<br />        The simple form 质, like the variant 貭, is altered to resemble 盾 dùn 'shield'.}	matter, material, substance			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%BD%E8"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">質的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=BDE8"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">質的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%B4%A8"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">质在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%B4%A8"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1137"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">質在RTK：substance</span></a>	RTH
0863	斥	斥	to reprimand	5	<i>Tomahawk ... a drop of</i>.[5]			chì	{Originally formed of 广 and 屰, long ago abbreviated to 𠂆 and 下.<br />        &quot;To 屰 attack in 广 the house&quot; --Karlgren.<br />        An alternative explanation is that 斥 chì derives from 斤 jīn axe with an added dot marking the blade, analogous to 刃 rèn.<br />        &quot;An axe on which the cutting edge of the blade is marked: upbraid (or reproach), scold, expel&quot; --Lindqvist.}	to blame; reprove; reprimand			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%A5%B8"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">斥的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=A5B8"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">斥的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%96%A5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">斥在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1138"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">斥在RTK：reject</span></a>	RTH
0864	訴	诉	to accuse	12	<i>Words ... reprimand</i>.[12]			sù	{诉[訴] ⁴sù b.f. ①tell; relate; inform gàosu ②complain; accuse sùkǔ ③sue; appeal ¹qǐsù ¹shàngsù<br />From 讠(言 yán) 'words' and 斥 (chì) 'denounce'.<br />        &quot;斥 blaming 言 words&quot; --Karlgren.<br />        斥 has one more stroke than 斤 (jīn 'axe').}	to complain, accuse; to sue; to inform, tell			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B6D"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">訴的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B644"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">訴的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%AF%89"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">诉在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E8%AF%89"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1139"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">訴在RTK：accusation</span></a>	RTH
0865	乍	乍	for the first time	5	This character is a picture of a saw. We leave it to you to make an association to the key word: <b>for the first time</b>.[5]	In line with the above explanation, the primitive meaning of this character will be a <i>saw</i>. 0869	雪	雪	the Snow	11	<i>Rain</i> that undergoes a change so that it can be swept aside with a <i>broom</i> is <b>snow</b>.[11]			xuě	{From 雨 (yǔ) 'rain' and 彐, picture of a hand (), originally from 彗 (huì) 'broom': 雪 snow is frozen 雨 rain which can be swept with a 彗 broom.}	snow			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B3%B7"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">雪的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B3B7"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">雪的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E9%9B%AA"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">雪在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1143"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">雪在RTK：snow</span></a>	RTH
0870	急	急	anxious	9	<i>Bound up ... broom ... heart</i>.[9]		(<u>not</u> <i>worried</i>)	jí	{The top 刍 was originally 及 jí, which is a 又 hand grabbing a 人 person. 急 and 及 are cognate; 急 is enlarged by 心 (xīn) 'heart'. In 急, the 人 person is written ⺈, and the 又 hand is written 彐, but the similarity to 刍(芻) chú 'hay' is accidental. The 急 in 隐(隱) yǐn and 稳(穩) wěn has yet another origin.}	hurried; worried			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%AB%E6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">急的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=ABE6"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">急的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%80%A5"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">急在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1146"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">急在RTK：hurry</span></a>	leech RTH
0871	尋	寻	to seek	12	<i>Broom ... I-beam ... mouth ... glue</i>.[12]			xún	{The full form is 尋: 彐 over 工 and 口 over 寸.<br />         ", 寸 two hands working with 工, 口 instruments for unraveling thread: unravel, investigate" --Karlgren.<br />        工 and 口 are omitted in the simple form 寻.}	to search, look for, seek			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B4M"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">尋的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B44D"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">尋的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%AF%BB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">寻在n词酷（</span></a><a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E5%AF%BB"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#550000;">简体字）</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1145"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">尋在RTK：inquire</span></a>	RTH

0878	事	事	Matter	8	This key word here refers to abstract <b>matters</b>. The elements are: <i>one ... mouth ... rake</i>. 0893	斗	斗	Big Dipper	4	<i>ice</i> and a kind of distorted <i>ten</i>	Since we already have a primitive element for a &quot;dipper&quot; - namely, the <i>ladle</i> - we shall let this one stand for a <i>measuring cup</i>. 0900	散	散	scattered	12	<i>Salad ... flesh ... taskmaster</i>.[15]			sǎn; sàn	792 &nbsp;散 [sàn] break up; distribute; dispel &nbsp;[sǎn] fall apart; scattered &nbsp;[sān]<div><div>From 龷, 月(肉 ròu) 'meat', and 攵(攴 pū) 'beat'. 龷 = 林 = 麻 is hemp fibers. Whatever you 攵 beat, either 肉 meat or 麻 hemp, it will fall apart eventually.</div><div><span class="Apple-tab-span" style="white-space:pre"> </span>"A cognate word is 撒 sǎ sprinkle" --Karlgren.</div><div><span class="Apple-tab-span" style="white-space:pre"> </span>The left side is NOT 昔 xī, which has 日 rather than 月.</div></div><div><br /></div>	scatter, disperse, break up			<a href="http://zhongwen.com/cgi-bin/zipux2.cgi?b5=%B4%B2"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">散的字源</span></a>・<a href="http://stroke-order.learningweb.moe.edu.tw/word_detail.jsp?big5=B4B2"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">散的筆順</span></a>・<a href="http://www.nciku.com/search/zh/%E6%95%A3"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">散在n词酷</span></a>・<a href="http://kanji.koohii.com/study/?framenum=1189"><span style="text-decoration: underline; color:#005500;">散在RTK：scatter</span></a>	RTH
